TALK.START.PARA: —I table the explanatory memorandum and move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The essence of the patent system is to encourage entrepreneurs to develop and commercialise new technology. Since a patent confers a limited monopoly over the use of the patented technology, the patent owner has the opportunity to make a profit from it, gaining a return on investment in innovation. The international character of the patent system makes patents a useful tool in penetrating export markets.

It is against this background that the Patents Bill was formulated. The present Bill is in fact a reincarnation of the Patents Bill 1989. That Bill was introduced on 1 June 1989 by the Hon. Barry Jones as Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business. However, it had not been debated when Parliament was prorogued prior to the March 1990 election. The Patents Bill 1990 derives from the 1989 Bill, but also takes into account a number of submissions made by members of the public about that Bill. Those included submissions by expert groups in the patents field: the Institute of Patent Attorneys of Australia, the Australian Manufacturers' Patents, Industrial Designs, Copyright and Trade Mark Association, and the Law Council of Australia's Intellectual Property Committee.

The extent of participation by users of the patent system in formulating the Bill is heartening. I intend that it continue, where appropriate, in further legislative developments in the industrial property field.

The economic effects of patent systems have been the subject of debate for at least a few centuries. The main arguments were outlined by the Industrial Property Advisory Committee (IPAC) in its report ``Patents, Innovation and Competition in Australia'', which forms the major basis for the policy changes which the Bill represents. Economists have not agreed, however, and IPAC, chaired by John Stonier of BHP Co Ltd, produced a report which was constructive rather than revolutionary. IPAC sought to improve the operation of the system so as to maximise the benefits and minimise the costs to Australians.

The most significant changes made by the Bill focus on fostering indigenous innovation and the use of the international patent system in developing export markets to improve Australia's international competitive position. For example, the standard of patentability for standard patents is strengthened by testing inventions for novelty and inventive step against disclosures in recorded form anywhere in the world rather than, as at present, just in Australia. Novelty and inventive step for petty patents, on the other hand, will be tested only against prior disclosures in Australia, consistently with the fact that petty patents are better suited to less significant inventions with a shorter commercial life and less likelihood of achieving market success abroad. Other changes are aimed at improving the efficiency of the administration of the patent system, ranging from examination procedures to enforcement of patents in the courts.

In addition, the Bill uses greatly simplified language and structure in comparison with the present Patents Act, so that it will be more comprehensible to people who are not patent experts. The Bill and IPAC's recommendations have already been dealt with in the Second Reading Speech on the 1989 Bill. There would be no point in my repeating that-it is in Hansard, and I agree with what was said then. I do wish to make two short general observations, however.

First, the patent system of Australia, or any other country, cannot operate usefully in international isolation. The reason for that is not theoretical; the reason is that international trade affects national economies. We in Australia have said and heard a great deal in recent years about our international trading position and its implications for the Australian economy. Patents and other forms of intellectual property have a role to play in international trade because they can assist in the establishment and development of export markets. A patent in Australia gives no protection against appropriation of the patented technology in other countries. But patents obtained by Australian enterprises in other countries can make a tremendous difference when it comes to developing an export market.

There is a two-edged sword here, since availability of patents in other countries to Australians is matched by the availability of patents in Australia to the nationals of other countries. A patent owned by a foreigner restricts imitation of the patented invention in Australia-a fact which has been anathema to some economists. But an Australian patent can also be an essential feature in negotiating an agreement for the licensing by an Australian company of foreign-owned technology. And the Bill, like the present Patents Act, contains provisions expressly designed to prevent abuse of patent monopolies.

The Government, like IPAC, supports the patent system, but believes that it can be modified to enable Australians to make better use of it internationally as well as nationally. One of the main features of the Bill is to move towards greater international compatibility of the standards of novelty and inventiveness which are applied in deciding whether a patent should be granted for an invention in Australia.
The second point I wish to emphasise is that a patent only gives an opportunity for profit-not a guarantee. A patent is no substitute for entrepreneurship in the broader sense.

The mere fact that a product is patented will not persuade people to buy it. Intellectual property is not some form of commercial magic which can cause a profitable market to appear and grow overnight. Marketing skills are just as necessary for success with a patented product as with any other; the difference is that the availability of a patent for a successful product can justify investment in research and development. Having got a patent, however, the entrepreneur must make the best use of it in developing a market. Intellectual property must be managed properly to ensure that it achieves the objectives of both the owner and the community generally.

Patents thus have a subsidiary, albeit important, role in entrepreneurship. The patent system itself is, in IPAC's words, ``a blunt instrument of industrial policy''. There are other more direct ways in which innovation can be stimulated.

This Bill increases the usefulness of the patent system as one of the measures which Australian entrepreneurs can draw upon. It is a constructive example of the Government's commitment to improving the climate in which Australian industry operates, but it is no substitute for entrepreneurship by Australian enterprises.
I present the Explanatory Memorandum to this Bill, and commend the Bill to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before commencing this debate, I would like to refer to the lack of courtesy on the Government's part by its failure to meet a request about the timing of the presentation of the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill 1990. It was my understanding, because of a commitment I had to a congress in town, that this legislation would not be brought in on this occasion. I had to shorten my stay there. I asked for leave of the Senate, which was granted but, because of a misunderstanding or lack of courtesy, I was required to return to the Senate this morning. Obviously there is a lack of communication on the Government's side which has certainly proved embarrassing to the Opposition. I regret what has happened.

SPEECH.PARA: The Senate has before it the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill 1990 for scrutiny and debate. This Bill is essentially the same Bill that was introduced into the chamber, but was not formally considered last year, as the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 6) 1989. The intervention of the general election necessitated a new Bill for consideration by both the House of Representatives and the Senate. The Bill contains an omnibus series of amendments covering many of the proposals originally proposed in the 1989-90 Budget. The issues raised include anti-avoidance measures with regard to the transfer of assets, net capital losses within company groups, exemptions to capital gains tax on a taxpayer's principal residence, rules concerning the concessional treatment of research and development, and other matters such as income tax treatment of a carer's service pension, interest payments on overpaid tax and tax file arrangements.

I would like to raise some practical problems associated with the amendments to the capital gains area. The legislation proposed within this Bill with regard to the transfer of net capital loss within the company group and the transfer of assets between companies within the same group are complex, cumbersome and produce unintended consequences that are beyond the original tenor of what the Government intended. The coalition considers it inappropriate at this time that the Government should be introducing legislation that is beyond the comprehension of the everyday taxpayer and completely contrary to what was intended in the first place.

I believe it is essential for the Opposition to cooperate within its philosophy with the Government to ensure that certainty is achieved in terms of what is intended as to how taxpayers will interpret and understand the law. Therefore, it behoves us all as members of the Opposition to bring to the attention of government those areas of legislation that have been hastily drafted and do not fulfil the Government's stated intention and need redrafting.

We are seeking amendments in a couple of areas to overcome deficiencies. As we mentioned to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) last night, it is no good his seeking and encouraging industry to review and restructure when, at the same time, the Treasurer (Mr Keating), espousing the same ideals, puts up roadblocks that make this impossible and rejects Opposition amendments which see the way clear to overcome those problems. The Government is either genuine or hypocritical.

I am seeking assurances in this debate that there will be further consultation within industry to ensure the rapid passage of some of the needed amendments even if the Government does not agree with what we are putting forward today. Within a short period the identical amendments that we are putting forward today will come back, albeit in a slightly revised form, in three months, six months or, if we are unlucky as we have been in the past, we may have to wait two or three years, in which case incalculable damage would have been done to the speed of restructuring many essential Australian industries simply because this Government is too proud to say, `We will have another look at it, there might be another way of doing it-there might be a simpler and more direct approach'. Unfortunately this Government has a red-necked attitude towards tax avoidance and wants to pick up the last dollar rather than the last $100. For that reason it couches its amendments so wide as to make normal commercial dealing almost impracticable.

The Government espouses the need to improve performance, and companies have to move into new areas. Before they can add an additional coated paper product to a process of paper manufacturing and paper processing, they have to have an environmental impact statement. There is no allowance under tax law for these items to be treated as an expense or written off. It does not meet the challenges that are required of a changing society. The Government demands with one hand and takes with the other. It makes it more difficult for industry to meet the challenges of the future by its archaic ways and obsession that 98 per cent of Australian taxpayers are tax avoiders and tax cheats. It is time the Government opened its eyes. We have moved away from the 1970s and we are now in the 1990s, with a new approach. The Government has to take off its tunnel vision approach to legislation and has to make sure that it is not so tight as to make normal commercial transactions law avoidance.

The coalition believes that much of this legislation is contrary to normal commercial practice. It is important that we cooperate with government and that within our philosophy we ensure certainty within the law. We had a debate the other day about the need, with self-assessment, to have this certainty. The package of Bills before us today takes away that certainty and creates more uncertainty.

Two areas of the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill need great attention. First, I will discuss the areas dealing with the transfer of net capital loss within a company group-section 160zp in clause 23 of the Bill. I beg the patience of the chamber in discussing the next two areas as they are rather technical. One section permits a loss company-that is a company with a capital loss-to transfer to a gain company an amount of capital loss for capital gains purposes where both companies are within the wholly owned group. This is stated government policy, but there are roadblocks all the way in the legislation before us.

We acknowledge that mischief can arise by way of a double tax benefit if the loss company is subsequently sold. This derives from the fact that when a company sells an asset at a loss the net worth of the company is reduced and this is reflected in a decrease in value of the shares or other investment in the company. In other words, the company suffers a loss, which is deductable for capital gains purposes, and the shareholders, in turn, suffer a similar loss. By selling the shares-that is if acquired post-September 1985-the shareholder may also create a loss for capital gains purposes.

The Government proposed to limit the transfer of losses within a group to the extent of the post-September 1985 investment in the loss company. Also, the cost base, which is an indexed cost base, will be reduced by the amount of the loss transferred so avoiding scope for a double tax benefit.

The legislation, as presently drafted, does not achieve this objective. What is the purpose of putting legislation forward which does not even achieve the objective that it is seeking? In fact, it goes far too wide. The approach is: we must stop the last dollar of any possible tax avoidance. For example, loss transfers would be available only to the extent of post-September 1985 investments. This would mitigate against long established company groups-that is, those established pre-1985 which would have cause to keep the loss in the loss company, and carry it forward, and suffer tax in the gain company in circumstances where the group had made neither a loss nor a gain by the simple process of combining the two companies.

The Opposition's solution is quite simple: it attacks the typical tax avoidance case which involves the sale of the loss company shortly after the loss transfer. We propose that a deemed amount of the consideration, equal to the loss transferred, should be added to the sale price of this loss company if it is sold within three years. This very simple approach overcomes the problem.

If the Government believes that three years is too tight a period-and with current interest rates, that is hardly the case-let it put up an amendment to extend it to 3 3/4 or four years. To protect the long term restructuring of Australian industry the Government should make it simple, straightforward, understood and practical; it should not build in cumbersome arrangements that are impractical, costly to administer and ineffectual. In most cases of group loss transfers the loss company continues to be retained and so no suggestion of double tax benefit arises.

It is believed that, under our amendment, by limiting the period to three years it would overcome virtually all tax avoidance arrangements. The Government has not been able to point out one tax avoidance practice in this area; but we acknowledge that there is the potential for it to happen. It is fair enough that the Government has attempted to close the gap ahead of what might happen, but not in such a way as to close down business.

It should be noted that the converse can arise: a company with a capital gain could be sold with a further liability attaching to the shareholders. Of course, no attempt has been made to remedy this double taxing. So the Government catches on the one hand but, on the other, it is not prepared to offset a situation where there is double taxing. There are numerous examples throughout the tax Act nowadays where the single item of income is taxed in more than one hand. That is not good enough.

The Opposition's redrafted amendment takes note of the Government's original intent. It defeats the tax avoidance scheme without the impractical consequences of the original Government Bill. We say that if the Government is unhappy with this amendment it should come back and-it has had it for a long enough time-seek the necessary improvements. If the Government wants to refine it, it should do so, but it should not allow damage to be done while it sits on the impractical solutions that it is currently putting forward.

In the areas dealing with the transfer of assets within a company group, we have a similar problem. Again, the Government has asked corporations to restructure. We are not restructuring by grabbing a company and rearranging a new one straight away. We are talking about a long term restructure within a company group. With respect to proposed section 160zzo, which is dealt with in clause 31 of the Bill, the original proposals that the Government put forward today were cumbersome and contrary to commercial practice. Our tax Act is stifling business in Australia, and that is not good enough. The proposals require interlocking investments between groups which are frequently inconvenienced. Companies intending to restructure for purely efficiency reasons are prevented from doing so by virtue of the legislation before us today. That is not good enough in these perilous times that the Australian economy is facing.

The Government is constantly pressuring business to restructure, to become more efficient, to compete both domestically and internationally; yet the willingness of these companies to restructure is being thwarted time and time again. We have before the Senate today examples of tax impediments, such as the very amendments that we are referring to, that seek unwieldy, unworkable arrangements including cross-holding securities which some company laws forbid. How much further can we go?

Further difficulties arising from the Government's proposals include the impossibility, in terms of the Companies Code, for a parent company to issue shares to a subsidiary and the impracticality of issuing the alternative securities in terms of the proposal-here The Australian Taxation Office and the Treasury are working on their own without reference to the company law people-the inapplicability of the proposed roll-over consideration requirements, as applied to the restructuring of international and Australian groups' thus potentially excluding groups from the use of roll-overs; the effect of effectively converting previously capital gains tax exempt assets into assets subject to capital gains tax when there is no change in the ultimate beneficial ownership and when that result is not the stated intention in 1985 or later years-the Government is leading us into no-man's-land, a quagmire from which it is going to be very difficult to extricate ourselves in the future-and, finally, the proposed amendments, in effect, reduce the options available to taxpayers with no tax avoiding purposes whatsoever. This is the tunnel vision that the Government has with tax avoidance. In effect, the Government waters down the rights of taxpayers and exposes them to potential capital gains tax liabilities, which in many cases, should not exist.

The transfer of assets between members of a company in exchange for shares issued by the transferee company could create a web of cross-shareholdings between companies within the group, thereby creating unnecessarily the complexity of company groups which, over the years, will add to administrative and auditing costs. In addition, such cross-shareholdings could give rise to flows of dividends through the group which are inappropriate to the normal commercial practice within a company group. The problems caused by such cross-shareholdings as proposed in the legislation cannot be overemphasised.

We have given the Government in advance our proposed amendments for evaluation. We hope that the Government will respond meaningfully. The Liberal-National Party amendments provide greater flexibility and will strike down the offending loopholes. The proposed amendment will assist intergroup transfers and, at the same time, diminish the avoidance possibilities. Where an asset is transferred between companies within a wholly-owned group, any capital gains liability which might otherwise arise may be deferred by placing the purchaser in the same capital gains position as the vendor with regard to the cost base, thus passing on to the purchaser any potential tax consequence-that is, the roll-over benefit.

The coalition acknowledges that tax avoidance may arise in at least two ways. We wish to present a means of overcoming this deficiency in the law. The avoidance can occur in a number of ways. I mentioned that the treatment creates unnecessary cross-shareholdings. The mischief in transferring a post-September 1985 asset to a pre-September 1985 group relates to the concept already covered in proposed section 160zzt and should be covered by specific amendment to that provision. It is the coalition's view that amendments should be dealt with through that section without upsetting the roll-over relief provisions of proposed section 160zzo where a specific provision already caters for this sort of contingency, rather than making 160zzo completely unworkable by extending the definition.

The issue raised in the practice of creating a new company capitalised as the market value of asset is specifically covered by our proposed amendment. At present, a purchaser can pay the market value for an asset, the vendor can claim roll-over relief, and the shares in the purchaser can then be sold at market value without incurring capital gains tax. The liability for capital gains tax remains with the company but unless the underlying asset is sold in the short term the capital gains tax may be deferred indefinitely.

By causing, in our proposal, the consideration for the asset transfer to be limited to the cost base, which is the fundamental structure and integrity of our amendment-indexed or reduced cost base, as the case may be-the shares in the purchasing company will, if sold, give rise to a capital gains liability such as will prevent tax avoidance arrangements. This is a very simple approach compared with the Government's very extensive change which involves excessive use of one provision to roll over into other provisions which have been set up to deal with specific purposes. Each of the proposed arrangements will be the subject of two of the three amendments the National-Liberal Party coalition intends to put forward at the committee stage of this debate.

The third area in which the coalition is proposing to move an amendment is the legislation concerning a taxpayer's principal residence. Here the Bill does not go far enough. Why should the Government discriminate against young people who go out to the suburbs, buy a block of land and put a house on it and who, before the transaction is completed in terms of the requirements of the legislation, are transferred in their work-for example, an operator in Newcastle being required to move from the shipyard down to the frigate project in Melbourne, or a person in the defence forces being transferred overseas or from Sydney to Western Australia, or a person in a bank or insurance company moving to its head office? Why should the Government discriminate against these people, essentially the young people of Australia, who are seeking progress? We require a more mobile work force, yet this legislation is putting a road block on it.

Why should the Government favour a person who has bought an existing house and is getting the benefit of a principal residence exemption and, at the same time, deny that principal residence exemption where a person pursues the alternative route of wanting to build and plan his own home? I certainly hope that the Australian Democrats will move with us on extending that exemption. It could be a compulsory transfer or a non-compulsory transfer. Plenty of precedents exist, but why leave this gap that is essentially going to hurt the younger members of the community? I believe that the coalition's proposed amendment, which the Senate has before it today, can be easily achieved by alterations to clause 34 of the Bill before us.

The Bill has very many examples of hastily drafted legislation. On the three Bills already discussed, the coalition will move amendments in the committee stage of this debate. However, we draw the Government's attention to another area that it might also like to examine-the treatment of research and development technology. It is not consistent with current practice, which generally treats intellectual property as capital assets, which, as such, are subject to part 3a of the Industry Research and Development Act with respect to the sale of eligible assets. Here the Government is moving in an area contrary to international practice and international standards in relation to the treatment of intellectual property, and in an area which poor old Barry Jones used to refer to as the sunrise industries of Australia which were going to help us get out of our current morass.

The proposed amendments provide that, where a deduction has been allowed in respect of eligible activities, they are to be included as assessable income-no great problem. The rate of deduction of expenditure on core technology is limited. Core technology has a special definition, of which all are aware: it refers to intellectual-type property. All assessable income from all receipts from granting access to, or the right to use the results of, a research and development project where expenditure on the project has been allowed as a deduction is included. So, consequently, the result of such research cannot be sold for more than the grant or costs involved and the excess will be taxed; hence the need, of course, to encourage firms to go into research.

Ministers on the other side constantly say that there is a lack of research in Australia and a lack of incentive. The lack of incentive is caused by the failure to the Government's legislation to provide adequate means of compensation where that research is carried on in Australia and subsequently sold. This legislation before us today further inhibits Australian progress in the intellectual sphere of research and development technology transfers.

The effect of the amendment in this Bill before us today-hastily drafted legislation just to get something on the statute book without considering the consequences of its repercussions down the line-is to deny the vendor of research activities the benefits of the indexed cost base provisions provided in part 3a of the Act in respect of the sale of eligible assets. I ask the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator McMullan), who is responsible for this area, to take this legislation back to Cabinet with a view to revising it in order to overcome the dilemma that companies are going to face as a result of its introduction. I appeal to the science community in Australia to apply pressure to this Government to have this particular provision overturned in order that the proper provisions of part 3a can apply.

It has further come to my knowledge that a small, wholly owned Australian research and development based company and another Australian company are participating in an unincorporated joint venture which has developed a system to remotely identify, locate, track and communicate with vehicles in urban environments. It is a system that is unquestionably in a world-leading position. The intellectual property associated with the technology is owned on a 50:50 basis by two companies, and they now propose to transfer their respective interests in the technology to a new company which will be owned on a 50:50 basis by the original two companies which have developed the technology.

The compelling reason for the introduction of the new company is the need for a vehicle to exploit the considerable export potential of this new technology. It is envisaged that aspects of the technology will be licensed, at significant benefit to Australia, to major international telecommunications organisations. The housing of technology in a single entity greatly facilitates this approach. In order to assist the export drive and to provide working capital for the exercise, a third partner is to be introduced into the new company shortly after its incorporation. The two original companies are not proposing to sell any of their assets but to issue new capital.

In the light of the proposed legislation, the original two companies requested the Australian Taxation Office, prior to proceeding to incorporate the new company, to rule on a number of taxation issues. Principal among these is the proposed transfer of the technology to the new company, bearing in mind that this transfer would not generate any assessable profit to the original companies involved and that, for the expenditure prior to 7 September 1990, a transfer would be subject to the roll-over provisions of section 160zzn (2) of the capital gains tax legislation.

The roll-over provisions of the capital gains tax legislation were introduced in recognition of the fact that asset ownership changes associated with specified types of business organisations, where no changes occur in the underlying ownership of the assets concerned, should not constitute taxable events, but the failure to recognise this particular problem has resulted in capital gains tax acting as an impediment to sensible business organisation. Income should be taxed only when income is generated. The amendments before us to section 73b fail to recognise why the capital gains tax provisions allow roll-over.

Companies involved in this new technology, which should have outstanding export value to Australia, have been informed that the transfer of the technology from the original two companies to the new third company will be deemed to generate an income, the value of which will be imputed from the price of any shares issued to a third partner. If, for example, the third partner were to be issued shares amounting to one-third of the total for a price of, say, $5m, the imputed value of each of the two original companies' shares would also be $5m to each of the companies. This is in spite of the fact that neither of the original two companies has received any proceeds and both have sought only to transfer an asset from an unincorporated 50:50 entity to an incorporated 50:50 entity.

The final result is that, in the case of one of the companies which actually has all the technical know-how and experience, the tax liability that will arise out of the incorporation and integration of the third partner will be so great, if imposed, that it will almost certainly result in the liquidation of the company and the end of the new technology and the potential for an excellent export business. The Government is killing from the start a new technology, a new innovation, not as a result of the enthusiasm of the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce but as a result of the tax legislation not being able to cope or keep up to date with modern technology and modern movements.

Whilst this venture is poised after four years of development to launch into the lucrative international telecommunications market, the taxation position could thwart all the efforts of these enterprising people here in Australia to develop new markets and new research and to open up new areas of export. This Government should be encouraging business and encouraging companies to restructure and to export. Yet what has occurred is hasty, detrimental drafting of Bills which hinder business through taxation laws that go far beyond anything that the Government has intended.

I ask the Government to at least give an assurance of when a review is going to be organised to overcome the problems that have been raised. Does the Government intend to follow the path that we have suggested, of agreeing to straightforward amendments, or does the Government intend to defeat this Bill purely for the purpose of winning the game in terms of `The Government beat the Opposition on this amendment because the Government had greater numbers', irrespective of the detriment that the problem is going to cause to the restructuring of companies and irrespective of the suffering that the deficiency is going to cause some young people who may have to refuse a transfer on the ground that they cannot afford the capital gains tax when they are forced to transfer by virtue of their employment, whether voluntarily or involuntarily? I look forward to the Minister's response.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating legislation dealing with changes that the Government announced in the Budget last year-the Government introduced legislation last year that was not passed by both Houses before the dissolution of the Parliament-to deal with a number of matters, including some changes with regard to the treatment of capital gains tax and subsequent matters. The Australian Democrats support the passage of the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill 1990.

SPEECH.PARA: I listened with interest to many of Senator Watson's comments. The passion with which he talks about these matters rarely strikes any other member of this place. But the point of the matter I find strange is the passion with which various changes to the particular pieces of legislation that the Opposition is proposing are put forward, considering that during the last election campaign it wished to abolish the entire exercise. As people know, the Democrats supported this. We were the only party that ever campaigned in an election for the introduction of a capital gains tax. We believe that it is part of the equity establishment within a taxation system that those who earn their income by salary have to pay tax. We believe also that those people who earn their income by capital ought to pay tax too. Prior to the introduction of the capital gains tax it was possible for many people to escape that liability. Of course, that meant that the wage earners of this country had to carry a larger burden because other people were exempt.

In bringing these types of items under a taxing regime there has been a massive amount of equity introduced into the taxation system. It is inevitable when this occurs-certainly from our point of view we strongly urged that there be a starting date with regard to this type of taxation, and that it not be made retrospective-that there is a dividing line. What we have in a large proportion of this particular piece of legislation is again a treatment of that dividing line. So we are going back to 1985 to attempt to modify some of the problems that undoubtedly occur when we move from a total non-taxed context to a taxed context. The proposals that the Government has here are sensible. I will leave to the committee stage those matters which were rehearsed by Senator Watson at the second reading stage as they really form the substance of the amendments he intends to move in the committee stage.

There are also changes being made in this Bill in terms of the company context. I think one could easily foreshadow that given the new company regime to start on 1 July, with any hope, we will be facing further changes because there have been substantial modifications made, particularly with regard to grouped companies, that will have an impact on the taxation regime.

Another item included in the Bill, and probably the most contentious item, is how to treat the major primary exclusion from the capital gains tax, that is, the principal residence. Again, the Government has sought to address a number of quite genuine concerns in the community as to how these matters will be dealt with. I must admit that in wading through the explanatory memorandum, which I found in very large part not to explain anything and only to make the essence of the thing more difficult, I had to go back to the Bill on a number of occasions to try to find out what was going on. I found it difficult. I remember when I asked a previous Minister for Finance to explain to me what the explanatory memorandum meant he could not explain it, neither could any of his advisers. We are getting to the context whereby explanatory memorandums ought to do a little bit of explaining. I hope that those who write these might take a course in plain English-there are excellent ones in Victoria that they could be referred to-so that all of us, including not only people in this place but people who have an interest, might be able to find out in straightforward English what is going on in terms of the changes.

I will raise in the committee stage some interesting waffle in regard to the exercise relating to a principal residence. For a person who is not in residence at the principal residence for up to four years-which I think is an excellent idea as people obviously move around a great deal in this community and that has to be taken into account-there is an extraordinary section in this Bill which explains how the whole thing is treated with regard to a person's absence. I seem to have lost the reference but I will bring it up in the committee stage because I think a lot of people want to know-this is presumably what this particular section is talking about-what happens when they leave their residence.

What is still massively unclear from the explanatory memorandum is what happens when people leave their residence and rent it out. As I remember, in this particular explanatory memorandum, it is referred to as earning income on it; the normal terminology is `rent'. I think most Australians know what rent means. It is a pity that the person who wrote this did not know what rent meant. When a person rents out his residence when he is not living there-which I presume is what it was all about-what happens? I think that is a reasonable question. People ought to know. It ought to be put in a reasonable way so that people can understand and so that their advisers, in reading this material, might be able to advise their clients more quickly and more surely as to what they should do.

Unfortunately, the complexities of the taxation system being what they are, I do not suppose we will ever get a simplified tax system. I know that it is the Government's earnest wish in this regard. It says something is going to happen later this year. There is not a soul in Australia waiting with bated breath for that particular exercise. It seems to me that at least in one step back, if we cannot make the legislation readable, we should at least make the explanatory memorandum readable.

As to the various items in that regime, the Democrats support the variations that the Government has introduced in terms of the treatment of the principal residence. I think every honourable senator has had people talk to them about some of the anomalies that occurred. Particularly difficult for those that I have dealt with, and I am sure other senators have had to deal with, is where a person has died. There was some odd treatment of that exemption where a person died. The difficulties and concerns of the remaining partner as to what precisely might happen if he or she wished to sell their residence at that stage, particularly those residences which in the majority of cases, in a married context, would be owned by the husband and wife. I think the Government's move in these regards is most welcome. In many cases these changes have been backdated, as they should be. Undoubtedly, that was going to cause some unravelling. Nevertheless, I think the Government is on the right track.

This matter can be dealt with more extensively in the committee stage. At the end of the day the line has to be drawn somewhere. I suspect that we will not be able to do a great deal to make that line any more acceptable to those people who fall under it than has been done to date without abolishing the exercise in its entirety. Certainly, our view is that the exercise needs to be treated with a great deal of caution. At the moment the Government's propositions, as have been put in this legislation, seem to meet the difficulties that have arisen.

Senator Watson constantly referred to the matter of hasty drafting of legislation. I am not quite sure to what he referred specifically. I presume that he had some inside knowledge-that I do not have-of the amount of time that it took to draft this legislation. I merely point to the fact, and it will be important in terms of the committee stage debate on the commencement, that the Democrats did say to the Government that we wanted legislation within six months of announcement of these matters. In regard to this legislation the Government has done that. It made the announcement in August and, as I remember, brought in the legislation in November.

The legislation we have before us is new, but is in substantially the same form as the first Bill introduced. This enables the community, particularly advisers, to be aware of what is likely to happen. I agree with Senator Watson that we would not want any hastily drafted legislation. Nevertheless, do we want a return to the situation of having to wait around for months, indeed years, before we see legislation with regard to an announcement? I think the movement to get it done within that six-month timeframe needs complex drafting and undoubtedly mistakes can be and are made.

I would not like my silence to be taken to mean that the Democrats agree that the Government has a lot longer timeframe in which to get its legislation into the Parliament. We believe that when it makes an announcement it ought to introduce legislation with as much despatch as possible, otherwise the destabilising effect of knowing that something will commence from a particular date but not knowing the details of it makes the disposal and operation of one's private affairs extremely difficult. It also makes the operation of company shareholdings, movements and restructurings almost impossible.

We would support the Government moving with as much despatch as possible to get these pieces of legislation into the Parliament, and thereby exposed to the public for longer periods before they are actually passed by the other chamber or this place. It also gives people like Senator Watson, who have an interest in these matters, the opportunity to be able to go through the proposed legislation in detail. It we do not have that timeframe available to us it makes our task more difficult.
The Democrats will be supporting this legislation at the second reading stage. We reserve comments with regard to the points raised by the Opposition until we get into the committee stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly, I express my appreciation to Senator Watson and Senator Macklin for the constructive way in which they have approached not only this debate but also the discussions that have led up to it. I have appreciated the openness with which we have had those discussions. Whatever the outcome on this occasion, it is the sort of process that can, over time, lead to better outcomes from the deliberations of the Parliament. I thank them for that. I indicate my willingness to continue to participate in that sort of process and hope that they will reciprocate.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Watson and I were a little surprised about the timetable that was brought forward for the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill 1990. Last night we discussed what we wanted as a timetable and this was not it. Certainly, I raised it with the representatives of my Party and I presume Senator Watson did as well, but other people's wishes have prevailed. I acknowledge that he has raised it with me.

I will not, at this stage, go into a sort of quasi-committee debate dealing with the detail of all the amendments. In response to some of the points raised in the second reading speech, I am happy to give what are called assurances for continuing consultation, as Senator Watson requested. The Government has already commenced dialogue with business groups concerned about the particular matters to which the Opposition has proposed amendments, with regard to both the transfer of capital losses and the transfer of assets between group companies.

There has also been some discussion on research and development. I am aware of the example to which Senator Watson refers. The people involved have also communicated with me. In regard to those three instances all I want to say at this second reading stage-although I am happy to discuss it in more detail subsequently-is that we do not believe that any of the alternatives proposed are better than that which we have before us. We have looked at proposals that have come from affected companies, related interest groups and the Opposition, and we have tried to be as open as we could.

I suppose we all have to acknowledge that from time to time we may be restricted intellectually by a sort of pride of authorship-this is our proposal and we do not want to see it changed-but on this occasion I think not. We have tried to be open to sensible suggestions and we have indicated to those affected that we will continue to be so. But at this stage there are no amendments from members of the Opposition or industry suggestions that we find acceptable in terms of our principal responsibility, which is to protect the revenue and the interests of the taxpayers who pay their tax regularly and who are entitled not to have an extra burden placed upon them because others enter into complex arrangements to avoid their proper responsibilities.

There are two other points to which I should refer because they do not directly arise from amendments, and I want to respond to a couple of things which Senator Macklin said. With regard to the possibility that double taxation might arise under the Bill I say two things. First, in the normal circumstance the question of a capital gains tax obligation being transferred would obviously be reflected in the price of the asset being transferred. The person buying it would buy it in that knowledge and that would be reflected in the price. In the normal course of events I can see no circumstances in which that double tax would arise.

It is possible that, in a not dissimilar way to a complex arrangement which might endeavour to incur, at the moment, a duplication of the loss, one could enter into a complex corporate arrangement that would incur for one a double taxable gain. It would be an extraordinary arrangement that somebody entered into that achieved that sort of odd objective. I do not think that in the normal course of business this will arise because of the price factor and the information. So we do not have a problem with double tax.

With regard to the question of hasty drafting I do not want to say more than Senator Macklin has said. I think we need to make the distinction between being hasty and being prompt. It is appropriate that these things are dealt with as speedily as possible. It is appropriate for the Parliament; in effect, it is a requirement of the Parliament. It is also appropriate for people in business.

If from time to time this throws up a particular drafting problem, that is something we in this place ought to address. But as a generality I do not accept that this has been particularly hastily drafted. By virtue of the arrangements that took place at the end of last year and then leading up to the election, we have had a chance to have two goes at it. Without unduly delaying procedures we have had the chance to review and revise the drafting.

I want to say with regard to Senator Macklin's comments that I welcome the continuing views that he and the Australian Democrats express concerning capital gains tax overall and I recognise the points that he makes with respect to the principal residence exemption and particularly the question of complexity. I am a great advocate of the plain English approach to drafting. Senator Macklin and I had some experience of it during our membership of the Joint Select Committee on Corporations Legislation. If anything can make the tax Act look simple, it is the Financial Corporations Act. That was a learning experience for all of us. Some discussions are taking place between me and the Australian Taxation Office, and within the Taxation Office, about the question of plain English drafting, in part relating to the ongoing simplification project.

A lot of other things could be said in detail about the amendments but they would be appropriate for discussion in the committee stage, so I will simply conclude by saying that we will not be accepting any of the amendments that have been put forward at this stage. We do not believe they meet the principal obligations on the Government with regard to preventing avoidance but we remain open to constructive suggestions in the future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sorry that perhaps in the second reading debate I did not make sufficient response to the question of principal residence exemption. I am happy to do so now. I want to proceed in the order in which the amendments have been moved-that is, the transfer of net capital losses, the transfer of assets between group companies, and the principal residence exemption. I will not go into matters in great technicality but will try to deal with them in the way that Senator Watson did, in terms of the broad principles that are involved. Having canvassed the matter in the second reading debate it seems to be inappropriate to do otherwise.

SPEECH.PARA: On the question of the transfer of net capital losses, the Government's amendments are designed to prevent a company group from obtaining the benefit of multiple capital losses in respect of one real loss. Our problem with the Opposition amendment, the purpose of which we accept, is that all it would achieve would be to defer for three years the opportunity to realise multiple losses. It may be that the circumstance Senator Watson has outlined is what he calls typical at the moment; the problem is that it would become rapidly atypical the day after we passed this amendment.

That is the problem. I am not saying it would be of no benefit but it does not achieve the benefit for which the Government has proposed the amendment because it could easily be circumvented. The concern which has been raised with me in that regard is that the amendment applies only at the time when a loss company ceases to be a group company, and that is, for the purpose of the Taxation Act, when 100 per cent common ownership ceases. So there are a lot of options between the sale of one per cent and 100 per cent in which companies could still transfer a substantial balance of shares in the loss company without the application of the Opposition's amendment.

We think the three-year mechanism of itself is not satisfactory but also we are concerned that the trigger mechanism in the proposal, whereby the Opposition amendment applies only at the time when the loss company ceases to be a group company, is flawed as well. I think our objectives are common; I do not think what Senator Watson proposes achieves them.

With regard to the transfer of assets between group companies, the proposed Government amendments are essentially intended to prevent the abuse of the concessions available on the transfer of assets between companies sharing common ownership. There are two aspects to those. One is the question of whether the concessions can be used to defer tax on accrued gains indefinitely. `Deferring indefinitely' and `avoiding' are difficult to distinguish when we come to the net effect.

But there is a second problem; that is, the transfer of value-using these concessions to transfer value from assets subject to capital gains tax to assets that are exempt by virtue of their pre-19 September 1985 status. The Opposition I think recognises-and Senator Watson acknowledged-that we could not just allow that potential to go unchecked, and it has attempted to address the problem. I will come back to the question of the business difficulties in a moment, just to reiterate what I said in the second reading speech.

But we are concerned that the Opposition's amendments do not achieve these aims. Even if they are effective in dealing with the deferral problem-and there is significant doubt about that-they do not address the value shifting problem at all, as we see it, and we are not therefore satisfied at this stage that we can accept that amendment.

I reiterate that these amendments have the potential-and, of course, this has been raised with the Government as it has with the Opposition-to cause difficulties for legitimate businesses going about legitimate activities, and we have no desire to achieve that. We have said to them that we wish to cooperate, but we have said to them that we cannot cooperate in a manner that leaves open blatant avoidance mechanisms. However, we have not only said that we welcome further suggestions but also have set out to establish mechanisms that will facilitate those companies and bodies like the Corporate Tax Association most effectively having their views reflected by attempts to come to an agreed position about subsequent amendments. But at this stage we are not prepared-and have made it clear to such bodies and to the Senate, as I did in the second reading debate-to forgo what we believe are necessary amendments for the elimination of tax avoidance opportunities. So we will press on with these but we certainly indicate our openness to further discussion.

Once one enters the principal residence exemption area one has to try to deal with some of the complexities that arise in the arrangements that individuals and families make in relation to the home that they either live in, aspire to live in or aspire to build. The problem we are confronted with is that the Opposition amendments seem to be even more arbitrary and, unfortunately, to a great extent, subjective. Whereas we have a prolblem-which I acknowledge and with which nobody could argue-that there is some arbitrariness in the existing legislation, I do not think we wish to see that problem exacerbated.

All of these discussions raise the question, which, I think, Senator Macklin mentioned, about where to draw the line. The honourable senator asked what is the essential distinction between a change in circumstance caused by a change of employment and a change in circumstance caused by other problems. He mentioned the example of the death of a close relative and I, as a constituency representative, have had examples of that sort put before me. Nobody has mentioned one to me concerning a change of employment. But other circumstances have arisen with people whose financial circumstances have changed, not by virtue of a transfer but for other reasons which have meant they have had to sell. Although they have been subjected to the capital gains tax, can I say that this has been imposed only on the real profit that they have made-on the income which they have earned. I, therefore, wish to say that they have not been subjected to capital gains tax on some notional gain-they are subjected to it only after a gain, and sometimes a quite substantial gain, has been realised.

We also have a problem if a person says, `That block of land is an investment purchased in order to generate the capacity to build a house subsequently'-which is what it becomes if one allows people to sell a block of land and use the profits, tax free, to build their subsequent residence. There is no obvious reason why we should exempt vacant land as against some other capital purchase that an individual may have made for the purpose of making a profit to fund the building of his house. If that were allowed it might equally be argued that gains realised on the disposal of shares to acquire a house are a legitimate investment and ought, somehow or other, be income that is treated preferentially with regard to all other sources of income when it comes to capital gains tax.

We also have a problem when we introduce this subjective element. The tests at the moment-arbitrary, as they need to be, in some circumstances-are at least objective. There are certain fixed periods of time involved for determining the availability of the exemption. We would not wish to see the subjective test introduced, particularly one that I think will create as many anomalies as it resolves. I can imagine the correspondence that would flow saying, `I had to move from Newcastle to Melbourne for some valid purpose other than a change of employment. My neighbour moved because of a change of employment. Otherwise, we were in identical circumstances but we were dealt with differently for tax purposes'. I think this creates a fairly fundamental tax equity question, which the Government feels the Opposition amendment exacerbates.

I raise in advance, in order to avoid duplication, a point which Senator Macklin raised at the second reading stage concerning the principal residence exemption and the situation that an individual who is gaining income from rent may find himself in with regard to this amendment. I think that maybe I have read the explanatory memorandum too often, and perhaps I have a false sense of reality about the extent to which it is capable of being understood by others. But as far as my reading of it is concerned, the explanatory memorandum refers to the situation where houses are rented out during temporary absences. I do not have that document in front of me now and the language may not be as simple as it appears to me in retrospect, but my recollection and understanding is that even if a dwelling is used for income producing purposes-rent, lease or the like-during a temporary absence, that use will be disregarded in determining the availability for the exemption. I think the situation, if it were not clear in the drafting, ought to be clear by that comment. Those are the comments that I wish to make at this stage concerning the amendments.

However, the difficulty is that I think his amendment can be got around precisely by the proposition that was raised by the Parliamentary Secretary-that is, the difficulty, under company law, of moving.

As I understand it, all that would be necessary would be for the loss company simply to enter into a contract for the sale of a share. That loss company would then cease at that time to be a group company. The appropriate proportion of adjustment to the consideration of the disposal of that share would then be made. The balance of the shares in the loss company-which, of course, is now no longer a group company-could then be sold off without the Opposition's amendment being needed at all. That seems to me to be a problem within the three-year context that Senator Watson is talking about. So I think one could drive a hole through the amendment and, therefore, I indicate that the Australian Democrats cannot support it on that basis.

I must admit that that is also one of the reasons for our attitude to the second amendment, which has caused us a great deal of trouble. Indeed, one of my advisers, in exasperation, finally wrote to me and suggested that, as he could not understand what it meant, we should not support it. The amendment is a difficult one. In terms of the amendments which both we and the Opposition have sought to move over time to taxation legislation, one has probably to err on the side of caution because of the possible ramifications throughout the taxation system. Luckily, not all legislation that comes into this place is piled on top of each other as is the case with the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill. Therefore, we are very cautious about these amendments. Indeed, Senator Watson, in his comments at the second reading stage, accepted that there is a difficulty here. The ability to defer tax or credit gains almost indefinitely by movement cannot be accepted, particularly where they carry over that cut off period, that September 1975 boundary-after all, it is that boundary that we are talking about-and then move on in an almost indefinite fashion.

Senator Watson's argument for the Opposition's alternative proposal was quite attractive. However, I still remain to be convinced that the problem of tax deferral and particularly the movement of values has adequately been addressed. On that basis of not being convinced and relying on that abundance of caution necessary in this area, we will not support the Opposition's second amendment.

The third amendment deals with a far simpler matter-if anything relating to this legislation can be simple-and that is the principal residence exemption. As I indicated during the second reading debate, the Government has engaged in a number of movements that we think are acceptable to the general community. The Opposition seeks to go yet a step further to deal with a situation where a person who had bought land and was either preparing to build on it or had built on it had got to the stage of not being able to fulfil the new residency requirement in this Act, which is now only three months rather than the previous six months. One could probably feel something for the people caught up in those circumstances.

The difficulty of deciding where to start this exercise is one we have discussed within the Party. We have had this concern with a number of pieces of legislation. Under the Fraser Administration Senator Colin Mason got quite upset in this place about changing dates for first home buyers. Of all people his son was drummed out of the exercise because he fell on the wrong side of the arbitrary date that was set. There is an arbitrariness about major tax changes. That has to be accepted. If the Government had not chosen to bring in legislation on that particular day, then obviously some other day would have been the cut-off point. Indeed, the same people may have found themselves exempt. To that extent one must sympathise with those individuals.

Like the Parliamentary Secretary, I have not had any of those people raise this matter with me. However, I am prepared to accept, as Senator Watson said, that those people actually exist. At least they are a theoretical possibility. Given the large number of people who move in this country, it is presumably more than a theoretical possibility; this has probably happened to some people out there. This did happen five years ago. I am sure the people have forgotten about it, though I congratulate Senator Watson; he is still fighting on about the issue. But the people probably forgot it and got on with their lives. They probably said, `That's the way it tumbles'.

This is a difficulty. If we were to accept Senator Watson's proposition we would have a new starting point. I am quite sure that we would then have to deal with those people who prior to Senator Watson's starting date had entered into a contract to buy land or who had entered into some contractual arrangement eventually to buy some land. There can be an almost infinite regression. On that basis, one simply has to say, `This is it. This is the point. We are not going any further'. I accept the Government's proposition on that basis. The fact is that a capital gains tax ought to have been introduced long before it was. The fact that it was not indicates a massive failing in the system.

It is not as though we are doing something that is inequitable. The introduction and operation of this tax introduced equity, not inequality. Quite frankly, those people who gained an exemption prior to that date can count themselves lucky. They got away with something which should never have been allowed in our taxation structure. One cannot say that these people have been badly done by. The entire country-all the wage earners-were badly done by because the tax was not in place.

The fact that the Government has seen fit to allow the reduction for three months is a further concession with regard to this principal exemption. The notion of the principal exemption is not likely to die at this particular point; I am quite sure it will live on because of its very nature. Indeed, it became a matter of some controversy because of various items that my Party raised about it during the election that the Government has not seen fit to take up.

I am not moving away from the fact that there are problems with this. But on the basis that we have equity in the system by the very introduction of this tax, it is reasonable to accept the Government's cut-off point. The Parliamentary Secretary's argument that it was introduced on the basis of an objective rather than a subjective ruling is probably as good as any in terms of where the line is drawn. I do not wish to make it any higher than that. There is not a great deal to stand on in any of these particular lines that one draws.

One could even draw the line further back than Senator Watson would like to draw it. When a line is drawn some people are excluded and others are included. The Government has argued that it wishes to do it and it has sought to do it in this legislation on the basis of an objective test. I think that is reasonable with regard to this principal exemption. On those grounds we do not support the Opposition's third amendment.
