DEBATE.TITLE: SOCIAL SECURITY AND VETERANS' AFFAIRS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1990

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 21 May, on motion by Senator Robert Ray:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Social Security and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill is designed to do a number of separate things. It implements many of the social security measures which were announced in the Government's February 1990 economic statement and, indeed, previously proposed in the coalition's Economic Action Plan of October 1989, including such measures as the tightening of the administration of income support for the unemployed, encouraging labour market participation by spouses of married beneficiaries, bringing unemployment benefits and Austudy more into alignment and removing certain anomalies in income support arrangements.

SPEECH.PARA: The coalition takes the view that each of those steps is desirable in terms of providing the right incentives structure in order to avoid the unnecessary temptations that currently arise from the malalignment of such things as Austudy and unemployment benefits. We therefore welcome the rationalisation which we believe provides the necessary incentive signals in order to encourage as many people as possible to re-enter the work force.

It has to be said that most of the significant changes in the Bill relate to the overhaul of the unemployment benefits system, but only pending the Government's foreshadowed total replacement of the current arrangements from July 1991 by the Job Search allowance for the first 12 months and the Newstart allowance for the long term unemployed. That indeed was a hastily cobbled together proposal floated in the heat of the election campaign by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) in the February economic statement. Quite clearly, it was a recognition of the overwhelming level of positive response from the community to the coalition's proposals in relation to the cutting out of unemployment benefits after the first nine-month period and thereafter to allow special benefits where necessary to accommodate those who were still out of employment.

I think the real reason why the Government came up with its own cosmetic proposals lies in the fact that, when pressed for detail, it acknowledges that in the first full year of operation, in 1991-92, the new scheme is estimated to save only $21m. That, I would have thought, was a devastating indictment of its alternative approach. Mr Howard had previously talked about far-reaching initiatives which would involve the total overhaul of the unemployment benefits system but, if we are talking of only $21m worth of savings in the first 12 months, it is fairly clear that that was little more than a cosmetic change designed for pre-election purposes, to try to suggest that somehow the Government was able to trump the Opposition's proposals and that it had a solution of its own to the long term unemployed.

That is a problem that has vexed policy makers for many years. In our judgment, it has been characterised by scandalous neglect on the part of the Government, principally because of a reluctance to come to terms with the hard issues-that very many people had been unemployed for years and that something more needed to be done about them than having periodic reviews. It is interesting to note that the mythology still abounds, because only a week or two back in this chamber during Question Time the Minister for Social Security, Senator Richardson, not only got it wrong in terms of the new government structure-he thought it depended on how old one was-but also thought that the majority of the long term unemployed were those in the age bracket of 50 years or over.

I am sure that Senator Richardson, having gone away and reflected on his off-the-cuff remarks, now acknowledges that the statistics make it painfully obvious that more than two-thirds of the long term unemployed are aged 45 years or younger. Clearly there is a great deal of scope for putting in place a proper incentive structure that would encourage very many of the longer term unemployed to re-enter the work force or to rethink their options and to undertake the training that people on both sides of the chamber recognise is necessary to properly equip those who have been out of the work force for a substantial time.

When we look at a proposal that will save only about $21m, it is fairly clear that the Government simply is not serious in its alternative approach. It can usefully be said that the dichotomy which the Government seeks to draw is false. There is no particular reason why we need to talk in terms of Job Search allowance for the first 12 months and of Newstart thereafter. We are really talking about increased training for those who have been out of the work force for a longer period of time. If that is the case, we do not need to come up with these sorts of cute gimmicks which somehow suggest that there is a new two-track approach which will replace the old system and that this will give us the way to dramatically reduce the numbers of those on the unemployment lists.

The reality is that, the longer a person is out of the work force, the more training and encouragement he or she is likely to need. There is no particular magic about the 12-month cut-off period. In fact, waiting for 12 months before embarking on an intensive phase may well be leaving it far too late. In my experience, it is analogous to delays that one can experience in the courts in personal injuries actions where it takes two or three years to prepare the case for trial, there is an endless round of visits to doctors and lawyers, and endless pensions, all of which tend to reinforce the victim in the notion that somehow there is no great economic disincentive in staying out of the work force and that there is a pot of gold that can be picked up in due course-all the signals are in the wrong direction. By the time people get to court, they find that psychiatrists are saying, `There may well be a significant functional overlay but we do not believe it will disappear once the litigation is concluded'. By now those people will be locked into a mindset which will make it very difficult to get them to come to terms with the true level of physical disability and to have a positive approach to re-entering the work force. The same can be said about the 12-month cut-off period.

In many ways we need to act pretty intensively from a very early point in time. That is to be done either by training or by economic incentives. Yet the Government's proposal does neither. It simply has an arbitrary cut-off point of 12 months and thereafter pretends that somehow we need a new scheme. Well, we do not need a new scheme; we simply need to be upgrading the level of training, depending upon the difficulties confronted by the individual unemployed person. Therefore, it is fairly clear that, despite the rhetoric, this was no more than a crude pre-election bid.
The Treasurer (Mr Keating), on 21 January when the Government's new proposal was unveiled, described it in very high rhetoric:
Our is a constructive and mature approach to help people back into the work force.

Yet on the following day, when asked what he would do to those people on benefits after the initial 12-month period, he said in his inimitable, compassionate style that he would simply `bump them off'.

We still do not have any realistic idea from the Government as to how many people will be moved off benefits under this new scheme. Indeed, it will not even begin to operate until July 1991-17 months after the announcement. One can only imagine that that is because, firstly, the Government needs to cobble together a lot more detail than it was able to trot out during the election campaign and, secondly, the Government is hoping that it will be able to defer any significant expenditure on training schemes and the like.

If the Government was fair dinkum about the need for a dramatic overhaul, which is what this legislation purports to be, one would have thought that there was absolutely no good reason at all why the matter could not have been properly addressed-not during the heat of the campaign-with an early start-up date. Instead, we had a quick off-the-cuff announcement of a dramatic overhaul and then 17 months to think about it. One can only deduce from that that there will be a substantial period of rethinking during that time. It may well be that the Government will try to dress up in another form the fundamental policy approach which the Opposition announced late last year and which was very much welcomed by a great bulk of the population.

To the extent that these changes in the Bill deal with some relatively minor adjustments, they are welcomed. But they really are not the main game. The main game is yet to be properly unveiled and we should not take seriously what the Government put forward during the election campaign.

I want to deal briefly with quite a number of initiatives in the Bill. One matter of concern in the area of long term unemployed that is worth dealing with is that in early 1989 the Department of Employment, Education and Training released figures showing that, out of the 10,000 long term unemployed who were part of the initial Newstart program, on the basis of one letter of advice to attend a departmental interview with DEET, 30 per cent had advised that within two weeks they had obtained employment. We simply do not know how many overall are in employment and receiving benefits when they ought not to be entitled to them. Yet the Government has just furiously ducked for cover on this issue. We have not had any satisfactory explanation as to whether there were significant mistakes made, whether people simply did not get letters when they ought to, whether it was a failure of Australia Post, whether people have subsequently been reinstated, or what the true outcome of that pilot project was. I would have thought that the time was long overdue for the Government to come clean on the issue and to release a measured response to that project, instead of, as I suspect, it being taken seriously in private but discounted heavily in public.

As many people suspect, the reality is that there is still quite a high level of abuse in the system. I say that not in any way to downplay the real demands of the genuine unemployed. To the extent to which there are people who are rorting the system, the capacity of the Government to cater for the needs of those in need of additional welfare is diminished.

Therefore, we all ought to take these matters much more seriously than we do instead of somehow pretending that the problems do not exist because in the course of doing something some interest groups might be offended. Generally, the Government has taken the course of least resistance in this area. As a result, it can accept a large proportion of the blame for the welfare system in this country attracting the odium that it does in many quarters.

The Bill deals with a number of relatively minor and unrelated matters, such as ensuring that Austrian Government restitution payments for Nazi persecution during World War II are not treated as income under the Social Security Act and the Veterans' Entitlements Act. We support that change. It also implements a social security agreement with Spain. Again, there is no reason to regard that as controversial. It allows for back payment of family allowance and family allowance supplement for multiple births despite late lodgment of application. Again, that seems to be a desirable change.

It also provides for the payment at a double rate of the first week's payment for victims of natural disasters. Undoubtedly, that is a worthy initiative as far as it goes, but I am not sure that it does much more than dabble with the problem. Clearly, there will be people in this category from time to time, and I think that a one-off payment of this small size will not really make a great deal of difference other than allowing the Government to claim that somehow it has done something in the area. We deserve to be told what the needs of victims of natural disasters are likely to be in that initial phase, what other emergency arrangements ought to be made and, generally, how the Government proposes to cope in the future in this area.

But the most significant matter that seems to be causing the most angst in the community is the proposal to limit the payment overseas of the wife's pension and class B widow's pension to a maximum of 12 months. I want to deal in some detail with that proposal. As at September 1989 there were some 26,661 persons resident overseas in receipt of a range of pensions and benefits. Of those, over 27 per cent are resident in Greece, 15.5 per cent in Italy, 15.7 per cent in the United Kingdom and Ireland, 12.2 per cent in Yugoslavia and 4.2 per cent in Turkey. Greece and Turkey have been the cause of most community concern. Indeed, they are the two countries with which Australia has very longstanding and, in a number of significant respects, outdated bilateral agreements and treaties which will need to be updated.

Certainly, I take the view that we do not have nearly enough information on the record to know precisely what is going to be renegotiated and what is the justification for Senator Richardson's taking himself off to those climes in the relatively near future. There is a lot more to be said by the Minister before the public can be satisfied that it is necessary for him to swan off and put his name to a couple of agreements. Certainly, the two communities in question are very concerned that there ought to be substantial consultation before any reciprocal pension agreements are signed. As recently as last week, they took the view that to date that certainly had not even started. They also feel very strongly that genuine, open community consultations ought to be carried out by the Government on this vital issue prior to any final decision and implementation.

I find it extraordinary that this Bill has been brought on, in a sense, prematurely. When it could have been put down the agenda for a day or two, it has been brought forward despite the fact that the Greek community are in the process of arranging a meeting in Melbourne this coming Sunday. There was a meeting of quite a large number of community organisations, I think nine in all, representing various sections of the Greek community, which they expressed their very widespread concern about the proposals. There have been a number of requests, almost pleas, to defer the legislation until a number of matters have been clarified. Yet we find that the matter is being dealt with sooner rather than later. That seems to me to be a breach of faith with these communities.

Wives' pensions, both for wives of invalid and age pensioners, and class B widows' pensions vary as a proportion of the total, but, relatively speaking, they represent about 30 per cent of the total of pensions paid to those five principal countries that I have mentioned. In respect of wives' pensions, the Government proposes that it will be able to save $2.4m in the 1991 financial year and $12.6m in the following year, presumably on the basis that once the 12-month period has expired very large numbers of pensioners will drop off the entitlements list. The same range of figures applies in relation to class B widows. It is foreshadowed that $2.2m will be saved in the 1991 financial year; thereafter, $11.5m will be saved.

There is an expectation that a very significant sum of money will be saved after the first year although, in the overall context, wives' pensions currently cost about $747m, which is being paid to almost 200,000 wives of age and invalid pensioners. Class B widows' pensions cost the Government about $565m for 81,000-odd beneficiaries. In some scheme of the total figure, the amounts that are proposed to be saved by these overseas cutbacks verge on the minuscule.

That is why we have to look very seriously at the rationale behind these proposals. I can understand the class B widow's pension being brought into line with the sole parent pension, which has already been cut off after 12 months overseas. I can understand the desire of the Government to encourage those persons to re-enter the work force, although when they go overseas there is very little opportunity to monitor and, therefore, check on any abuse either in terms of not declaring employment or not bothering to seek out employment. But I do not think the same can be said in relation to wives' pensions. It seems that the Government is saying, `If you intend to live overseas permanently'-presumably that is what the 12 months cut-off period is all about-`you will miss out'.

There is a lot of humbug in the proposition that somehow one can come back after 12 months and requalify. My understanding is that one would not have to satisfy any test to do that. One would simply have to come back and prove that one was the spouse of an age or invalid pensioner. That is not something for which temporary residence in Australia would be needed. Even if one simply came back, spent the air fare, established one's claim and went away again, presumably, one would be entitled to another 12 months of pension receipt. I think that is humbug.

It is really a Budget measure under the guise of formulating some elaborate method of requalifying. If the Government has in mind that those living overseas ought not to be entitled to a pension, it ought to have the courage of its convictions to come out and say so. But it seems to me that, if that is the real rationale, that is discrimination on the grounds of residence and, some would say, gender because, obviously, it will affect only wives.

Therefore, I think it is a matter of considerable significance. The view that if one is outside the country one ought not to be entitled to a pension even though one might have been in the work force for many years, does not strike me as equitable. If the Government's real agenda is to cut back on wives' pensions altogether, we ought to hear about that. If this is not the case and the Government is prepared to go on spending 98 per cent or more, probably 99 per cent, on residents, there seems to be a clear case of discrimination against non-residents. One is left with a very strong suspicion that the Government, particularly Senator Richardson given his prime areas of expertise, is very cognisant of the fact that these people are non-voters and, therefore, are not part of a constituency that needs to be pandered to in the way that Senator Richardson, no doubt, will endeavour to do with a number of other client groups.

We express a great deal of concern about these matters. We do not understand why the Government needs to take the blind or blunt approach that it is taking. It has been suggested to me that there might be wives who automatically qualify as spouses of pensioners even though they might never have lived in the country. To the extent that that is possible, it would strike me that they probably have a very low level of entitlement. Conversely, the Government might find that there are wives who have been in this country for many years, have been active in the work force, and have paid their taxes and could, if they continued to reside in Australia, continue to receive that pension. Therefore, I wonder why-I would be interested in an explanation from the Minister in due course-there could not be some cut-off period, such as 10 years, so that if a person had been resident in the country for a substantial period then he ought to be entitled to continue to receive that pension even though he might choose to spend the rest of his life overseas. In many ways that person is probably putting less strain on community resources if he is outside the country rather than inside the country. Therefore, it does smack very much of a budgetary measure designed somehow to cut back wherever possible. I think that the Greek and Turkish communities in particular, and the ethnic communities in general, are entitled to a much fuller and franker explanation than they have had to date in this area.

This is clearly a Budget measure. It was explicitly foreshadowed in the February statement. To that extent, I think that the Government has a clear mandate for these proposals and we do not propose, therefore, to oppose them, for that reason. But we do believe that the Government does owe an explanation to the migrant communities and that it ought to have consulted much more and earlier than it has. The determination to push this issue through now smacks very much of Senator Richardson's recent election to the Expenditure Review Committee and a desire to be able to show that he has already achieved a certain level of savings which might then be able to be squandered elsewhere.

The Bill seeks to save about $75m in 1991-92 and $122m in the following financial year. Clearly, that is a measure of quite some financial significance in budgetary terms. For that reason alone, in line with our approach to Budget Bills and expenditure measures, we would not be seeking to hold the legislation up at this stage. We certainly believe that there is ample scope for an explanation about these measures on their face insofar as they affect people who have been in receipt of these benefits for a number of years. If they are suddenly to cut out after a period of 12 months, clearly that would seem to be a retrospective measure and I think, again, those persons are entitled to an explanation as to why they should suddenly be disqualified.

I think I have made it clear that the Opposition does not wish to condone any efforts on the part of those who are abusing the system; and neither do the ethnic communities which have displayed a measure of responsibility in this area and, through their spokespersons, are very anxious to ensure that only the genuinely deserving continue to benefit from the social security system. But I think that they are the overwhelming proportion. There is undoubtedly some anecdotal evidence around which reinforces people's prejudices, but the community is entitled to have a government make its decision on the basis of fact. I think we ought to be entitled to much more detail than we have to date. For example, the Government ought to address the numbers of persons that we are dealing with-some 26,000-odd-and explain simply what proportion it believes are currently rorting the system to any, and what, extent. If they are not, then we are entitled to know why there is going to be this discrimination on the ground of non-residence. Until the Government comes up with those answers, I think the ethnic communities and the community at large will continue to believe that this is a measure driven very much by Budget expedience and by a recognition that these people do not have voting rights in this country and that, therefore, their claim on government support systems will be reduced accordingly. We do not regard that as equity in any sense. The Ecumenical Migration Centre takes a similar view. It states:

These measures are particularly heartless and expose the government's access and equity policies as nothing more than misleading rhetoric. They are particularly discriminatory when compared with the government's much vaunted concern for Australian born age pensioners.

I think there is a lot of strength to that proposition. Unless the Government is able to refute it in a much more detailed and coherent manner than it has done to date, then that belief will persist in the community. I think it is incumbent upon the Minister to explain these measures in a lot more detail than he has to date, to explain what he hopes to achieve by the renegotiation of those bilateral treaties, and to justify why he needs to wander off to the Mediterranean in the not too distant future. Until we have those sorts of explanations, then I think we will be very much of the view that this Government's commitment to the genuinely needy will be overwhelmed by extraneous issues and that its commitment to a proper functioning system of social security in this country will be dominated much more by rhetoric than a serious attempt to grapple with the very difficult policy issues which underlie the present system. Therefore, I think that we do have a very good opportunity in the course of this debate to have a number of these issues put on the table for the first time by an incoming Minister.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees Sen M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —The amendments to the social security regulations are based on a number of false assumptions. Some of these are: that there are plenty of jobs out there just waiting for young people to apply for them; that basically all young people are lazy and uninterested, are not willing to work, and need some sort of punitive so-called incentives to get them out there working; that young unemployed can live more cheaply than older unemployed; that by tightening and further complicating the bureaucratic maze, young people will be more anxious to get a job; that small business, traditionally a large employer of young people, is thriving; that there are sufficient and appropriate places for young people in education and training; and that all families are willing and able to support their young people.

SPEECH.PARA: I will start with the first assumption; that is, the erroneous belief that there are plenty of jobs out there for these young people. Unemployment statistics and job vacancy figures show otherwise. Last year 46.8 per cent of unemployed females and 39.9 per cent of males were under the age of 25. In South Australia alone there are 30,000 young people looking for fewer and fewer jobs. Given the current ratio of unemployed to job vacancies, it is inevitable that many young people will be rejected time and time again, and many do simply give up and drop off the statistics table. There is simply not a job for every young unemployed person; in fact, in January this year an average of one job was available for every eight young people seeking it. In some country areas in South Australia those figures are much higher. For example, in the outer western suburbs of Sydney it is almost impossible for young people to find regular work. In the next few months, even if the landing which we are supposedly going to be experiencing economically is soft, unemployment will certainly rise and the capacity to find work will be much reduced.
I would like to look at some facts on the fundamental changes that have occurred in the labour market. This quote comes from a report written in 1988 on the young homeless allowance:

In the decade after 1974 youth unemployment rose from 5.8% to 23.3%, teenagers holding full-time positions declined by 196,000-the number of part-time positions increased by 129,700. It is major economic changes, including structural changes that have occurred in industries throughout Australia since the 70s, that have resulted in youth unemployment. More recent figures show that . . .
these are between 1983 and 1988-

full-time jobs for 15 to 18 year olds have decreased by 70,000, while in the last decade casual part-time jobs have more than doubled. In addition to the casualisation of the youth labour market, many of the types of jobs in the past filled by young people no longer exist. Specifically, unskilled and semi-skilled jobs at the bottom rung of heavy industry, retail and offices.

I will move on to the second assumption that is being made by the Government: that basically all young people are lazy, uninterested and not willing to work. This certainly has not been my experience as a teacher for the last 20 years before coming into this place. Yes, there is a small minority out there-just as, I think, we would find in any professional group in any section of the labour market-that is not particularly keen on doing anything at all. But this is a very small minority. I would argue that most of these unemployed have been long weeded out from the benefit lists after the crackdowns that have already been initiated by government. No research I could find shows that there is a vast number of young people not really keen on getting a job. They are deterred and they do give up after their continual efforts to find work are not successful, but these young people generally drop out, and off the unemployment lists.

This assumption, which is a popular myth in the community at large, places even greater stress on those unable to find work. I believe that it is the job of government, indeed the job of all of us here, to go out and publicise the facts and to support these young people who are unable to find work. In the February edition of Youth Studies, Christelle Withers-Mayne, in an article entitled `Responses to Unemployment', states:
Most writers agree that unemployment is a detrimental exercise for the majority of unemployed people.
She then goes on to quote a series of studies:

It has been found, for example, that the unemployed are more depressed and anxious (Feather 1982), have lower self-esteem (Harris 1980), have poorer psychological well-being (Hepworth 1980), poorer physical health and more life stress (Gore 1978 . . . ), a higher incidence of mental health problems (Donnovan and Oddy 1982), higher levels of apathy (Feather 1982), and that these are reflected in more negative body image and depressed appearance (Jahoda 1982).
The failure of politicians to stand up and support these teenagers further adds to this stress.

I move to the third false assumption-that is, that young people can somehow live more cheaply than the older unemployed. Young people living independently have the same general food, clothing, transport and accommodation costs as adults. Those who have no support from parents may be in a precarious financial situation. The lowering of the unemployment benefit to the Austudy level means that unemployed young people are being pushed further below the poverty line-the poverty line being $142 a week as of December last year. The Australian Democrats believe that this is unjust and that in this case the Government should have brought Austudy benefits up to at least unemployment benefit levels. In fact, the Government should be paying living costs to these young students, keeping in mind that a highly skilled and educated work force will return considerably more revenue to the Government through higher taxes in the long term, as well as greatly assisting this nation economically.

Any person, young or adult, who is denied adequate income suffers damage to his or her self-esteem as well as to his or her image in the community. It is a blinkered approach to say that people can rely on their families. In many cases, young people live with their families in grossly inadequate conditions because their families are unwilling or unable to offer more support. Again, I quote from the report on the youth homeless allowance and youth in severe economic hardship:

It is the experience of the youth housing field that large numbers of homeless young people leave home and are unable to return as a direct result of the families' low-income . . . particularly those hit by unemployment, face independence of their teenage dependants as a necessity, not a luxury or absolution of responsibility. Significant changes in the labour market, including the disappearance of full-time teenage jobs and the rise in youth unemployment, have resulted in the prolonged dependancy of working class young people. For many low-income families, including single parents, this additional financial strain is unsustainable. In addition, it is frequently the case that the housing requirements of low-income families are not being adequately met. For many, an issue as basic as over-crowding, results in the necessity of the young person to leave home.

While there are no `junior' rents, no `junior' utility charges and no `junior' food bills, I noted that Monday's Adelaide Advertiser stated that there has been an increase of some 15 per cent in rents on flats. The average rent for a flat is now more than the allowance young people are able to obtain. I understand that in Melbourne there has been an increase of some 7.1 per cent-a rise of $5 to $10 a week. This is at a time when the Government is reducing benefits to young people. The Democrats ask where the justice is in that. As for a young married couple not needing as much as an older married couple, I would argue to the contrary: at least the older couple has had the opportunity to set themselves up with the basic essentials, such as bedding and kitchen utensils.

I move to the fourth assumption-that is, that the bureaucratic maze now being further complicated, will encourage these young people to get a job. The taxation Act and Social Security Act are always before the Parliament. We debate these two areas of government administration more regularly than any others. Both have a considerable consumer base for the Government as an administration. Yet we adopt quite different administrative principles to both of these consumer bases. In taxation there is a continuing awareness of the need to simplify the Act and adopt broad principles and simple administrative guidelines. Yet in the Social Security Act there appears to be the quite opposite approach-a certain bloody-mindedness, if you like, that sees this Parliament inserting more and more its, buts and maybes which impact on the client base. I wonder how many honourable senators would pass the test if their continued income was dependent on replying to letters within a reasonable time.

Perhaps the difference in attitude lies in the simple fact that there are a raft of non-government professionals who are paid to interact with the tax Act by the client base. As a client base served by the Social Security Act generally has no money, there is not an extensive half-way house group of professionals between the Department and the client base. It is a wholly one-sided affair. I wonder how many honourable senators would get through the tax Act without their accountants. Rather than encourage the young to get a job, this burden will alienate them further and will encourage more and more to fall through the net and end up on the streets.

Fifthly, we look at where these jobs will come from, particularly those in small business as small business is not thriving. Small business has been a traditional employer of many school leavers. But, as was detailed last week in this place, very many small businesses are not in a position, owing to the current economic climate, to offer a large number of jobs to young people. Also, the work which is available now is frequently only part time and/or temporary. Although job growth has occurred in some parts of the economy, it is declining within sectors which traditionally employ teenagers. The general consensus seems to be that it will be a very hard year for undercapitalised small businesses in particular due to a reduction in domestic demand as Government policy begins to have an effect on consumption.

The sixth assumption is that there are sufficient, and appropriate, places in education and training. An article in Monday's Age shows that higher education in Australia continues to be the preserve of the nation's elite, according to a survey of students enrolling at Monash University. The offspring of top social groups are six times more likely to enrol than their schoolmates from working class homes. The segregation of the already privileged on campus remains as distorted as it has been for the last 50 years.

Already there is a considerable amount of hidden unemployment within the education system, particularly in state high schools throughout the country. More and more young people are staying on, but if a job was available, they would be gone tomorrow. Disruption and disinclination are common in many school classrooms as the underfunded education system is asked to cater for these teenagers. Additional funding for appropriate courses and appropriate counselling and support services are urgently required in all States; rather than punitive measures such as we see before us today.

The final assumption is that families are willing and able to support their young people. I quote two different statements in the Burdekin report Our Homeless Youth which sum up the situation well-firstly:
It is clear that youth unemployment is concentrated disproportionately among young people from poorer backgrounds.

The class concentration of unemployment means that a family is often multi-disadvantaged, undermining its capacity to assist unemployed children. Often one or two parents are on a benefit or a very low wage or intermittently employed.

In a study conducted in the mid-1980s, it was found that unemployment rates were much higher among teenagers of sole parent families than among other teenagers and that this was attributable mainly to their low family incomes.
Secondly, from chapter 9:
Family relationships also suffered:

the adults in the study experienced `stress created by the constant struggle to make ends meet' which `took a heavy toll on the quality of family life and relationships'; marriages were `strained to breaking point' and `relationships with children were also damaged'. While it is now generally accepted that parents of small children require community support provided in the form of child care etc.), there is little recognition that such support is needed by families with adolescent children. Sole parent families in particular need such support.
One recent study linked current economic trends to family conflict stating that high youth unemployment, along with the tendency for children to stay at school longer, means that:

. . . while maturing earlier than ever before, [children] are now often dependent on their parents for longer than used to be the case, creating another source of potential tension in family relationships.

Other studies show that access to income, housing and unemployment are directly influenced by class, gender and ethnic background. Many of these young people have all the cards stacked against them, and homelessness is often the result.

This brings me to what the Democrats believe will occur if these amendments are passed. As the only thing that really seems to matter to the Government in the current climate is money, I will first speak in purely economic terms. The results of this callous action by the Government, supported by the Liberal and National parties-in fact, given half a chance, they would increase the pressures further-will in the long term be a cost to all Australians. For example, statistics could be used to show that as the young become increasingly alienated, and as they find it impossible to feed and clothe themselves, petty crime such as shoplifting and car theft will increase. They will not starve.

While there are no formal studies, Dr Paul Wilson, Assistant Director of the Australian Institute of Criminology, gives as his extremely well-educated opinion the expectation that a lowering of the unemployment benefit for young people will lead to a higher crime rate, particularly in petty crime. The Retail Traders Association in South Australia estimates the annual loss to shoplifting now at a conservative $70m. So we can expect that amount to rise. A witness to the inquiry on youth homelessness stated:
Basically, if young people have not got any form of income you get things like housebreaks, cars being taken, stuff being taken out of cars, things as simple as that.

Kate Hannaford, who is a South Australian currently on a Churchill scholarship in the United Kingdom looking at the victims of crime and how Britain deals with its young offenders, says that street violence is strongly linked to unemployment and that Britain believes it will get worse as the country slides deeper into recession and more jobs disappear. An increasing number of youths now have no jobs. Many are confronting the reality that they may never get one.

On the question of homelessness, if the Government persists with its present policy of inadequate income support, the long-term results will be that growing numbers of young people will find themselves on the streets, and the cost of housing and looking after and caring for these young people will far outweigh any savings. The Burdekin report stated:

Inadequate incomes are forcing young people into intolerable living conditions and leaving them exposed to ill-health, abuse, exploitation and often death, either on the streets if they decide to leave home regardless or are evicted, or in abusive families if they decide to stay in the family home.
One witness to the inquiry stated:

Without adequate income, young people have no choice regarding their housing and consequently are forced to remain in intolerable living situations where they are subject to family conflict and domestic violence.

One of the recommendations of the inquiry was that the total benefit paid to a homeless young person be equivalent to the adult unemployment benefit. If we do not allow young people an adequate amount to feed and shelter themselves we will surely ultimately be paying. Whether the amount is for a night in hospital, gaol or a psychiatric institution, we will be paying a lot more than the unemployment benefit.

The social cost is incalculable. The ultimate expression of disenchantment may well be suicide, and the rate of suicide among our young people is unacceptably high. On the question of increased disenchantment, the O'Keefe report, a report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Community Affairs, raised a number of concerns about the accessibility of social security. The harsh measures of the last three years have led to a different culture and an unpleasant attitude in regional areas. Clients are now fearful, in some cases almost to the point of being paranoid, about having to continually confront staff; and staff attitudes have undergone a change as staff themselves are placed under greater pressure.

Unemployment beneficiaries and sole parents are seen as second-class citizens in the realm of social security. They have been targeted quite unfairly and it smacks of government by opinion poll. The recent $2 increase did not flow on to unemployment beneficiaries, which means that the gap between the single over 21 pension and the single unemployment benefit is now $11.80-not much less than at the end of the Fraser years-which flies in the face of the Government's commitment to remove the difference.

The legislation has no carrots but lots of sticks. The sticks hit wide of the mark. Increased penalties for non-compliance with departmental rules will simply not address this problem. The Government would do well to increase its emotional support services dramatically to overcome these problems, letting social workers do what they were trained for rather than writing forms and double-checking everything. `I'd like to help you but I can't' seems to be quite common.

Overall, the amendments to this Bill will result in a social cost to the community which will be immeasurable in two senses. First, it will be devastating on the families and individuals directly concerned and on the families that they will have in generations to come; and, secondly, it will be felt widely. Perhaps then, at last, if it is felt so widely in the community, people will be able to see the need for us to support our young.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

ANSWER.PARA: This morning the Prime Minister referred to the campaign by the IRA against innocent people, whether British citizens or not, and condemned it without qualification. —I draw the attention of the Minister representing the Treasurer to the fact that today's official statistics show that the March quarter provided the third consecutive quarterly decline in new capital expenditure in Australia, that the major factor in this was a 10 per cent seasonally adjusted fall in new equipment, that forecasts for the current financial year are already significantly lower than those derived from the December 1989 survey, and that the forecast for the next year is a decline of 4 per cent. How is Australia going to trade itself out of this economic crisis by increasing its exports if this Government's economic policies, particularly massively high interest rates, continue to discourage new business investment?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am happy to comment on the investment figures which were released today and I will do so in a moment. These figures come out one by one, day by day, series by series. If Senator Watson had looked at the figures published earlier this week they would have indicated to him that, on the basis of the investment which took place in calendar years 1988 and 1989 particularly, there has been a 10 per cent increase in the productive capacity in this country following those investment figures. That must be regarded as good news.

ANSWER.PARA: If one goes to the figures which Senator Watson refers to, it is true that there was an investment decline of 4.3 per cent in the March quarter in real terms which followed a 4 per cent decline in the December quarter. That was not entirely unanticipated by the Government. In fact, the Treasurer, other Ministers and I have made comments indicating that that was to some extent anticipated.

However, the data is not all negative, as the Opposition might wish to imply. For example, manufacturing investment was little changed over the March quarter from the record level in the previous quarter, and that is encouraging. Manufacturing investment expectations for the June quarter are still healthy. There is some increase expected and, even with the recent decline, investment as a share of gross domestic product will be well above 12 per cent compared with the average of the last five or so years of about 11 per cent.

The growth in investment over the last few years has also been encouraging. It is considerably higher than the very low growth rates in investment experienced during the 1970s when, as I recall, the figure was about 2.8 per cent a year.

The declines in the March quarter figures and, indeed, the December quarter figures are from a very high base. As the Treasurer and other Ministers have said on a number of occasions, that base in the last two calendar years was at an unsustainable level if one looked at the impact on the current account deficit of the imports of capital equipment.

As Senator Watson well knows, monetary policy and fiscal policy were designed to decrease domestic demand, one component of which is, of course, investment. As I said a minute ago, that does not mean that that slowdown in investment is undermining the economy's capacity to produce more for both the domestic and export markets. As I said earlier, the growth in productive capacity as a result of that recent investment boom has been in the order of 10 per cent.

The impact of the increased capital stock over the last two years and the slowdown in investment resulting from monetary and fiscal policy can, I believe, be seen in recent trending improvements in the current account deficit which was referred to at Question Time yesterday.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support. The Government has often stressed the importance to the waterfront reform process of improved port efficiency. Will the Minister inform the Senate of progress by State and Northern Territory governments in this area?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —This question is topical because of the Australian Transport Advisory Council (ATAC) meeting of transport Ministers that was held in Perth last Friday. When the Inter-state Commission brought down its report on efficiency gains that were possible on the waterfront in Australia, it stressed that the productivity increases that were available on the waterfront were as great in that area under the control of State governments-that is, port authorities-as were the productivity gains that were available by any initiatives that the Commonwealth may introduce. Port authorities employ around 8,500 employees in Australia, which is about the equivalent of the number employed on the waterfront, and the revenues, approaching $1 billion a year, are also equivalent to the revenues generated by the waterfront itself. It is absolutely essential that if real productivity increases are to be gained across the whole area of the waterfront the cooperation of the States is necessary.

ANSWER.PARA: The Inter-State Commission in fact identified the areas where port authorities needed to apply some changes. They were establishing appropriate corporate charters for port authorities with full public accountability requirements, setting port authorities appropriate financial targets, ensuring that port authority boards had a high level of business management expertise, making port authorities more responsive to user requirements and making port authority pricing more closely related to costs. It has been evident in recent times that a number of the larger port authorities in Australia, principally at the ports of Melbourne and Sydney, are moving to do this.

All State and Commonwealth Ministers agreed last August to pursue these reform goals. Last Friday in Perth at the meeting of ATAC there was a detailed review of progress to date. It was a very amicable and positive discussion across the board with all of the Ministers, and the Ministers agreed that waterfront reform-that is, at the port authority level-will now become a standing agenda item at ATAC meetings, obliging the States to report progress in this area.

The State Ministers agree to develop and publicise their plans for port progress and timetables for reform of the port authorities in line with the Inter-State Commission's recommendations. The Ministers also agreed that a working party of officials convened by the Commonwealth will develop port performance indicators to make the reports to ATAC meaningful and examine other issues associated with achieving more competitive commercial environments in the ports. This working party, which will be convened by the Commonwealth as soon as possible, will include, by agreement, officers from the Commonwealth Trade Practices Commission and the Prices Surveillance Authority. State Ministers also supported the proposals being developed by the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) for union amalgamation in the waterfront and shipping sectors. The agreements reached in Perth last Friday are an important step towards the development of more efficient labour arrangements in the maritime industry.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: NATIONAL OCCUPATIONAL HEALTH AND SAFETY RESEARCH TRUST FUND

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Industrial Relations to the National Occupational Health and Safety Research Trust Fund set up in 1985 to investigate health and safety problems in the workplace. Can the Minister advise the Senate what progress has been achieved by the trust fund since then? In particular, how many projects has it financed and what kinds of activities have been funded this year?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The trust fund, as Senator Aulich's question implies, was set up in 1985 under the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission Act to fund research projects relevant to occupational health and safety. It was given a one-off grant of $3m for this purpose. It was up and running and functioning in 1986 and funded 57 research projects, including eight in 1990 on work related cancer and skin disorders.

ANSWER.PARA: Three of those grants were in New South Wales, one to a project of the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation Division of Fuel Technology in New South Wales for research into exposure to the chemical moca used in plastics manufacture; another to the Department of Public Health at the University of Sydney for a project related to skin problems and problems in the wearing of safety footwear; and another to the Skin and Cancer Foundation in Sydney for research into work-related dermatitis.

Three were in Victoria: one went to the Skin and Cancer Foundation for research into skin problems in the building industry; another went to the Operative Painters and Decorators Union of Australia for research into skin problems with paint trades; and one went to Gibson Chemicals Industries Ltd, Victoria, for research into work-related dermatitis. As well, in South Australia there were two: one went to the Adelaide University for research into occupational cancer; the other went to Flinders University for the monitoring of people working on cytotoxic drugs.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications aware of an article in today's edition of the Age reporting a serious near miss involving Ansett Boeing 737 and 767 aircraft and an Australian Airlines 737 aircraft yesterday morning near Melbourne? Can the Minister inform the Senate about this incident?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did read that article with some degree of alarm. I am, in fact, familiar with articles of a similar kind written by this particular journalist during the Australian Federation of Air Pilots dispute last year. But I was alarmed to see two references in the article to the effect that the aircraft had come within 900 metres of each other. That statement is, in fact, nonsense. A source close to the incident was quoted. I have been in touch with a far more reliable source, the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation (BASI), and it appears that the closest the two aircraft came to each other was, in fact, 15 kilometres. There is just a slight difference
—Wasn't there a second aircraft, and that was 15 kilometres away?

—No. Wait, and all will be revealed. I am not suggesting that the incident that did occur was not serious-all incidents of this kind are treated seriously. Indeed, in accordance with normal practice, the crew of the Ansett jet have been stood down pending an investigation by BASI. That does not necessarily imply any fault on their part.

—That is the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation-it is the decade of the acronym. What happened was that an Ansett B737 jet was cleared to descend to 23,000 feet and go into a holding pattern at Eildon Weir near Melbourne. A 767 jet, also an Ansett aircraft, was at 22,000 feet also in a holding pattern and considerably below both of those aircraft was an Australian Airlines jet in a holding pattern at 17,000 feet over Eildon Weir. I simply state that to demonstrate that, in fact, this incident involved only two aircraft and not the third, as there was a distance of 4,000 feet between the 737 jet when it finally did descend and the Australian Airlines jet, which was not involved in the incident at all.

ANSWER.PARA: What happened was that the aircraft did in fact descend to 21,000 feet. It descended below the level that it was cleared to descend to by air traffic control, therefore warranting the action taken against the crew. It was in full visual contact with the Ansett 767, and the pilots of the 737 had it in sight at all times. Perhaps it was the sight of that aircraft that alerted them to the fact that they had descended below the approved height. But at no point in time were the two aircraft anywhere near 900 metres apart. In fact, at no stage was there a breakdown in the separation of the two aircraft. The third aircraft, as I say, at 17,000 feet, was not involved in the incident at all.

The Bureau of Air Safety Investigation is currently investigating why the aircraft descended below the height that it was ordered to descend to by air traffic control and a report will be made available to me in due course.

This code recommends a minimum illumination of 400 lux for routine office work such as typing, filing, reading, writing, inquiry counters and the like. Because of the dismal lighting during the public hearings of Estimates Committee E in Senate committee room 16, I asked officers of the Senate to test the lighting in this committee room on 16 May.
