—I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications whether Mr Beazley said on the Walsh Report last Sunday that the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal (ABT) would have to decide whether non-voting shares are subject to the ownership provisions of the Broadcasting Act, thereby implying that this might be a way of extending the 20 per cent limit on foreign ownership. Did the Minister subsequently authorise or approve of his spokeswoman telling the Australian Financial Review that the Minister had been `confused' and should not have suggested that the Tribunal might consider non-voting shares as quasi-equity? How did this confusion arise? Was it merely a function of incompetence or was it a result of belated recognition that tighter controls are not necessary because the ABT already possesses adequate power to intervene in respect of any level of foreign ownership?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I assume that this question was not asked yesterday because of incompetence. I assume that it was only the headline in today's Australian Financial Review pointing it out that provoked Senator Alston to ask the question. A picture had to be drawn for him. The Government will be introducing legislation into the Parliament which will set an absolute limit on foreign ownership in Australian licensee television channels at 20 per cent. The Government believes that it is vital that Australia's radio and television stations are owned and controlled by Australians. Therefore, the question of equity is very important in this regard.

ANSWER.PARA: On the question of non-voting shares or quasi-equity, non-voting shares are shareholding interests for the purpose of ownership and control under the Broadcasting Act. They will be included when calculating the aggregate level of foreign investment in any Australian broadcaster. That is the situation with the current Act and the amending Bill will not change that. Quasi-equity, that is, convertible securities, are loans which give a right of conversion to a shareholding interest on predetermined conditions. The Broadcasting Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1990 will delete that requirement for approval of loan interests because they would not normally confer control, unless, however, the option to convert them into shares is exercised. If that option is exercised, it will come under the provisions of the Act, preventing that shareholding to be beyond 20 per cent. The Act bans foreign control of Australian broadcasters. The Australian Broadcasting Tribunal has the power to investigate any arrangement, including loan agreements, that is, convertible securities, which changes the actual control of an Australian broadcaster.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I acknowledge the Minister's ability to read a brief, but I am not so sure about his ability to comprehend questions of incompetence. I asked why Mr Beazley said what he said on the Walsh Report and why he authorised his spokesperson to say that he had been confused and had got it wrong.
—He would not know whether the Minister--
—I am asking whether he did approve. That was part of the question. If the Minister would purport to answer any part of that question, then we might have a better idea of what incompetence means.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would not need a brief to determine Senator Alston's incompetence. I do not know at first hand what any spokesperson for Mr Beazley said to the press or why that person was authorised to do so. I suggest that Mr Beazley could answer that question. I am happy to communicate with Mr Beazley. I was interested in the substantive matters that were canvassed in the press.
—So are we. We want people to get it right the first time around.

—I must say in response to that interjection that in light of Mr Brown complaining severely just the other day about the restrictions being placed on foreign equity in Australian television licences it was interesting to see that, in his comments in the paper yesterday, he is now complaining that Mr Beazley is freeing the matter up to allow more foreign equity in television stations. Perhaps it would be timely for the Opposition to work out what its position on this matter is.

ANSWER.PARA: The position the Government has adopted on this is clear enough. There will be an absolute limit of 20 per cent in terms of foreign ownership in Australian television licensee stations in Australia. That will also include non-voting shares which are included in this category already under the Broadcasting Act. The amendments the Government is introducing will not change that situation.

In respect of any other loan arrangements, that is, negotiable securities that might be entered into, the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal has the power to investigate all of those arrangements to determine whether there is a degree of control exercised by the arrangements.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Has the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission conducted a study into work-related fatalities in Australian industry? Has the Commission analysed the results of the study? Can the Minister advise the Senate whether the Commission has been able to undertake any activities which address problems identified in the study?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the first part of that question is yes, it did, over three years from 1982 to 1984. It had access to coroners' reports and findings in terms of fatalities at work in order to carry out its study. It found, depressingly, that 1,738 work-related deaths had occurred in that period. Of those, 1,544 were in the civilian labour force, and of those 1,278, or 83 per cent, occurred during working hours; 266 occurred when going to or from work. Fifty-two were either in the armed forces or in the category under the age of 15 years. Eighty-seven were during unpaid domestic or community work, including voluntary firefighting, and 48 bystanders died in work-related accidents in that period, mostly on farms or in rural communities.

ANSWER.PARA: The other significant findings of the survey were that mining and quarrying workers were nearly nine times more likely to be killed at work than other workers. They had 70 deaths per 100,000 employees per year in their industry. That contrasts with the next worst category, transport, where 38 workers per 100,000 employees per year died, and the rural industries category where 22 workers per 100,000 employees per year died. The rural category includes forestry, which is also a very dangerous occupation.

Many of these problems can be addressed only be cooperation between the Commonwealth and the States. That issue was canvassed at some length last Friday in New Zealand at the Australian Ministers for Labour Advisory Council. I am confident that there will be much greater attention to lowering the level of work-related fatalities as a consequence of some measures put in place there.

The National Occupational Health and Safety Commission has as well undertaken several activities in its own right. This includes reconstituting the mining industry standing committee which has responsibility in this area and working with the Joint Coal Board in New South Wales and Queensland on epidemiological monitoring of the entire New South Wales coalmining work force and to detect and control work-related hazards.

In Western Australia, the Western Australian Iron Ore Industry Consultative Council is doing similar work. There is in place now a system of surveillance for work-related fatalities throughout the Commonwealth. Mr Kerin and I oversee a program in rural communities called Farmsafe and the Occupational Health and Safety Commission is making funds available in forestry to raise the level of safety consciousness. Minister Bob Brown is urging better safety standards and the elimination of black spots on roads to lower the level of fatalities in the transport sector. There is a long way to go. It is a difficult problem but the steps are in hand to deal with it.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications. Does the Government support the moves within the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) which have been supported by the Managing Director, Mr David Hill, to axe locally produced ABC weekend television news bulletins? Does the Government recognise that such a decision would ensure that regional centres such as Tasmania would be denied local news during the weekend period? Should the ABC Board decide to accept Mr Hill's views on this matter and abandon regional centres, is the Government prepared to overrule his decision?

—It is not a matter for the Government to politically interfere with programming decisions of the ABC. The constant cries we get from the Opposition to do this amaze me. It is not a position it is particularly consistent about. It depends on the issue involved at the time. The matter has raised considerable public concern. I have read a lot of press reports about it. The position seems to be fairly clear on both sides. Management is considering a rationalisation of weekend news bulletins providing for a national bulletin-not a Sydney bulletin-of news taken from ABC corres- pondents right around Australia.
—A Sydney bulletin.
—Not a Sydney bulletin, a national bulletin.
—It will just have Sydney fires in it.

—There is nothing like having a few mates on the front bench. I thank my fellow senators for their assistance. They are a big help. I am simply reiterating what has appeared in press reports. There is no question but that the management of the ABC is proposing to do this--
—Answer the question.

—Perhaps my colleagues would allow me to continue. But the matter is to be considered by the ABC board tomorrow. That is the proper place for a decision to be made. I have no doubt that the board of the ABC-which is responsible for making this decision, not the Government-will take into account the protests of the Australian Journalists Association and the feedback it has had from the community. The feedback from that section of the community respresented by honourable senators here no doubt will also be taken into account. The proper place for this decision to be made is the ABC board. That is where the decision will be made, or not made, tomorrow.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. It relates to the reference in the Governor-General's Speech at the opening of Parliament to a campaign to eliminate the introduced plant mimosa pigra from the wetlands of the Northern Territories. What action is planned to rid northern Australia of this damaging weed invasion, particularly in the Kakadu National Park area?
—Yes, what are you doing about it?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I knew this matter would be of particular interest to Senator Collins as he comes from the Northern Territory. Senator Zakharov has had an abiding interest in Kakadu for a long time. Mimosa pigra has now overrun more than 750 square kilometres of wetlands in the Northern Territory since its introduction in the mid-1970s. This shows that it has a phenomenal potential to double the size of its infestation every year. Areas, once infested, become very different ecosystems from those which existed before. We now have a real problem right across the Northern Territory, and in Kakadu the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service is now spending an awful lot of time and money in attempting, by hand, to halt the march of this weed.

ANSWER.PARA: As the Prime Minister announced during the election campaign and as stated in the Governor-General's Speech, we are now sitting down with the Government of the Northern Territory to look at a proposal for a joint strategy for halting the march of mimosa pigra. Under normal circumstances, weed control is a State, Territory or local government issue. But given the national significance of this one, I think it will require Commonwealth assistance and intervention.

It is worth noting that already mimosa pigra has had a serious effect on the Aboriginal way of life in a number of areas and on water resources generally. Its potential threat to primary production is probably greater than anything since prickly pear. We have already discussed with the Northern Territory Government program alternatives including the aerial release of herbicides, labour-intensive ground control, and research into effective chemical use in controlling mimosa and an accelerated research program into biological controls.

The Commonwealth will be allocating $1.25m over the next three years so that the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation can continue that research into biological controls. Hopefully that will produce some results. In the meantime, during the next year the Commonwealth will spend just on $1m in attempting to control mimosa pigra, mainly by some aerial application and utilisation of hand labour from the National Parks and Wildlife Service. We hope that the two-pronged attack of trying to hold mimosa pigra's march on the ground now and a three-year program to look at biological control might provide some answers.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN DEFENCE FORCE: EXPOSURE TO ASBESTOS

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Defence. Given that many members of the Army have been exposed to asbestos-for example, soldiers have trained for the last 10 years at the old Townsville power plant, where there is free-floating asbestos; thousands of soldiers moved to and from Vietnam and trained in the aircraft carrier HMAS Sydney, which is notorious for its asbestos hazard; and many soldiers live and work in very old buildings that are potentially dangerous in terms of asbestos-and that the Army `has not, is not and does not intend to conduct any studies into asbestos-related diseases because these have not been considered necessary', will the Minister insist that such studies be undertaken as a matter of urgency, however small the risk, so that potential sufferers may be identified?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Newman has drawn attention to a position that has existed for a number of years regarding asbestos. It is most unsatisfactory. Whilst the problem is not strictly confined to the defence forces-it is a major problem in Canberra too-it is a specific concern in a variety of areas of the defence forces, but particularly in the Royal Australian Navy because of the way in which asbestos was used. It is also a problem in one of the training areas in Townsville, to which our attention was drawn one or two years ago. Action has been taken there.

ANSWER.PARA: There have been calls for inquiries. Senator Newman may be confusing inquiries with studies. It will be essential that the defence forces study the problem. I reiterate the statement which Mr Bilney made on PM last Friday night that any servicemen and ex-servicemen who think that they may have been affected should, for heaven's sake, be checked now so that they can clear up in their own minds whether they have any health problems. At this stage, there is nothing to stop any studies into the problem. Minister Bilney will be looking at that. On the other hand, we have not yet seen a good enough reason for a general public inquiry at this stage. A study into the matter has not been ruled out. Following Senator Newman's question today, again I will draw the matter to Mr Bilney's attention. I might write to Senator Newman on it later this week if I hear of any decision from him.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for his answer, but I draw his attention to the fact that in my question I said that the Army `has not, is not and does not intend to conduct any studies into asbestos-related diseases because these have not been considered necessary'. In fact, that statement is a direct quotation from the Army's answer to a question I asked in the Senate Estimates Committee. Even if the risk is considered to be small, I am concerned about it and believe we should be trying urgently to identify the sufferers. When the Army gave me that answer, it already knew about some of the things that I detailed earlier in the question. In light of the Army's approach, will the Minister see that something is done in terms of changing its attitude to such studies.

—I recall the answer given. No doubt, that was an Army view at the time. Fortunately, in the Westminster system the relevant Minister makes the decision. Senator Newman can be assured that Minister Bilney is on a very sharp learning curve with regard to this. Asbestos has been a problem for quite a while, but, obviously, it has been highlighted by certain tragic events of last week. I reiterate that I will talk to Minister Bilney later this week and give Senator Newman a written response as to what his intentions are, specifically in relation to the Army.

—My question is also addressed to the Minister for Defence. In light of the fact that last year the Australian Defence Force (ADF), apparently, was spending up to $1,200 on advertising to attract each new recruit in the Royal Australian Air Force, and a little less for recruits in the Royal Australian Navy and the Australian Army, I ask the Minister whether there has been an evaluation of this highly expensive advertising campaign given that there appears to be an equally expensive advertising campaign this year. Further, what is the point of all this advertising while there are continuing resignations from the ADF and it is likely that recommendations will be made that the size of the ADF be reduced and greater emphasis placed on the reserves. Finally, I ask the Minister whether the recent military displays, involving helicopters and hand-to-hand combat, at the Sydney Easter Show and the State of Origin match in Sydney, were part of a push to glamorise a career in the armed forces and whether the cost of this kind of display is being met by the taxpayer at a time when the ADF claims to be drastically short of money for day-to-day functioning and personnel needs?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —An internal Defence Force recruiting evaluation is under way to ensure that Defence Force recruiting is effective and fulfilling its role. The review, which is being undertaken by the Inspector-General, will be about the extent to which recruiting is appropriate, effective and efficient. We recognise that recruiting for the Defence Force is getting more difficult. Therefore, we need to focus on how to do it better.

ANSWER.PARA: The whole point of advertising is to attract recruits for both the regular and reserve elements of the Defence Force. That process is required because the Defence Force needs, on a 10-year average, some 8,000 new recruits each year for regular elements of the Defence Force. Recruit advertising tries to show the attractiveness of a career in the Defence Force. Whilst it does not shirk the warlike nature of the Services, it does not seek to glamorise war. Military displays such as that provided for the recent State of Origin match in Sydney simply show members of the Australian defence forces doing their jobs. That should never be described as glamorising war.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Acting Prime Minister, Senator Button. Is it not a fact that the wool industry submission to the Government shows that, by holding the floor price at its current level, over the next five to six years the contribution to the national economy from wool export earnings will be $3 billion more than under a 700c floor? Is it not also a fact that under the industry's proposals, this increase in national income would be achieved without any direct financial assistance from the Government? Under such circumstances, whose interest is the Government trying to serve by demanding that the floor price be cut? What is the justification for deliberately wanting to reduce the value of our most important export earning commodity which in April alone earned $360m?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not analysed the proposals by the wool industry. One has to be something of a Rhodes scholar to do so because there are so many proposals floating around from the wool industry, although I can see that there is a basic position which seems to have been adopted by the National Party and which was argued by Senator Boswell, the Opposition's leader without portfolio, in the Senate yesterday at Question Time and rejected by the Leader of the Liberal Party last night.

ANSWER.PARA: Having said that, I merely reiterate that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has been conducting a series of meetings with the wool industry about this matter. He has indicated his views to it-views which I understand to be shared by most people in this chamber. Those views will be communicated yet again and discussed with the industry I think again today. They will be considered by the Minister in conjunction with Cabinet tomorrow. Following that, an announcement presumably will be made.

Senator Bjelke-Petersen referred to the value of the wool crop. As I said yesterday, the wool crop is of immense value to Australia, but that part of the wool crop which is sitting in stores is of no value to Australia at all-it is costing Australia a lot of money. It is that part which the Minister is particularly concerned about. So I have nothing to add to what I said yesterday; indeed, I have nothing to add to what Dr Hewson said last night.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health whether he is aware of recent research in Great Britain which showed a substantial increase in the leukaemia rate among the children of men who have worked at the British nuclear fuels facility at Sellafield and at other British nuclear establishments? Is the Minister aware that the levels of radiation to which these workers were exposed were very low in relation to the standards which are held internationally and in Australia? What steps is the Minister taking to review the allowable level of radiation exposure? Is this recent British study being taken into account, and how advanced is any review?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that a recent paper published in the respected British Medical Journal reports an association between an increased incidence of childhood leukaemia and the radiation exposure of the fathers of the children who were employed at the Sellafield nuclear reprocessing facility.

ANSWER.PARA: The study found that children whose fathers were exposed to the highest levels of external radiation-either a total dose of 100 millisieverts, typically accumulated over six to seven years, or a dose of 10 millisieverts in the six months before conception-were six to eight times more likely to develop leukaemia than control cases. The currently internationally accepted limit for exposure of radiation workers is 50 millisierverts per year.

I am advised that the outcome of the study is a matter of some controversy and discussion in the scientific community. It needs to be emphasised that further work needs to be done. The numbers involved in the Sellafield study were very small-just four cases with fathers who have received the high doses-and the evidence from the Japanese bomb survivors does not support the hypothesis linking paternal radiation dose to incidence of childhood leukaemia. Nevertheless, the Sellafield results are important and, if confirmed, would have a most important impact on radiation protection standards.

Australia, along with the rest of the world, is already reviewing its radiation protection standards in the light of the current data on the radiation exposure suffered by, and the subsequent cancer incidence in, the atomic bomb survivors. The International Commission on Radiological Protection is revising the internationally accepted recommendations and the revision can be expected to involve a reduction to around 40 per cent of the current limits. When this revision is completed, the National Health and Medical Research Council will move quickly to change Australian standards. In the meantime, it has issued guidance drawing attention to the likely revision and reminding users of their responsibility to keep exposures as low as is reasonably achievable.

Should further research arising from the Sellafield results indicate that there is a need for further revision of limits, or of changes to employment practices, I would expect the National Health and Medical Research Council to act quickly to promulgate new advice.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The Minister said that the Sellafield results show something in the region of 100 to 120 millisieverts in total over a period of six or seven years access to radiation exposure. In view of the fact that at Roxby Downs the workers are exposed to 15 millisieverts per year-that is, over a period of something like eight years they would be exposed to the same degree-is the current review also taking that into consideration, bearing in mind that some workers would be getting close to that amount?

—I think it has been indicated that the Sellafield study is subject to some controversy as to the true implications of such a small number-four cases-of fathers who had received the high doses. Whether we can extrapolate from those a sound scientific conclusion is itself a matter of controversy. I am quite sure that, in the light of the review of standards around the world, the National Health and Medical Research Council will move very quickly to ensure that adequate and sensible standards are promulgated in such a way that those involved in work in Australia which would expose them to radiation would be protected. I am sure that that will be undertaken in as speedy a way as is compatible with getting the best scientific advice.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Last week I asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade a question about the rights of Palestinians who were resident in what is now Israel at the time of the United Nations (UN) partition of Palestine in 1947, but who fled or were forced out in the subsequent fighting. I asked about their right to return to Israel if they so choose, and their right to the property they left behind when they fled or were forced out. The Minister replied, in effect, that they had undoubted rights to both, but that such rights were unenforceable in the face of Israeli intransigence. I now ask the Minister representing Senator Evans a related question. What is Australia's attitude to the request by the Palestinians for a UN presence in occupied Palestine to ensure that the Palestinians living there are treated fairly by the occupying power? What is Australia's attitude to the Palestinian request?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Government has always taken a very consistently even-handed attitude to these almost irresolvable disputes in the Middle East. It is somewhat pleasing to see that the situation in Israel and the occupied territories has quietened somewhat from the violence of last week, but it would also be true to say that tensions remain very high.

ANSWER.PARA: At the United Nations Security Council in Geneva last Friday and Saturday, the Palestine Liberation Organisation Chairman, Yasser Arafat, suggested that it was time to have a UN fact-finding tour to Israel. The idea will continue to be discussed in New York today and probably tomorrow and some conclusion drawn.

It is our understanding that the Israeli Government is opposed to the idea of UN observers being permanently based in the occupied territory and might not even accept a fact-finding mission of the type discussed by the Security Council. The attitude of the Australian Government is that we want to encourage Israel to consider such suggestions positively as a means of reducing tension in the region. DEBATE.TITLE: OPERATIONS OF THE REGISTERED HEALTH INSURANCE ORGANISATIONS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

In speaking to the annual report 1988-89 on the operations of the registered health insurance organisations, I wish firstly to make the point that the majority of registered health insurance organisations operate their health funds on a non-profit basis. Any surpluses which the organisation accrues remain in the business and are used to benefit contributors. In this way the health insurance industry plays a vital role in ensuring the access of Australians to health care at a reasonable cost.

It is a regrettable fact of life as we have come to know it under the Hawke Labor Government that our health care networks are facing an increasing state of chaos. Throughout the nation public hospitals have waiting lists which grow daily. The Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, promised in February of 1983 that nine out of 10 Australians would be better off under Medicare. How very wrong, once again, he has proven to be. The facts are that most people are far worse off. Waiting lists for public hospitals, which were once counted in the tens of thousands, are now calculated by the hundreds of thousands. Not a week goes by when we do not hear of public hospital beds closing, deficits and ever-increasing demands for rapidly diminishing resources. It is interesting to note that even the Prime Minister voted with his feet and trotted off to a private hospital for the small operation that he had recently.

At the same time, because Labor's health policies have discouraged private health insurance, private hospitals find themselves with empty beds, financial problems and, in most cases, the under-utilisation of their excellent facilities. This situation is a sad indictment of the Government and of the operation of the Medicare system.

The one per cent income tax Medicare levy was introduced in February 1984. In July of 1985, just 17 months after the scheme was first introduced, the Government saw fit to remove the Medicare levy limit, and in December of 1986 Mr Hawke broke his November 1984 election promise not to increase the Medicare levy, by raising it from one per cent to 1.25 per cent. The problem is that this ad hoc approach to health by the Government has served seriously to disadvantage an important component of our health care system-that of private health insurance. As a result, perhaps not at all surprisingly, some health insurance funds are facing a crisis which, if not resolved, threatens their future viability.

In 1983, 62 per cent of the population contributed to private health insurance funds. Today that number has dwindled to 45 per cent and continues to fall at the rate of around 2 per cent per annum. The point that the Federal Government has missed on this issue is that a drop of just one per cent in the number of contributors imposes on the State governments an additional $100m a year in hospital costs. If this trend continues at the present rate, by 1995 the additional cost to the Government will be $1 billion per annum and that figure does not take into account the rising costs caused by inflation. In other words, the Government's apparent failure to see the writing on the wall is destined to result in another huge bill being passed on to the taxpayer.

When this issue was examined from a practical point of view in my own State of Tasmania we found that over 20 per cent of public hospital beds are currently occupied by insured patients, generally because of a lack of understanding of Medicare and the lack of any financial alternative. Private hospitals have occupancy rates of 65 per cent while waiting lists in public hospitals grow longer. This is a tragic waste of resources and could have potentially fatal consequences for those awaiting urgent surgery. Even a smaller transfer of patients from the public to the private system would provide immediate benefits for taxpayers, the Government, and health care generally within this country.

Quite simply, the Government has turned its back on the private system at a time when it is more than capable of picking up some of the present surplus. A return of Commonwealth support for these funds would help to stem the loss of contributors by lowering contribution rates. As an example, an inflow of $400m from the Federal Government would reduce basic contributions by 25 per cent. I know that in Tasmania there has also been some discussion regarding the concept of giving very low priority to privately insured patients using public hospitals for certain specified procedures which could just as adequately be performed in private hospitals. There has also been consideration of the wisdom, or otherwise, of queue jumping by insured patients in private hospitals. In addition, the concept of charging a facility fee for specialists treating private patients in public hospitals is also being examined.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON INDUSTRY, SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Childs Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I table the report of the Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology entitled New Management Techniques in Manufacturing Industry-People and Technology, together with the transcript of evidence.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

This report highlights the serious problems facing manufacturing industry in Australia. It is a report aimed at improving productivity in the manufacturing sector. Not to do so will see Australia's living standards decline. The manufacturing sector is a vital element in the Australian economy. A chilling reminder of its importance was provided in evidence to the Committee when we were told that all the `successful' economies were supported by strong and efficient manufacturing sectors. Unfortunately, relatively Australia is not one of those economies with a strong manufacturing base. Indeed, in 1988-89 Australia had a manufacturing trade deficit of $19.9 billion. In that year manufactured imports comprised 72 per cent of total imports.

Without wishing to sound too alarmist, it is imperative to lift productivity levels to the point where Australian manufacturers can compete on world markets or can produce goods which are a viable alternative within Australia to imported products. The Committee's findings are that this is possible. We have looked closely at the techniques employed by other successful manufacturing nations and set out the facts about the so-called `secrets' of their success in this report. I say so-called because they are not secrets at all. They are sensible management practices making the best use of technology but, more importantly, making the best use of human resources. It is this combination that is the secret to productivity increases.
Industry, Science and Technology

In this report the Committee is promoting the concept of new management techniques. As defined in our report, the term covers the best use of technology combined with human resource practices that maximise skills, commitment and performance. Following extensive hearings and factory inspections it is disappointing to have to report that only a handful of companies in Australia have adopted such practices and could be termed `world-class'. More heartening is the fact that many companies are now recognising the need for improvement in their approach. It is the Committee's aim to increase that awareness and to ensure that they are able to obtain the assistance needed to change. For those companies who have not contemplated the need for change, I ask them to examine their staff turnover levels and rates of absenteeism for these are often direct indicators of poor management practice.

The report specifies a number of ways in which structures can be changed to create a greater feeling of common purpose among employees and employers alike. Common purpose will require a shared commitment to agreed corporate goals. This involvement, combined with responsibility for achievement, access to the latest technologies and training in their use, will lead to increased productivity and profitability.

The report places a heavy emphasis on the issue of productivity. The argument is often advanced that through productivity increases Australian manufacturers will achieve greater export sales and hence turn around our balance of payments problems. This view is somewhat simplistic, as other factors such as distance from markets and the small size of Australia's domestic market will affect the level of exports. However, Australian firms need to increase productivity just to survive on the domestic market, particularly in competition with overseas imports. This issue is further complicated by the practices of other trading nations who provide various forms of assistance to their exporters. This is of great concern to Australian manufacturers as we move towards a freer trade position.

The Committee is aware of this dilemma and the calls to tilt the playing field. We have not addressed that issue in this report but rather focused on the matters within the control of manufacturers. As set out in our report, the scope for improvement at the factory level is great. If improvements can be made at the micro level, they will also be felt in the national figures.

The focus for raising awareness is a series of conferences at national and State level aimed at developing an Australian model for new management techniques. The conferences will bring together manufacturers, industry experts, government agencies, peak bodies and others who are able to highlight action for change. The emphasis on selection of conference participants will initially be directed to those manufacturers and others who have already demonstrated a commitment to introducing new management techniques.

In addition to raising awareness of the matters discussed in the report, the conference will work on developing an Australian model for new management techniques. The conferences should also serve to emphasise the importance of the manufacturing sector to the Australian economy. The need for this recognition was a finding of the Committee's 1988 report Manufacturing Industry Revitalisation, and the Committee's approach in this report has been to focus on raising awareness through the conference process. The conferences must be an ongoing process with emphasis on practical solutions and case studies of successful implementation.

The report itself contains much specific information as to steps that should be taken, steps that have been proven effective by our overseas competitors. It details assistance that is currently available to industries to undertake the changes necessary to adopt new management techniques. Indeed, the range of bodies offering such assistance is a problem in itself. There is a confusing interrelationship between the many organisations and consultancy firms claiming to be able to provide support. When the Committee put itself in the position of a manufacturer attempting to find relevant information we were confronted with a daunting array of available courses and consultancies and, worse, difficulties in getting through to the organisation which was specifically set up to overcome the confusion.

That coordinating role is clearly vital. It is performed by the National Industry Extension Service, which is a national and State government funded body. It refers enterprises to the most appropriate source of information and advice and also provides subsidies to engage consultants. The report details the importance of that approach and makes recommendations to streamline even further the service they are offering.

Training and development of staff is crucial to improving productivity levels. The approach to training is not consistent across manufacturing industry. It is our aim to demonstrate the value of money spent on training. Human resources are a company's greatest asset, yet in many plants surprisingly little is done to upgrade skills through formal in-house training programs that are properly supervised and evaluated. Making this and other external training through technical and further education colleges and other bodies relevant to industry's needs should be a major focus of the national and State conferences. Much more information about the value of training to industry should be provided, including how that increased knowledge can be best harnessed within a plant.

I conclude my remarks by again emphasising the value of national and State conferences to develop awareness and to increase current knowledge and practice about new management techniques. It will only be through this process that change across a wide range of manufacturing enterprise will occur. There are many examples of individual companies that are progressive and productive. Sadly, though, when we look at the national figures the need for improvement becomes all too apparent.
I would like to thank the members of the Committee, both past and present, and members of the secretariat, both past and present, for their valuable contribution. I seek leave to continue my remarks.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.
