TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to conclude my remarks on the Social Security and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill by going back to what we see as the problem-that sufficient jobs are simply not available for the age group that we are talking about. By adequate jobs we mean jobs that have a future, jobs that give young people an opportunity to work their way out of poverty, to get sufficient income at least to be able to feed, house and clothe themselves.

SPEECH.PARA: As I have mentioned earlier, a lot of the jobs that are available for these young people are casual, part time work of irregular duration and generally very low paid. This is no problem for those young people who are simply working for some pocket money, who have parental support and encouragement, and, particularly, who have family finances that can support them if they happen to lose one job or decide that they want to move to another. These are not the young people we are talking about.

The people we are talking about do not have these luxuries available to them. They have to work, they need to work and they need to earn sufficient money to be able to provide for themselves-without anyone else helping them-with the necessities of life. To say that by hitting these young people harder and harder we are giving them incentives to get out to work really flies in the face of any rational debate and discussion. What we should be looking at as incentives are support schemes, counselling and advocacy to make sure that they can find their way through the existing maze that has been provided for them-and, indeed, removing some of the restriction and qualifications they now need to face.

The Australian Democrats, therefore, will be moving a number of amendments. Hopefully, we will be able to give these young people a little bit more support and somewhat more of a chance than they are currently getting.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —In addressing the Social Security and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill 1990, the first piece of social security and veterans' affairs legislation since the last election, I want to refer to the second reading speech which was presented in this chamber by the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray). The second reading speech pointed out that this Bill comes before us as a result of the February economic statement and that it implements a number of social security measures which were outlined in that statement. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: Many of the changes provided for in this Bill . . . are the forerunners to the far-reaching initiatives announced in the Treasurer's February Statement which involved the total overhaul of the unemployment benefit system.

The February economic statement was, of course, an election campaign exercise in a climate where, as has been pointed out in many areas but particularly by Louise Dodson in an article in the Australian Financial Review in May, public sympathy for the unemployed is at an all-time low, a fact not lost on the Government during the recent election campaign. The Government's own research demonstrated that certain campaign promises which had been made by the Opposition seemed to be hitting a chord in the context of lack of public sympathy for the unemployed and other groups, including sole parents, and that therefore led to a statement that, if elected, certain other measures of that nature would be put in place by a new Labor government. Well, eventually we have that new Labor government. We have before us a piece of legislation which, as much as anything, could be said to be an example of government by public opinion polls in that it feeds a series of prejudices in the community.

I would like to remind Senator Alston, who, of course, has made his first speech in this chamber on legislation in his new capacity as spokesperson for the Opposition in this crucial area of social security, that this is not, in fact, a Budget Bill. As I have just said, we do not consider the February economic statement to have been a Budget. After complaining about certain aspects of this Bill, his excuse for not taking any action is very thin and rings very hollow. The best he can offer is to say that this is a Budget Bill and, therefore, there is nothing that the Opposition can do. In fact, the tax Bills that are yet to come before the Senate this week are Budget Bills and I understand that there is a whole range of Opposition amendments to that legislation. So I must say that I find that stance somewhat at odds with reality and even, indeed, with an honest approach. It was a pretty unremarkable debut from Senator Alston, and certainly it will give no comfort to those at the coal face of community support for the most disadvantaged and needy in our community.

As I said, the Government did its market research and found that the community has pretty much hardened its heart against those on welfare. But Karen Luscombe, an Australian Labor Party researcher whose work is quoted by Louise Dobson in an article in the Australian Financial Review of 2 May, found that the community was reluctant to accept the Liberals' more hardline policy of withdrawing the unemployment benefit after 12 months, favouring instead compulsory training programs which became one of the election policies of the Government.

Like Julian Disney, the former President of the Australian Council of Social Service, the Australian Democrats believe that there is certainly value in directing tough measures against welfare abuse and, indeed, in making sure that the unemployed are given every possible opportunity to be trained and placed in worthwhile work. But targeting, which has been a feature of the welfare policies of this Government, has, in our view, gone beyond a reasonable point. The results of that `strict targeting', which has been the term used for taking draconian measures in this area and creating cost savings in the welfare budget, have included the continuation of poverty traps and the development of new ones for some groups such as sole parents and young people in particular.

The legislation which this chamber dealt with in December last year regarding sole parents and de facto relationships, and legislation in other areas, has created a reversal of the onus of proof-if not in legal reality, certainly in effect. It has created risks to people's basic civil liberties in this country. I refer to the freedom of choice that people have-not people in this chamber but people who are dependent on the community for income support for however short time; most of them want it to be a short time-about where to live.

I have already raised early in this session with the new Minister for Social Security Senator Richardson, questions about the program set in place last year which enables the withdrawal of unemployment benefit if people move to an area which is seen to reduce their prospects of employment. We objected to that measure at the time. It is a measure which, we believe, creates the potential for the beneficiary to suffer the reverse onus of proof. We were told by the Minister that `yes, there had been some problems', but that he-the Minister told us this on two occasions-was satisfied that the Commonwealth Employment Service (CES) had adequate information available, that its officers could, and indeed would, make the right decisions, that the Government was keeping a very close eye on the situation and that it would see that this provision was used only to crack down on people who were moving their place of residence simply to avoid having to take work and, therefore, become classic dole bludgers.

However, we do not believe that this provision is working yet. We opposed the provision and we continue to oppose it. I offer it here as an example of my point that we have endangered the civil liberties of people who are dependent on welfare benefits and community income support. I have been given some examples of cases current under this system. I ask the Senate to consider whether the rights of the individuals involved have been impeded. I ask the Minister to consider this and to attempt to assure this Senate that the problems raised by these cases have been, or will be, dealt with. We actually believe that we can deal with these problems only by removing this provision which is far too discretionary and is creating far too much distress.

Let me give some examples. Take the case of a person 17 years old, who has only one arm, who is currently unemployed but has worked in the past, and who is living with a family in Campbelltown, in Sydney. He has lived with this family for over three years, including for a period when the family moved to Kempsey for 12 months. This person's family is now due to move to Coffs Harbour because the father has received a work transfer. This young person-a 17-year-old-has been informed by the Department of Social Security at Coffs Harbour that he will lose his unemployment benefit if he moves with the family and that if he reapplies for the benefit he will have to wait 12 weeks. Those are the provisions that we put in place last year. He was told by the Coffs Harbour CES that he would be deemed to have-and I quote from the legislation-`reduced his employment prospects' by moving. This was determined by comparing the general unemployment rate in Sydney with that in Coffs Harbour-4 per cent versus 9 to 11 per cent. This is above a 2 per cent differential and so anyone moving from Sydney to Coffs Harbour would have his unemployment benefits cancelled under section 116 (6a)-the section to which we objected last time and the section which I offer as an example of the way targeting of social security benefits has put at risk the civil liberties of Australians.

Indeed, this determination runs counter to the point that the Minister made in answer to a question I asked about whether the CES was determining these matters on a case-by-case basis or whether it was simply taking global figures and applying them to individuals. This person was told that he did not fall into the `sufficient reason for moving' category, which is in the legislation, as the family he lived with was not his father and mother and this was the only interpretation of `family member' allowed for by the legislation. If this is indeed the case, I will be exhorting the Minister at the appropriate time in the committee stage to make some definitive statement about what is a very narrow definition of `family'-that of mother and father. A 17-year-old person with one arm has lost his benefit because he has moved with his `family', but they are not his father and mother.

Another client moved with his wife and children from Sydney to Brisbane following an offer of work by his father-in-law. He left his job in Sydney, arrived in Brisbane and commenced work only to be advised a week later that there was insufficient work available. He applied for, and received, unemployment benefit in Brisbane. But, due to an overcrowded situation in which the client and his family were living-they had intended to move out into other premises once he was working on a regular basis-they then decided to move to Nowra where an aunt could put them up for a while. When the client moved to Nowra, the 12-week postponement period for unemployment benefit was put in place and his wife and children were paid the special benefit.

Another client moved to the north coast of New South Wales in July 1988 after purchasing a block of land in that area. He left his employment in the Blue Mountains area of Sydney so that he could supervise the building of his house and he obtained employment after about eight weeks. His mother became ill and, due to delays in the construction of the house, he decided to move back to the Blue Mountains, which he did in November-December 1988. He has subsequently obtained employment in Penrith.

In December 1989, just at the time we were passing this piece of legislation, he moved back to the north coast of New South Wales on the basis that the house was now completed and his mother's health had improved. The move back to the north coast constituted a breach of our new section 116 (6a) provision, and a 12-week period of non-payment was imposed. In this case, the Welfare Rights Centre in Sydney advised the wife to claim a special benefit so that there was some income. The person involved did gain full employment just after the 12-week period had expired.

It is clear that the `sufficient reason for moving', which is defined in the legislation at present, is too limited and is excluding genuine job seekers from income support, even with the Government's amendment, which now allows for the inclusion of health problems in the family. It was an amendment which was put in subsequent to my initial question to the Minister here on the first week of sitting. It is also clear that that provision is not being correctly interpreted in that the individual's employment prospects are not, in spite of the answer given to me by the Minister, being assessed; rather, a blanket approach is being taken by Commonwealth Employment Service (CES) officers.

Those are examples of what I believe are impingements on the individual and civil liberties of Australians and their choices about where to live, about whether to go home and look after their mother for a while, and whether to build a house in another area, et cetera.

In this Bill we have a further set of provisions which impinge on the rights of a particular group of Australians-those who were born overseas. The provisions in this legislation mean that a wife's or a widow's B pension will not be payable after 12 months overseas. In both cases it is when that woman has lived overseas for more than 12 months. This is clearly a restriction on these women who are entitled to benefits under Australian legislation, simply because they exercise their right about where they will live. In the case of these women, they are without work and without a partner. That is why they are on this benefit. In most cases these women are choosing to live among family or community support which happens to be overseas because they are not Australian born. This is clearly a discrimination against that group of people and one which we will oppose. As I am sure many other honourable senators have had, we have had a number of representations from, for instance, the Ecumenical Migration Centre in Victoria, the United Association of Greek Orthodox Communities and Parishes of Victoria, and the Ecumenical Migration Centre, and, on behalf of many immigrant groups and ethnic communities, the Welfare Rights Unit. We will, as I say, oppose those provisions of the legislation, particularly as we see in it some ministerial discretion as to whether a certain country will or will not be included, which seems to us to be totally inappropriate in the circumstances.

My colleague Senator Lees has dealt with the impact of the tighter squeeze on young people and their families that is represented by this legislation. I particularly want to raise the question of the foreshadowed moves which the Minister mentions in his second reading speech. That is the replacement of unemployment benefit altogether with labour market training programs in the context of child poverty. The basis of my remarks will be the Brotherhood of St Laurence assessment of the election policies, which was made a week or so before the election. As I say, this whole exercise marks the beginning of the implementation of that election policy program.

The Brotherhood place great emphasis on trying to create an understanding that child poverty has everything to do with the situation of the family. They asked the question before the election-and it is equally valid now, and perhaps more so-how are children likely to fare in a period of rising unemployment? We are, we are told, in a technical recession. Unemployment is not falling; unemployment is rising. The question is whether the pathways out of unemployment will be clear and navigable-to use the Brotherhood's words-for the parents of children at risk of poverty. The Brotherhood's view is that neither the Labor Party nor the coalition parties are planning to introduce measures that will make the economic security of unemployed families better. They believe they will be made more problematic by the sorts of draconian measures that are in this legislation. The proposals make access to income support more dependent upon the satisfaction of administrative tests of one kind or another.

The Brotherhood supports the view that I have already expressed: that there should be no abuse of income support systems. But they point out that the measures that we now have before us by way of legislation carry the risk that as the system becomes more administratively complex, some unemployed parents with genuine needs will fail to satisfy the new tests. New tests include those sections in the legislation in which it is proposed to extend the number of tests with regard to visits to CES offices and whether or not people answer their mail.

The Brotherhood points out that the coalition's policies on unemployment benefits carry a greater risk for children because the long term unemployed will be subjected to more stringent conditions on entitlement without any guarantee that labour market training programs will be made available to them. So there is enormous concern about the safety net of income support from the children of unemployed families and the fact that both the Government and the Opposition are increasing the risks that these families and their children face.

We acknowledge, as does the Brotherhood, of course, the child and family payments that have been put in place by the Government, and, in particular, the indexation which was a major feature of last year's legislation. The real problem is the continuing inadequacies of the benchmarks set for the child related payments and the level of income support provided to sole parents and to homeless teenagers in particular. They are both still well behind where they need to be in terms of an adequate income support program. This legislation also further reduces the income support for, particularly, the young unemployed.

We also need to raise in the context of this legislation the point that is made by the Brotherhood when they say that there is no question but that rigorous administrative procedures are necessary to combat abuse of the income security system; but-and I am quoting here:

Brotherhood research has shown that as eligibility for pensions and benefits is tightened, the system becomes more difficult for genuine clients to understand and establish their correct entitlement. This results in lower take-up rates and confusion about rights and eligibility, at great cost to both the efficiency and the equity of the system.

I ask myself, when looking at the savings figures in the explanatory memorandum of many of the measures in this Bill and measures in previous legislation of the Hawke Government in recent years, how much of that cost saving is dependent upon the confusion and the lack of understanding of these people, and the lack of advocacy that they can get. This results in lower take-up rates and so the full circle is closed. The Government saves money, but at what cost? They are costs which have been very clearly articulated in this chamber today by my colleague Senator Lees, with regard to young people in particular. Louise Dodson said in the article to which I have already referred that the changes are likely to actually increase the role of government and add to, or at least maintain, spending and staffing levels.

I question whether the Government is adequately and sensitively administering these changes. I refer to the examples I gave about the withdrawal of unemployment benefits a few moments ago, and I raise the concerns, as expressed by the Brotherhood, that there is a need to ensure that the restructured system of unemployment benefits is administered with sensitivity to individual circumstances-and it is clear that is not happening in all cases-and with a recognition that no amount of obligation to undergo training or seek work can overcome that shortage of job opportunities in the economy.

At present, there are about eight unemployed people for every job vacancy. The figure is much higher amongst certain age groups and in particular areas. If there is not sensitive implementation of even a very fair system, even a system not so tightly targeted, then many people do lose out; there is no question about that. But the Government saves money and I suppose that is a goal which is attractive in the wider community. At least, that is what the public opinion poll showed and that is why we have this legislation, and why new legislation will be presented.

I point out again that the coalition does not have a specific policy in this area. It talks about tax breaks for families, crackdowns, and a special benefit for the unemployable; but it seems that a large group would fall between those able to find work and those able to qualify for special benefit. There would be many severe casualties under this sort of system. Indeed, labour market programs were to be scaled back under a coalition government. There is a continuing shortage of job opportunities and a limited pool of jobs.

We must, and we will, constantly question the Government about the labour market training programs that it is proposing to put in place. It seems to me that if its goal is to spend less, then this is a major concern. Programs for training-for the wide range of people who are currently unemployed and for those who find employment most difficult to achieve-will not be inexpensive. If they are going to be implemented properly and if all people are going to be catered for, it will not be an inexpensive exercise. The Brotherhood raised these problems in its pre-election document: firstly, whether the planned increase in labour market program places will be adequate for demand and, secondly, whether it will all be adequately funded. That is a question which the Australian Democrats will continue to ask.

The further issue raised by the Brotherhood to which we should all pay attention is the need for family support services. Senator Lees has talked about family breakdown. We are all concerned about our homeless youth. This legislation specifically puts more pressure on families and puts more responsibility on families for a longer period of time. It is ironic that the class B widow's pension now cuts out once the recipient's child reaches the age of 16 because the child is said to be independent at that age. Yet dependency is designated as being up to the age of 21 in various measures that are implemented in this legislation.

We are conscious that in the new Parliament-albeit not yet a new Senate-we have the numbers man, Senator Richardson, as the new Minister for Social Security. I have thought about this matter. I will be delighted if he can get the numbers in the interests of the disadvantaged and turn around the discrimination which still exists against sole parents and their children-the children who are in poverty-and the young unemployed. I do not think that anyone will be delighted if Senator Richardson is in this new role in order to paper over the significant chasms in Government policy.

I refer again to the article by Louise Dodson on 2 May in which it was said that Labor strategists felt that social welfare policy was a major weakness in the runup to the election campaign. The article stated.
This is where the new Minister . . . comes in. Mr Howe . . . was not able to successfully explain and sell the changes.
With regard to Senator Richardson's appointment, the article stated:
Although initially far from happy with the job-
Senator Richardson must have had a grim look on his face when he did this interview, if indeed he did it-
he was given . . . perhaps, Senator Richardson's undoubted political skills could turn the social security reforms into a plus for the Government or at least neutralise the potential negatives.

It will require more than a paperhanging exercise. The Democrats will be here to ensure that progress is real progress, and will ask real questions about the new system which is proposed to be implemented in the Budget session. We will be looking at the labour market programs. We will be pointing out the deficiencies which will no doubt be there and which are there already. There would need to be a very sensitive and well resourced program put in place because we-like the Government says that it does-believe that unemployed, of all age groups and both genders, need the opportunities to get back into the work force, to be independent-to be their own people-and have all the choices. They will not have them if all that they are given is a sausage machine which tries to standardise them in labour market training, at the other end of which there are no jobs, anyway.

There are people with special needs, such as those isolated rural women who have to get back into the work force because they are now on their own. They may have skills, but not necessarily the skills that the market wants at that particular time or in that particular place. What are we going to do for them? What are we going to do for the young people in the same communities, and young people for whom the education system, as it currently exists, has not been an advantage, and who have been square pegs in round holes? We will be looking at that, as will major groups in the community whose job it is to provide advocacy for the disadvantaged.

There has been a rumour that anybody who has $5,000 cash will become ineligible for the unemployment benefit. That is not in this legislation, but there is a very strong thought that $5,000 in the bank is going to create ineligibility. I want the Government to know that there are people who are concerned about this. I do not know where the idea came from, but it is out there. It might be useful if the Minister has something to say about that.

I finish by saying that we will be here, we will be keeping an eye on it and we will be opposing those draconian clauses of this Bill. We will be looking at what the Government is planning to do next. I refer to some remarks made in the `Impact Newsletter' of the Australian Council of Social Service by the President, Merle Mitchell, about the fine election result of the Australian Democrats, pointing out that this was not just a green vote. The article states:

Much of the Democrats' support is due largely to their social and economic policies which are similar to the general directions advocated by ACOSS. ACOSS hopes this clear shift in opinion which is reflected in the Democrat vote will be recognised more by politicians and the media than appears to be the case so far and that the Government's policies will reflect this recognition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This package has some positive aspects because it allows backpayments for family allowance supplements for multiple births and special payments for victims of natural disaster. It also allows recipients of compensation from war crimes exemption from income testing through a reciprocal agreement with Austria. So some parts of the legislation have positive aspects, and they are welcome. Although the social security legislation package is intended as a broad rationalisation of the benefits system, indirectly in principle it targets the female spouses of dole recipients to encourage them to re-enter the work force or skills training programs which will probably be irrelevant in a decade because of the impact of changing technologies on the work force.

SPEECH.PARA: I have a particular concern about clause 10 (1) (a), or old clause 9 (1) (a), which effectively reduces the dole for 18- to 20-year-olds. This relates to a dependent woman living with a dole recipient who is on Austudy and who will have her benefit reduced to half the married rate. I will wholeheartedly support Australian Democrats' amendments to this clause. I do not believe that a young married couple can survive on less than an older married couple. So the legislation does discriminate against youth despite the Government's commitment to deal with youth poverty. Youth benefits will have to be increased to match married rates and pension rates if our welfare system is to reflect any social equity. Forcing youth into further poverty through reducing payments to Austudy levels will contribute to more people falling into the poverty trap-perhaps never to escape. However, in income testing terms the Austudy payment will not be judged as additional income, so it appears that the Government is taking away on the one hand from young couples and then giving a little bit back, but this is inadequate as a way of dealing with welfare policy.

The legislation clearly discriminates against young women who will now have to qualify for the dole in their own right if they are married or in a de facto relationship with a dole recipient. This initiative is forcing women into training programs which are mainly blue-collar oriented for jobs that probably do not or will not exist for much longer. The whole emphasis of Jobstart is to put young people into trades and apprenticeships, an area now being overtaken by technology, so the structure of the Government's skills programs is increasingly irrelevant.

This legislation package is draconian and clearly discriminates against young, disadvantaged women who will be deterred from re-entering the education system because the total household income will be reduced because of the Austudy payment. The change proposed under the legislation, that the social security benefits of a married person whose spouse is on Austudy will be limited to half the normal combined married rate, goes against the philosophy of all the affirmative action programs the Government has introduced in other policy areas and against its poverty initiatives.

The Government claims it is a work incentive to reduce the level of the payment to Austudy levels while the spouse is on the dole, which is totally ironical because it is obviously a disincentive for women to enter or continue education courses whilst their spouse is on the dole. This clause will directly contribute to immersing women in a cycle of limited education and poverty. It is clear that education is the key to freeing women from the poverty trap and helping them contribute to the economy and society productively. But the Government is taking the right wing economic rationalist route by reducing the dole to the level of Austudy which has historically lagged behind social security payments, rather than doing what is just, which is to boost Austudy to dole levels.

Since 1985-86 in its Youth Policies Budget Statement and other various statements such as Priority One, the Government has claimed that it is committed to creating parity between the dole and Austudy. In 1985, the Government said that by 1988 the basic Austudy rates for 16 to 17-year-old secondary and tertiary students and unemployment benefits would reach parity. However, this legislation shows that across the board we are moving in the opposite direction. The Government is long on rhetoric and short on action. What it is doing with this piece of legislation is reducing dole payments to half where a spouse receives Austudy, which is a shocking rationalisation at the expense of the disadvantaged.

The point is that over 21-year-old students still get a rate that is equivalent only to the intermediate rate of the dole for over 18s and under 21s or the youth allowance, so parity is not being reached according to the Government's projections and with the direction of this legislation it probably never will be.

The Government is disregarding its commitment to help free under 21-year-olds from the poverty trap and goes against the grain of many other initiatives which the Government has instituted to help youth, such as the youth homeless allowance. The Government is slashing social security benefits and making rationalisations at the expense of the class of disadvantaged people and, even more particularly, disadvantaged women wanting to educate themselves.

All the rationalisations the Government is making in the social security area are tightening the welfare sector and reducing fraud in some areas-and, of course, that is commendable-but at the same time they are squeezing the life out of an underclass of people already caught in the inescapable pincers of the poverty trap. For example, the decision to discriminate against dole recipients moving to low employment areas by extending the period of non-payment of the dole is unacceptable and is one major rationalisation in a whole package of draconian measures.

In addition, the Job Search allowance, which will replace the dole after nine months is the Government's middle ground solution to the work for the dole scheme. The whole welfare system is now becoming very harsh and punitive and is forcing the margin of people unable to receive the dole onto the stringent category of special benefits. In other words, it is squeezing the life out of those in the poverty trap. The welfare lobby are outraged by these rationalisations and I believe that middle Australia would be appalled too at what is going on if the Government did not couch the changes in the language of economic rationalisation, which is really the hidden sell out of traditional Labor principles. It is no work incentive for a woman to live on half the married rate of the dole. It is just another bureaucratic rationalisation at the expense of the rights of individuals at the expense of social justice as a whole.

I am also concerned about clause 16, formerly clause 15, which extends the period of non-payment or punishment for an individual not taking reasonable steps to find employment-not visiting the CES office for registration for jobs, or by voluntarily leaving employment-from four weeks plus two weeks to six weeks plus six weeks. This is unnecessarily harsh and it does not allow for an individual to explain the circumstances of those alleged breaches. The whole social security system is becoming highly discretionary and punitive. People on welfare should not be made to feel like criminals.

I am also worried by clause 17 of the Bill, which disallows people conditioned sickness benefit if they are deferring their education course. This is also highly discriminatory. If the Australian Government looks at the effects of Thatcherism, it could well learn the dangers of increasing the gaps in the social structure through tightening the welfare system. Britain now has a large, angry and dispossessed underclass and the commensurate problems of increasing violence and crime.

The point is that our family support structures such as the family allowance supplement and the Government's initiatives to boost middle Australia are being made at the cost of disadvantaged, dispossessed and unemployed youth. As Senator Lees pointed out, the Burdekin report left us in no doubt about this fact.

The welfare system in Australia has gone off the rails and cuts to youth benefits are now subsidising benefits for the families of middle Australia. The Government is juggling the figures to make the Budget look equitable, but in real terms no increases are occurring in the welfare sector and the dole and Austudy have not been equalised. The monetarist policies may work for the moneyed classes, but they certainly do not benefit our new underclass of poverty-stricken youth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not seek to answer all the points that were raised during the second reading debate because quite a few of them relate to the passage of legislation over the last two years and not actually to those amendments with which we are dealing today. In any event, no doubt in committee we will go into those in some detail. However, I would like to mention a number of points that Senator Alston raised, particularly those in relation to our arrangements for the Newstart program.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Alston said that 30 per cent of 10,000 persons surveyed were supposed to have found jobs within two weeks of the start of the scheme. He hinted that they actually had jobs while on unemployment benefits. In July 1989, the then Opposition spokesman on social security, David Connolly, claimed that 25 per cent of beneficiaries who were sent a letter inviting them to attend a Newstart interview reported that they had found a job in the previous fortnight; they were, therefore, fraudulently in receipt of the benefit. Since February 1989 a total of 5,289 unemployment beneficiaries, that is, 13 per cent of a total of 40,000 who were invited to attend the interview, terminated from benefit within one week of the interview date. That includes 2,440 beneficiaries whose benefits were terminated for failure to attend the interview, 1,001 who returned to work and 499 who failed the work test.

Six weeks after the interview 2,964 beneficiaries-that is, 7 per cent of all beneficiaries invited to a Newstart interview-had not come back onto benefit. That includes a further 858 returning to work, 1,217 who failed to attend the interview-and that is only 3 per cent of the total, and 244 who failed the work test. So I think Senator Alston has followed on from a mistake made by his predecessor and his criticisms make no more sense than did the initial ones.

In terms of one of the most important aspects of what we are dealing with today, though, Senator Alston raised the question of portability. This has, of course, had particular reference to the Greek and Turkish communities in recent times because should the Government proceed with not exempting Greece and Turkey, wives' and widows' B pensions in those countries would cease to be paid from 1 July next year.

This would also involve the Government giving formal notice of the termination of agreements between Greece and Turkey signed in 1972. It should be noted that those agreements have always been dead letter treaties. Neither Greece nor Turkey ever abided by the terms of them because the foreign currency restrictions in both countries virtually prevented the payment of any pensions overseas. In the case of Turkey, they totally prevented the payment of pensions outside the country and in the case of Greece, they very severely restricted the agreement to the point where we think that only 101 pensions from Greece are paid into Australia whereas we are paying 7,200 into Greece, costing $45m a year. The Greek Government is paying $160,000 in pensions a year into Australia. For that reason we want to get reciprocal agreements with Greece and Turkey.

For all the worry about the cancellation of wives' and widows' pensions, it is important to note the rationale behind it. Many of the reasons given in the last few weeks simply do not get to the point. Widows' pensions in this country are not strictly confined to widows; the recipients include divorcees and others. Wives' and widows' pensions are unique to Australia. They are paid in almost no other country. That being the case, the Australian Government decided in February that these pensions were not appropriate for export. Instead of simply terminating those payments around the world, instead of giving those who had been in receipt of those pensions no time to adjust, the Government quite correctly announced that the decisions would take effect from 1 July next year.

In terms of prior community consultations with the Greek and Turkish communities and Senator Alston's suggestion that the Bill be deferred in the meantime, it has to be remembered that, under this legislation, by regulation any country can be exempted. The reality is that the consultations with the Greek and Turkish communities are not finished. They have now been occurring for some weeks. I have had two meetings in Melbourne, two in Sydney, I am attending a further meeting with the Greek community in Melbourne tomorrow and I will be meeting with the Turkish community, also in Melbourne, on Thursday morning. Those consultations will continue, and will include some much larger meetings in Sydney and Melbourne next week.

Given that this legislation provides the power to exempt by regulation, should the Government at any time between now and 1 July next year decide, for whatever reason, that Greece and Turkey should not be included in this legislation, that power to exempt can be used. That is why the consultations with the communities are valid and will continue in the way in which they have during the last few weeks. At the end of those consultations I will be able to report to Cabinet on the attitudes that have been displayed by the communities in question and the Cabinet can then determine its position.

As to whether there is evidence of rorts under the present system-which is what Senator Alston was attempting to get at-it should be noted that whenever pensions are paid overseas, and not just wives' and widows' pensions but pensions for the age or invalid pensions, virtually all of the policing of those pensions is done on an honour system given the difficulty of finding out sufficient information in foreign countries on assets and income. So one can only speculate as to whether there are abuses to the system. Certainly, members of the Greek community have approached me and suggested that these abuses exist. In terms of proof, one wonders exactly how one could go about getting it. With a comprehensive reciprocal agreement signed between Australia and other countries, the possibility of a better flow of information between Australia and other countries might assist.

The other point to be made about these reciprocal agreements which so far has failed to be made during this debate is that reciprocal agreements with countries such as Greece and Turkey would over time inevitably mean more money, rather than less, being paid into those countries by Australia. A short-term saving is involved in chopping off wives' and widows' pensions. The form of these agreements is quite well known because Australia has signed agreements with Canada, Italy and Spain. Malta is also now ready to sign and during the next 12 months I think I can confidently predict that agreements will be signed with Portugal, West Germany, Ireland, the Netherlands and Austria.

TALK.START.PARA: —You will never be here.

—I will manage to stay here occasionally; Senator Alston should not worry about that. There is a whole range of countries with which negotiations are at an advanced stage. The social security system differs in each one of these countries, so we cannot have exactly the same agreement with every country. Nonetheless, it is pretty obvious that in all these cases the agreements do provide for the continued payment of age and invalid pensions, which make up the bulk of the payments to all the countries. For all those who fear that in some way we have a thin edge of the wedge step, that a move on wives' and widows' pensions is actually the first step to cutting off age and invalid pensions later on, all I can say is that the signing of all these agreements around the world should allay those fears.

SPEECH.PARA: While I cannot pretend or purport to bind a future Australian Government in 10, 20 or 50 years time, I can say that Australia's record of honouring its international obligations is first class, irrespective of the political colour of its government. That being the case, the agreements now being signed obviously will be honoured by future governments. It will be virtually impossible for any Australian Government to decide to walk away.

It should be noted that there is a benefit in the signing of these agreements. As an example, they allow the qualification periods in both countries to be added together, to give a total eligibility period in either country. That means that in the case of Greece there will be many people who would be entitled to a part pension if we had an agreement but who receive nothing at the present time. That is why the signing of these agreements can bring about considerable benefits for more people.

In terms of progress of negotiations, the Government of Turkey is seeking to have a joint announcement with Australia on the termination of the 1972 agreement, asking that negotiations on a comprehensive reciprocal agreement begin immediately, and it is confident of having the Turkish Minister visit Australia in August. I will be seeking to visit Ankara in September. The Government of Greece, too, is anxious to begin negotiations, which will kick off during the next few months. So we will be pursuing with vigour negotiations with those governments and with the other countries that I mentioned earlier to make sure that as those agreements are signed, there is less and less concern expressed by people in Australia about the Government's present and future intentions.

I think that the contributions of Senator Powell and Senator Lees covered many of the same points. Many of their comments related to changes in the legislation during the last 12 months or perhaps two years and to their assessments of those changes, what they meant, and what was behind them. The philosophy which has been behind most of these changes is that Australia needed to do much more for those receiving unemployment benefits, in particular, to get them back into the work force. The changes seek to reflect that need.

Insofar as whether I will be welcomed as the Minister for Social Security, I can say that I agree with the philosophy espoused. It is certainly the Government's intention to do as much as it possibly can to assist people get the skills and information necessary to get back into the work force. However, that does not mean that we will not tighten up on work and activity tests to make sure that people try.

From time to time there will be problems in the implementation of those sorts of schemes. That is inevitable. But I say to Senator Powell that I will endeavour over the course of the next few years to make sure that sensitivity is shown by the Department of Social Security and, insofar as I can have an influence, by the Commonwealth Employment Service (CES) in dealing with these labour market programs.

As honourable senators would appreciate, there is quite an overlap from the CES to the Department of Social Security. As the question that Senator Powell asked in the chamber a few weeks ago demonstrated admirably, that overlap can sometimes cause difficulties. Today again she has referred to the difficulties of those who seek to move to areas where employment prospects are considerably lower than in the areas in which they presently reside.

While there have been teething problems at the implementation stage of this scheme, they now largely have been overcome. It is not just a question of State governments saying that they will not drop people down the waiting list for housing if they refuse to accept the offer of a home in an area where employment prospects are lower; the way that the CES now assesses each case has also changed. It looks not only at generally the possibility of getting a job in the area to which a person moves, but also at the individual case and the particular skills and occupation of the person concerned.

It is a case of endeavouring, in so far as is possible, to make sure that programs which are intrinsically worthy are administered properly. If they are, there should be no real cause for hardship. I totally reject the concept that this has a sausage-machine effect of jamming people together and throwing them out at the other end onto some labour market scrap heap. Certainly, that is not the aim of the scheme nor the way the scheme has been administered; nor would I ever allow it to be administered in that way.

Senator Powell talked about another rumour as to what the Government might be contemplating in the course of Budget discussions. One classic example appeared last week in the Sydney Morning Herald. It recklessly announced that we were looking at reducing from 16 to 12 years the eligibility of people to receive the family allowance.

TALK.START.PARA: —You encouraged that.

—At no stage did I encourage it. One always faces a difficulty in denying a rumour because, inevitably, someone comes up with another, one is asked to deny it and so on. That makes the Government's budgetary task very difficult. I do not intend to comment on these issues rumour by rumour. That is a waste of time. SPEECH.PARA: We note that this measure has an expected saving of $29m in the first year and $28.7m in the second year. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to the rationale behind this whole proposal, is it correct to say that 12 months has been taken as a period of time that is sufficient to indicate that a person has an intention to be permanently resident overseas, and to avoid the difficulties that might otherwise be experienced with someone being away for a couple of months and coming back if the Government tried to determine some shorter level of permanency? . . . an absence of a person from Australia ends if he or she returns to Australia, even if only temporarily.

What the Government is then doing is condoning permanent absence from Australia but making an exception for a person who can afford to come back. I do not know why the Government simply does not come out and say that it does not want people to be resident overseas and that what it is on about is restricting that entitlement, rather than having this backdoor arrangement that somehow will cater for those who can afford to come back here.

Others have suggested that this may well result in an excess burden on the social infrastructure in the sense that a lot of people will come back here who otherwise would not have returned. It seems to me that this is quite unlikely. The reality is that what the Government has in mind is that hardly anyone will come back; that people will simply throw in the towel. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

There is some disagreement, of course, in different ethnic communities about how many people are actually going to come back to Australia and take advantage of it. I am told by the people in the Turkish community that great numbers will come back and take advantage of it. SPEECH.PARA: As regards Senator Powell's statement about rubbery figures, I do intend to write to the Minister for Finance (Mr Willis) shortly and suggest that perhaps all the savings anticipated from this measure might not be there, for a number of reasons. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly, in response to Senator Alston, I think the only reason for putting back the date was the intervention of the election, and that interregnum meant that we could not do it quite as quickly as had been hoped when the announcement was originally made. TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 5, after clause 8, insert the following new clause:
``8a. Section 81 of the Principal Act is amended by inserting in section 81 after `prescribed educational scheme' ``, with the exception of the Assistance for Isolated Children Scheme,''.''

The reason that I am moving this amendment is to give effect to the declared intention of the Minister to seek to have the Act amended in that way. The Committee will recall that on 17 May I raised with the Minister the case of a mother who lived in an isolated area of Tasmania. Her child was boarding in Hobart in order to attend secondary school. She appealed against the removal of her family allowance payment when her child reached 16 years of age because she was receiving a boarding allowance for her student child under the assistance for isolated children scheme.

The Secretary to the Department of Social Security, pursuant to section 81 of the Social Security Act, removed the family allowance because the mother was receiving a boarding allowance for her child under the assistance for isolated children scheme. I posed the question to the Minister as to whether it was fair for parents living in isolated areas to suffer such a financial penalty simply because the child turned 16. I pointed out to the Minister that the Social Security Appeals Tribunal, whilst having no alternative but to deny the appeal on technical grounds, said that the case of the mother was a `reasonable case' and that `it seems unreasonable that receipt of AIC boarding allowance should disqualify receipt of family allowance'. That was the statement of the Social Security Appeals Tribunal.
The Minister responded quite positively. Having asked his Department for a good reason as to why the provisions were included in the Act as they are, he said:

I cannot find a good reason. It seems to me certainly to be harsh, unconscionable and oppressive that this should occur. I am not aware of any other case although I will have that double-checked for you. I think it is the only time it has happened. Nonetheless, even if it were to happen only once or twice, it should not happen and I shall seek to have the Act amended to make sure it does not happen in the future.
The reason that it did happen is to be found in the actual text of section 81 of the Act, which says:

Where the Secretary is satisfied that payments under a prescribed educational scheme are being or will be made to or in respect of a student child, other than a child by reference to whom the rate of those payments is increased, the Secretary shall decide that family allowance in respect of that child ceases to be payable as from a family allowance pay day specified in the decision (whether before or after the making of the decision), not being a day before . . .

Section 79 (1) of the Act includes in the definition of `prescribed education scheme' the assistance for isolated children scheme. Therein lies the unintended consequence and the cause for the denial of the appeal of the mother in this case, on technical grounds, and therein lies, I believe, the reason that the Social Security Appeals Tribunal itself suggested that it was unreasonable for the family allowance to be withdrawn in that circumstance.

My amendment simply seeks to amend section 81 of the principal Act so as to remove `assistance for isolated children scheme' from the definition of `prescribed educational scheme'. I think it is very reasonable because, as was pointed out by the mother in this case, the fact that her child turned 16 did not mean that she was any less expensive to keep boarding in Hobart. The reverse is the case, because we have seen figures to that effect, but I will not go into that. The fact is that, as the Minister said in his response to us, it seemed to him that it was harsh, unconscionable and oppressive that this should occur. The purpose of my moving the amendment was to give effect to what the Minister had indicated and also to the view expressed by the Social Security Appeals Tribunal that this was unreasonable.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats are opposing this clause in toto because what is happening here is a very good example of the approach that has been taken recently in legislation with regard to the unemployment benefit. As I said in my speech in the second reading debate, we believe this takes the whole exercise beyond what we can support. True it is that the rationale for increasing penalties and restrictions is that we do not want welfare fraud. We do not want welfare fraud any more than anyone else.

SPEECH.PARA: As I have said, concern has been expressed by organisations such as the Brotherhood of St Laurence and the Australian Council of Social Service that one can go beyond a point where one is really making available the opportunity for income support as a genuine safety net to those people who need it. This clause imposes non-payment periods of four weeks and two weeks for each additional occasion where unemployment is due to a voluntary act, to misconduct, to failure to accept an offer of employment or to undergo a medical examination or to take reasonable steps to seek employment. These provisions have been in the Act before but the periods have been extended. This clause also adds two further areas: refusal to comply with requests to attend a Commonwealth Employment Service (CES) office departmental interview or to respond to correspondence.

We are not saying that requirements for appearance at offices, requirements to accept offers of employment, requirements to take reasonable steps and so on should not be in the Act. What we are saying is that the requirements that are currently there are sufficient. To add to the penalties and to the requirements does nothing to make the system that is here a better safety net and does very little in the area of genuine prevention of real fraud.

There can be many perfectly valid and human reasons for any of these provisions not being met. We are concerned-and examples have been given already in this debate-at the lack of ability of the Department of Social Security and the CES, either separately or in joint operation, as they increasingly are, to be able to handle these matters with any kind of sensitivity, even with adequate information at their disposal.

It therefore seems to us that we are going beyond what is reasonable in this clause. We cannot support that extension of the stress and the consequent distress of those people who are unemployed in an environment where there still are not enough jobs for all those people who want them. With regard to these sorts of provisions, we are concerned about people's access to speedy appeal, and we are conscious of the history of difficulties in these areas. One example is unemployment due to misconduct. Some individual has to determine whether that is in fact the reason for a person moving into unemployment. That comes down to what the previous employer says, what the previous employee says, and the assessment that is made in the CES and then at the Department.

Another example is failure to accept an offer of employment. Clearly, there would be many young women, for instance, who would go to a place of employment and be extremely uneasy about the prospect of working in that workplace because of the implications and insinuations that might be made that might make young women fear some form of sexual harassment or some other form of rather subtle mistreatment which might not be able to be proven. It will be very difficult for these women if we continue to make the penalties for these sorts of processes more draconian and if we add other requirements.

So we believe that there are unreasonable expectations here. I point out that the Government's expectations for savings here are $3.2m in the first year and $6.5m in the second year, which seem to us to be rather small-not that one sneezes at a million dollars here or there; but we are conscious, given the history of these sorts of provisions in the Act, of the distress that is caused and the ultimate consequence that many people, particularly isolated people, have to face these kinds of provisions. How are we handling things such as requests to attend CES offices when people in isolated areas are obviously not physically able to do that on demand or with great frequency or without difficulty? How are we handling cases where correspondence is not replied to for a range of reasons-it was not picked up, the dog took it out of the letterbox, the person was away for a period, it was lost in the mail, or whatever?

We are concerned about these provisions and we are not prepared to take them any further. We think that the tests in the system now are adequate and, indeed, we are concerned about how they are being carried out and we do not want to extend them any further.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Obviously, there is no question that the intent of this clause is to be punitive. I would not seek to deny that, but I believe it is well targeted. We want to make sure that the smarties cannot take advantage of the situation, because there is no equity if that current situation is to continue.

SPEECH.PARA: It must be understood that there is the situation where Department of Social Security (DSS) staff are lined up for an interview at a Commonwealth Employment Service office. TALK.START.PARA: —We are passing legislation and you have not got the guidelines?

—Yes, we are, because we must address what at the moment is an obvious anomaly which advantages those who are seeking to abuse the system. We cannot allow that to happen. SPEECH.PARA: I think it should also be taken into account that there are review officers at every area office whom people affected by this can consult and there are expedited appeals before the Social Security Appeals Tribunal (SSAT). They are the hard core, difficult group that we will have to watch very carefully when it comes to the administration of the Newstart program. They are the ones that we seek to help. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Training Guarantee (Administration) Bill and the Training Guarantee Bill have as their objectives, according to the provisions of the Training Guarantee Bill, to increase and improve the quality of and employment related skills of the Australian work force. The Opposition has no quarrel with those objectives. They are widely shared in the community, and I think it is recognised very clearly that training for the work force to improve its skills, to retrain because of developments which require new skills, is required.

SPEECH.PARA: However, the Opposition differs fundamentally with the Government about the way these objectives can be achieved. The legislation seeks to do this in a typical way that one associates with this Government-to impose upon a selected group in the community, namely, a limited number of employers, a charge to the extent that they fail to meet the Government's requirements for training. That is what these Bills do. That is their whole purpose.

The Opposition fundamentally disagrees with the Government's approach to solving this problem. We are opposed to it because it amounts to a tax on a small section of the community, namely the group of employers selected by this legislation. I will deal with that in detail as I develop my argument. Essentially, our problem with this legislation is that the Government has chosen a selective approach and a heavy-handed and bureaucratic solution.

The Opposition believes that training is desirable. That is also the widely accepted view of the community. But our solution to these problems is totally different from that of the Government. We see the solution to these problems in working through the ordinary pressures and forces placed on employers when working in their own interests. We believe in providing incentives and government leadership so as to encourage greater training without putting impediments and further taxes on the employers.

On the face of it, this legislation is presented, by use of words, as not instituting a new tax. The fact is that that is just what it is doing. In the first year of this legislation's operation the Government will raise hundreds of millions of dollars. The Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) says that that amount will reduce as more people satisfy the requirements imposed upon them by this legislation to train not only people in their own work force but also others. As those obligations are met, the amount raised by the Government will decrease. But even if that pious hope is achieved, the Government will recover substantial moneys and place them into a separate fund, admittedly, to be spent by the Government on the objectives of the legislation, namely retraining.

It is rather ironic that the Government has sought to present this legislation not as a taxing measure. The language used during the second reading speech and indeed in the Bill emphasises the fact that it is not the Government's purpose to collect further revenue.

According to an opinion that I have received, the only way that this Bill could be constitutional would be if it came within the taxation powers. Indeed, according to the opinion I have received, it is probably unconstitutional legislation because the measures in the Bill do not amount to taxation in the constitutional sense. But that is an argument for another place on another day. I do not propose to spend my time tonight developing that constitutional argument. Nevertheless, there is a threshold problem for the Government with this legislation. It may well be that whatever we do with it in this Parliament, it will fail under a constitutional challenge.

The Opposition's concerns about this Bill are not on those grounds. That is really a problem for the Government. Our concern is to oppose this legislation in its entirety because, as I have said, we believe that the Government is going about solving this problem in completely the wrong way. In our view, the effect of this Bill is to place a new impost on a selected group of people in the business community. It is part of a long line of legislation that has been brought down by this Government over the years, imposing more and more taxation on business. It is in the same tradition as has been achieved by the fringe benefits tax, the capital gains tax and the new provisions to accelerate the payment of taxation in the business community. It is particularly directed against a relatively small number of employees.

There is a very important exception in the Bill which is designed to protect small business. That exception of a payroll threshold of $200,000 a year, is in itself an inadequate protection, even for small business. With that threshold the Bill will impose these obligations on a minority of employers, even though many of those people will be categorised as small business because the threshold of $200,000 a year for the payroll of a business will exempt only businesses with perhaps as few as six or seven employees. Even the Minister has stated that clearly businesses that are employing 10 or more people will come within its provisions. Nevertheless, as far as a majority of employers are concerned they will be relieved from obligations under this Bill.

The Bill is clearly an impost on a relatively small number of employers and certainly a small number of people in the community, whereas the object and purpose of this legislation is to benefit the community generally by improving the quality of the work force and thereby the benefits which the whole of the community will receive if that work force is better trained, better skilled and able to produce better quality products both for domestic consumption and exports. The whole of the community will benefit by improving the skills of our work force. As I have said, that is an objective with which the Opposition agrees. However, placing the whole burden of this legislation on a small group in the community we believe is a very unjust way of going about it.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a selective tax.
—That is absolutely so. It is only a selected group in the community who are having to pay it.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has also chosen one of the worst ways of taxing any section of the community. Even this small section of the community is going to be taxed on its payroll. There is no worse tax in Australia than the payroll tax; it is counterproductive because the employer has to pay it whether he is making a profit or not. There is no better way of reducing or killing the incentive to employ people than to have a tax on payrolls. We have already had years of experience of this sort of tax at the Commonwealth level. Let us give credit where it is due. It was a Commonwealth government that introduced the whole concept of a payroll tax. Some 20 years ago the Commonwealth generously handed that poisoned chalice to the States, so it is now a State tax.

It is a thoroughly regressive form of taxation. In the States the exemption from paying it is at a higher level. Even the State with the most benign form of payroll tax has a threshold which is higher than the one proposed under this tax. It is a selective tax imposed on a small group in the community. The method of paying the tax is the worst and the most counterproductive form that one could think of, particularly when presumably one wants to encourage employers to spend more money to train their employees better and to increase the level of skilled employment and employment generally. It will discourage employers from employing more people as well as from training them.

Another major weakness in this legislation is that it is simply imposed across the board on all employers above the threshold and has no regard to the nature of any particular employer's work force. It is not targeted to the encouragement of training because it is not targeted to the particular section of the work force which is most likely to benefit from training and which the employers are likely to see some benefit in training.

There are a whole range of examples of employees in respect of whom, because of their payroll, employers will have to pay this tax. It is very difficult to see how any benefit would be obtained by employers from that expenditure, which they are being encouraged to make because, by making what is called `eligible expenditure' under this Act, employers will be able to avoid paying the tax. A classic example of this is Drake International, which is a body that employs people who are immediately seconded to other employers. That is the nature of its business. It finds skilled people whom it technically employs, but does no more than act as agents to second those people to other employers.

A company of this kind will come within this Act. Its employees will come within the provisions of the Act and it will have to pay this tax or provide training for people who it does not, in fact, have working for them at all, although the employees may have that legal status. They are people who have the skills. They are chosen for employment simply because they have the skills that are wanted by the people who are benefiting from them.

Then there are other categories of people who are themselves not likely to benefit from training and where the nature of the work means that the employer does not require them to have anything more than minimal training. If they have been trained at all, they do not need very much training. They are all the categories, say, of casual employees, seasonal workers and so forth. They include all those employees whose work enterprise does not require a high level of skill, where there is very little room for multi-skilling or for career paths and where there could very well be a high turnover of employees.

Then there are other employers most of whose work force is already highly skilled. This includes people in the professions who, although many would be working in partnerships, would be employing a number of people with high skills who have already received training with their professional education. They may need to keep up with that but would not do so under the concept of training which is part and parcel of this legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —They could be exempt.

—It is impossible to try to amend this legislation because of the way it has been structured by the Government. That is why, despite the fact that we support the objectives of the Bill, we can see no way in which this legislation can be satisfactorily amended-certainly not without full consideration by a Senate committee, and that is another proposal that we will be making and one which I will deal with in a minute.

SPEECH.PARA: The other serious problem that we have with this legislation is the concept of what is called the eligible training expenditure. Let us assume that we have justifiably selected the target of this tax-namely, a relatively small group of employers-and that these employers are employing people who may in fact benefit from training, and certainly a large number of such employees may well benefit from training in the way in which this Bill proposes its arbitrary and generalised concepts about the matter. But there are very considerable limits as to what will be eligible training expenditure. As I said, unless employers can come within these narrow definitions of expenditure that will be eligible-that is, can be used by the employer to set against the tax, or the charge, as the Bill calls it-the tax will be imposed upon them.

A great range of problems emerges here. Firstly, what is excluded entirely from this Bill is the ordinary on the job unstructured training which has always been, and always will be, a very important part of the development of skills of any employees, whether they are professional people, people with high technical skills, semi-skilled people or people who are unskilled and who will never be skilled. It has always been a very important part of training that these people are trained on the job by people who are taking an interest in and supervising what they are doing.

But the definition of eligible training prevents that in itself from being included because the Bill requires that any eligible training program has to be a structured training program. Proposed section 27 goes to great lengths to establish what is meant by this and thereby to greatly limit the sort of expenditure that can qualify. For instance, a training program is only a structured training program if it satisfies a number of conditions set out in the section. The program has to be designed or approved by a person who is appropriately qualified to design such a program; the skills to be acquired are to be clearly identified before the program begins; the means of imparting the skills are to be identified before the program begins; before the program begins, the expected program outcomes are to be clearly formulated; and so on. The Bill goes on with the final sting in the tail that an eligible training program cannot include any generally supervised practice or work experience. So unless that most important form of training-namely, generally supervised practice or work experience-is part of one of the structured training programs set up in that bureaucratic, theoretical, arbitrary fashion as laid down in this legislation, it will not qualify.

There are, as I have sought to point out, many great deficiencies in this legislation. We in the Opposition cannot see how this Bill can be improved-if it ever could be-without a great deal more thought and much more consideration of submissions from people who know what they are doing in relation to these matters.

We have fundamental objections to it, as I have said, and we propose to vote against the second reading. However, if the Senate does ot accept that view and gives the legislation a second reading, we believe that the only other suitable course that we could adopt would be to endeavour to send it off to a Senate committee to see whether something could be done to make it a more workable piece of legislation than it appears to be.

I have already mentioned the extent to which the legislation will impose further imposts, not only on large businesses or middle-sized businesses, but on small business. Any business which is employing more than 10 people will clearly come within its operation. There will be very great additional administrative costs imposed upon business in giving effect to all of the bureaucratic steps that will be required under this legislation. For all of those reasons, we believe that the Senate should defeat this legislation. It should tell the Government to try to do better. The Government should come up with a far more positive incentive, if it believes that that is required, in order to improve the level of training and the development of skills in our community.

TALK.START.PARA: —I table a correction to the explanatory memorandum relating to the Training Guarantee (Administration) Bill 1990.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Zakharov Sen A.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —In view of the pressure of business before us this week, I wish to speak only briefly on the Training Guarantee (Administration) Bill 1990 and the Training Guarantee Bill 1990. I want to focus on the justification and need for these measures rather than the details of the legislation itself. However, I point out that Senator Durack has just said that the Government is going about this the wrong way. Well, we have waited a very long time. A succession of coalition governments did nothing about the situation and certainly did not seem to know what was the right way.

SPEECH.PARA: The training guarantee will require employers to spend a minimum amount at least on training. Many employers, of course, are spending much more than that minimum amount on the training of their work force and these measures will not affect them. Rather, they are targeted at those employers who are making little or no effort to train or retrain their work force. Those employers will be required to pay the equivalent of one per cent initially, and 1.5 per cent from June 1992, on structured training activities, or pay a levy of that amount. I would argue that that levy is not a tax in the usual sense because it will not go into Consolidated Revenue; rather, it will be dedicated to funding additional training activities in the community. The legislation excludes very small-scale employers whose payroll does not exceed $200,000 per annum, and that threshold amount will be indexed.

I should point out that these Bills were released in draft form earlier this year to enable public discussion and comment and this is the reason for some of the Government amendments. Such amendments, particularly after a draft exposure, show that the Government is being honest in its intentions and is willing to listen to community suggestions-this is probably far more profitable than sending it off to a Senate committee.

At the time of the introduction of the higher education contribution scheme, many of us believed that it was wrong to expect some future employees to contribute to the costs of their education while employers, who stood to gain a great deal from a well trained and educated work force, were in many cases contributing little or nothing to the cost of that educated work force. In some cases, employers who may have had little education themselves were employing lawyers, accountants, engineers and so on to run their businesses-expertise to whose costs they had contributed nothing.

At the basic job training and apprenticeship level there are many companies, some very large as well as small businesses, who have taken little responsibility for training their work force, preferring to rely on those who have been apprenticed or been given training by other employers. Before I was elected to the Senate, I worked for many years as a student counsellor in a high school and was made constantly aware that the number of apprenticeships offered came nowhere near meeting the number of qualified and eager applicants.

The group apprenticeship scheme, which enables a group of usually small businesses to share the training of an apprentice, has overcome the difficulty of an employer who wanted to train his or her staff but could not provide the range of training experience required or could not meet the full cost of their training. But there were and there still are many businesses who prefer to poach or head-hunt those trained by others.
