This legislation aims to correct that situation, at least for employers whose payroll exceeds $200,000, which is not to say, of course, that smaller businesses do not have some responsibility for training, but it is recognised that a levy would fall unduly heavily on those employing very few people. In any case, it is my experience that there are many small employers, particularly in the skilled trade area such as the local electrician, plumber and so on, who are meeting their responsibilities for training, perhaps because they remember their own training, which they got the hard way.

I believe that one of the major problems with many Australian companies at the moment is their concentration on short term goals and short term gains rather than on the long term viability, profitability and growth of their operations. In the training area, as with research and development investment, this means an unwillingness to invest in training, at a relatively short term cost, when in the long term they will benefit from a work force which is not only better trained but also more likely to stay with a particular employer who has helped to train them or perhaps in a job which they have been specifically trained for in that enterprise. At the same time employers are benefiting from increased retention rates in education as they do through public provision of child-care and labour market programs such as Jobstart and Skillshare, largely at the expense of the general taxpayer.

In spite of a lot of public discussion about the need for a better trained work force-a need recognised by major employer organisations, particularly in the context of industry restructure needed to meet Australia's present economic needs-the Australian Bureau of Statistics figures in April indicated no significant increase in structured training over the past two years. The ABS found that more than half of the targeted employers for this legislation-those with a payroll exceeding $200,000-spent nothing on structured training. This is a levy targetted to those employers, those not currently investing in training or investing very little.

The definition of training in the legislation is broad-not broad enough, I hope, to be fiddled, but broad enough, for example, for donations to training schemes in tertiary institutions to replace direct spending in the workplace. The proceeds of levies collected will be used to fund additional training activities. So it does not affect those already meeting their responsibilities.

One example I would like to give of an employer who is doing that is a very large company, the Ford Motor Co., whose factory at Campbellfield in my own State of Victoria not only provides a wide-ranging training program for all levels of its work force, but also shares its excellent facilities with technical and further education institutions and neighbouring industries. Other large operations would do well to follow Ford's example.

I support these Bills as a further step in ensuring that the cost burden for training is shared in an equitable way by a sector which has accepted the benefits of skilling without necessarily contributing to them. No doubt there will be attempts to circumvent the payment of the levy where applicable, just as the fringe benefits tax has sometimes been evaded by converting a business meal into `a seminar'. It will need to be monitored to ensure that the intent of the legislation is carried out. There are penalty clauses, for example, for failure to provide information or for the provision of false information, and those will be an added incentive to conform. I believe this is a missing piece in the education and training jigsaw and I hope it will neatly fit into the total picture.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight we are debating two pieces of legislation-the Training Guarantee Bill 1990 and the Training Guarantee (Administration) Bill 1990. The Australian Democrats welcome these pieces of legislation. When they were announced last year we welcomed them in principle. This year, when we saw the drafts, we welcomed the level of detail that the Government had put into them. We believe that all employers need to accept responsibility for training their employees. I acknowledge that to date a very large number of Australian firms have already recognised the great value of training to their industry and to their particular businesses. Many Australian firms have embarked on substantial training programs. I have great admiration for these firms and the work that they have done. In many instances they are world leaders in methodologies and approaches to training.

SPEECH.PARA: Unfortunately, however, there are still some employers who devote little or no time, money or effort to this task. Some rely on the public education system to perform this role for them, while others simply poach staff from other employers who have spent their money on training. It is primarily these particular firms to which this legislation applies. The training guarantee will ensure that there is a more equitable distribution of costs of training across all employers in Australia. Those employers who have, to date, been having a free ride on others will cease to do so when this legislation comes into effect.

The Bills that we have before us are, as was mentioned by the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) in his second reading speech, the result of extensive consultation and negotiation. This negotiation has taken place not only between the Government and other bodies, but also between the Australian Democrats and a whole range of industrial and academic bodies throughout Australia.

The draft Bills which were released by the Government in February this year represented a welcome approach to dealing with these types of matters. The Australian Democrats, having read those Bills, fully supported the overall thrust of the legislation; but we saw what we believed were major inadequacies in the then proposed Bills which we believe worked against industry and threatened the effectiveness of the legislation to achieve its desired aim. The Democrats recognise that the nature of this legislation is such that the support of industry is absolutely essential for its effective implementation.

As party spokesperson on employment, education and training, I undertook a range of meetings with a whole group of bodies throughout Australia to see what their concerns were with the draft legislation that they had had in their hands for some time. Those meetings were very revealing to me because they showed the enormous support and regard that industry has for training. This is something which is extremely welcome and augurs well for the future of this country. The other concerns that industry had were those that we had, having read the draft legislation. As a consequence of those discussions, I was able to undertake further discussions with representatives of the Department of Employment, Education and Training and with the Minister, in which I set out what I believed was a regime that we would be able to follow and which would have the support of industry.

These particular suggestions were accepted by the Government and I think those changes now have increased markedly the efficiency of this legislation and provide a much more conducive environment in which training can be conducted. Included in these changes are the following: the partial devolution of responsibility for the Bill's administration away from the Australian Taxation Office to the registered peak industry bodies; the inclusion of a depreciation clause for capital expenditure on training; exemption from some of the more specific requirements of the Bill for those firms which can demonstrate that they already have and will continue to have an exceptional commitment to training; and the inclusion of a variety of items such as study leave, occupational health and safety and industrial relations as eligible training programs.

However, in terms of the draft legislation, perhaps the greatest concern that I had was the assumption of responsibility for the operation by the Taxation Office. This concern, I must admit, stemmed from a number of grounds, not the least of which is the administration by the Taxation Office of the taxation deductions for self-education expenses which over the years have become so narrow and so restrictive as to become almost non-existent in terms of their original effect. I did not believe that the Taxation Office was the relevant office or had the relevant expertise to deal with this matter. I rather thought that the Taxation Office's involvement in this should be restricted to its area of responsibility; that is, if in fact a claim had been made for an eligible amount of expenditure, the Taxation Office was obviously the department responsible to check simply that that expenditure had been expended. In the original draft of the legislation the Taxation Office's operation would have gone much further than that. In addition to that proposition, one of my priorities-I believe it was the priority of the Government as well-was to have a minimum amount of bureaucracy involved with regard to the establishment of this particular piece of legislation.

The proposed alternative, which is now in the legislation before the Senate, allows the peak industry bodies to become registered for the purposes of some of the Tax Office's former duties under the draft legislation. These bodies will now be authorised to advise on guidelines for eligible training expenditure; to deal with issues of interpretation with respect to the definition of training; and to approve individual firms' training programs as eligible training programs for the purposes of the legislation.

I am very glad that the Government saw the value of this particular alternative scheme because I think it was that one move which brought on side a very large number of people in industry who had previously been prepared to undertake a very noisy and possibly effective campaign against this legislation. The fact that they did not go ahead with that was due to the fact that they saw this change put the exercise of this particular legislation back into their hands, as people who had been responsible to date for the training in their own industry and who, under the legislation, would be able to be responsible for the continuation of training within their particular industries.

In practice, then, an individual firm can now go to its industry body at the beginning of the financial year with specific details of training programs it wants to undertake in the coming year. Its industry body will be able to examine those particular proposals and before any time or money is spent it will be able to say that those proposals are acceptable. Where an employer's training proposal is appropriate, the industry training body will be able to issue a certificate stating that this is the case. Then if, for example, the Tax Office for whatever reason decides to conduct an audit, all these firms will need to do is show that they have spent the prescribed amount.

Unfortunately, under the draft legislation initially put forward there would have been great uncertainty. One would not have known until the Australian Taxation Office had knocked back one's expenditure that one had a problem. Then there was provision for an appeal to the relevant training body, which would then advise the Tax Office. There was great uncertainty in that mechanism for employers, who, when expending their time and money, want to have great certainty that that time and money will be expended in a way that is acceptable from the outset, rather than at the end.

Suitable industry bodies to perform these tasks are already in existence in Australia and have welcomed the opportunity to be involved in this matter. They have the capacity. In many cases they have been performing this task with excellent results. Of course, everybody recognises that they are the people with the relevant expertise who are able to say within their particular industry what is eligible training and what is not. What we have here is an option for employers; it is not a compulsion. They may well continue to deal direct with the Tax Office through those procedures if they wish to do so. However, it is highly unlikely that many employers will choose to do so.

The Minister has stated, in his second reading speech, that the scheme for registered industry bodies will be up and running by 1 January 1991. In the coming months the Minister will be looking to the development of guidelines governing this scheme. I make a number of suggestions in that regard. It seems to me that the criteria used in determining eligibility for registration need to be fairly stringent to ensure that the legislation will be implemented in the intended manner. Included in these criteria, as an absolute minimum, should be items such as the recognition as a peak industry body or a relevant industry body, a demonstrated commitment to training-which I think almost every one of the relevant industry bodies in Australia has-and the capacity to administer that, which most industry bodies are very happy to undertake.

The favourable reaction to this exercise now means that the big stick approach, which admittedly the Government has used in this legislation, will cease to have quite the wallop that it was initially seen as having and will now be more an exercise of working together with a vast range of employers in this country. I admit that a number of employers will still be forced to pay the levy: that is, they will not meet the one per cent exercise. However, I believe that this will be only a short term situation. I see absolutely no reason whatsoever, in this legislation, nor in the response that industry has now given to the new piece of legislation before us, as to why a complete phasing out of any money from industry should not be able to take place within the next two years. I believe that the relevant industry bodies will be keen to make sure that no group within their industry will be paying the levy. That means that we now have a far more cooperative approach, a far more supportive approach. The response that I have had so far leads me to believe that we are now on the right track and that this particular proposal is off to a good start.

To complement the industry-based scheme, the Democrats have also proposed that firms which have already shown a strong commitment to training of their staff should be given the freedom to continue with their established training programs without the necessity for further training approval.

If one looks around Australia, one is aware that a number of firms, mainly very large ones, see training as relevant to their market niche. In fact, a number have expressed to me that they see training, their commitment to it, the way they have gone about it and their willingness to put resources into it as the reasons why they are the leaders in their field.

I believe that it is possible to identify those firms. It ought to be possible for an agreement to be reached between the individual firms and the relevant national body which will be chosen to administer this so that those firms can be exempted from the exercise. Of course, we would be looking at firms which spend in excess of one per cent; normally, these spend much more than one per cent. They would have had this commitment over a number of years. Typically, they would even have a section or department within their corporate structure devoted to this task. Many of the large firms in Australia already have that set-up, as honourable senators will know.

In my discussions with the Minister, he has acknowledged that he thinks this would be a very valuable way to proceed. I ask the Minister to give a firm undertaking that the Government will enable such a scheme to take place and that those firms which wish to avail themselves of it and which already have an excellent training program will then be able to say to their shareholders not that they have operated with regard to the requirements of this legislation, but that they are such good trainers that there is no need for this legislation to apply to them and that they have reached an agreement with the Government on that basis.

Many of these firms have expressed to me that training is seen as one of their shining glories and not something which is thrust upon them by government. Certainly in the discussions I have had with the Minister it has been apparent that the Government well recognises the valuable contribution that many of these firms have made to the development of training in this country and in no way wishes to impede the excellent work that is already being done.

In addition to those general major changes with regard to accountability and methodology, the Democrats also negotiated with the Government other minor changes which are worthy of note. First, we have now incorporated into this Bill a depreciation clause for capital expenditure on training. In the draft legislation, it was proposed that capital expenditure on training would be eligible expenditure only if it could be claimed in the year when it occurred. The Democrats believe that this would have placed a disincentive in the way of firms which wished to go down the line of computer-based training as this would obviously involve a significant capital investment on a one-off basis. So in the legislation we have a new clause 26 which provides that capital expenditure on buildings or depreciable property used for training can be claimed either in the year it occurs or over a number of years, as under the normal regimes in the Income Tax Assessment Act.

A further amendment initiated by the Democrats involves the evaluation process in a structured training program. The initial proposal put forward by the Government in this regard was really far too onerous in terms of the possibilities of training. While the Democrats believe that it is vital that any training program be able to identify the goals that it wishes to achieve and to know if they have been achieved at the end of the exercise, we believe that the proposal in the first draft was so restrictive as to rule out a considerable number of programs.

Indeed, I think that many of the comments that Senator Durack made were directed at the original draft; certainly, they do not go to the draft which we have before us. There is no restriction on those programs. I found it strange that Senator Durack made the claim that the normal processes by which training has gone on in this country were ruled out by the legislation. They are specifically included in the legislation. What has been ruled out is the exercise whereby somebody is simply popped into an office or in front of a lathe and told, `Go to it, that is your training'. That is not allowable and could not be allowable under any circumstances. I do not think that anybody in his right mind would say-certainly I have never met anybody in industry who would-that that is good training.

We know that many things have gone on under the heading of training in industry that most industry bodies have been trying to stamp out for a long period. What has been offered to some people has been appalling. When one reads some of the reports on occupational health and safety, one realises that the level of industrial accidents in this country is often due to the lack of training for people coming onto the job. Industry does not accept that waving at people and saying, `Go to it', is training. It knows that what the employer puts in determines what he gets out, and that expenditure on individuals is probably one of the most productive expenditures that any company can undertake.

Obviously the expected program outcomes need to be set in place, and the means of identifying the extent to which the program has enhanced the participant's activity are clearly formulated. That is what industry does when it undertakes training, and that is what this legislation merely mirrors. That is what goes on in training across the board. It may very well be that these things have not been formulated in those precise terms, but that is what people do. The reason employers send their staff off to courses is to increase their productivity. When the staff return there is an evaluation process by the employer. The employer will not fork out hard-earned dollars to send somebody else on another course unless he knows that the original operation was a success. All that has been put down in the legislation is a formulation of what goes on in good training practice within industry. Indeed, industry has not raised any problems with me about the new formulation. It is happy with that and sees it as mirroring what, in fact, is a good practice.

The final amendments brought about in the legislation in terms of the propositions that I put to the Minister deal with the matters to which I have already referred. For example, question marks over items such as occupational health and safety, industrial relations, study leave and the like, have now been fixed up. The various groups which had a concern about those matters-and indeed many other people; lawyers and so on-have now found that the new legislation, which has passed the House of Representatives and is now before the Senate tonight, deals with those matters in an acceptable way.

There are a number of other items that I wish to raise in the committee stage with regard to specific exercises. I propose merely to flag a couple at this stage. First of all, I refer to the discrepancies in payroll tax. As honourable senators know, the States have different payroll tax requirements for employment agencies, which is one of the matters that has been raised by Senator Durack. When we get to the committee stage, I would be interested to have the Government's response on a number of those matters.

I am also particularly interested in the types of discussions that the Government may have had with the States. Because of the obvious constitutional prohibitions, we have a situation of being able to deal with the States other than as a single entity under the Crown. State departments-that is, the various departments of, say, education, training, housing, and so on at the State level-are, for constitutional purposes, probably to be regarded as a single entity. I want to know whether or not the Commonwealth Government has had discussions with the State governments on this matter. The Commonwealth Government, of course, will be able to treat each of its departments-as it does with the fringe benefits tax-as a discrete employer. That may not be the case at the State level. I wonder whether progress has been in terms of any discussions.

I am also interested in the Government's discussions with the trade union movement, among others, as to the problems of equity in terms of training-that is, how we may be able to assist the spread, across the board, of the training dollar so that it does not congregate, for example, in the most highly skilled and highly trained areas which, despite what Senator Durack said, do spend a considerable amount on training. The continual need to upgrade one's professional qualifications and to stay with the profession as it moves very rapidly is very expensive. Indeed, the professions tend to spend far more than anyone else on training. How are they going to continue to do that?

TALK.START.PARA: —But who is, in fact, eligible?
—Senator Durack knows that even in his profession law firms spend a considerable amount on this.
—But does it come within `eligible training'?

—It certainly does because if a law firm cannot in fact read this particular legislation to make sure that it comes within this scheme, I would take my business away from that particular law firm. There is absolutely no problem with every one of these types of training, including seminars, coming within the structured training.

SPEECH.PARA: I am also interested in the matter of confidentiality. What I did discover in my discussions, as I have already outlined, is that a very large number of companies in Australia are very proud of their training programs. They see them as things they have developed themselves: in other words, that they have a proprietary right to those programs and believe that if they were out there in the marketplace, their market advantage would be dissipated. Therefore, they are particularly concerned that no operations of this legislation should impact upon them in such a way that the details of their training programs would become matters of general knowledge within either their industry or wider still, otherwise their market advantage of relying upon those programs would be dissipated.

In closing, I would like to flag the problem that I see arising from recent ruling No. MT2046 of the Taxation Commissioner with regard to tax exempt employers-that is, educational institutions, trade unions, and the like, which pay an employee's higher education contribution scheme (HECS) charge. The ruling was that they will now have to pay a fringe benefits tax on this. I am concerned that this will create a distortion whereby public institutions will be placed at a disadvantage vis-a-vis private institutions. In other words, when the HECS legislation, the fringe benefits tax, and this legislation are put together, an anomaly exists. I would like the Minister's response as to how the Government intends to deal with that anomaly so that public institutions are not placed at a disadvantage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The contribution I make this evening to the debate on the Training Guarantee (Administration) Bill and the Training Guarantee Bill centres primarily on the scenario for the introduction of this package of Bills, it having been done with almost complete ignorance of the particular needs of particular industries in respect of training; the Government's seeming abandonment of its former confidence that extra training through the nation would come as a consequence of award restructuring; and, lastly, the business and economic climate not being appropriate for this sort of levy in any event at this stage.

SPEECH.PARA: However, before doing that I make some remarks with respect to the two previous speakers, Senator Macklin and Senator Zakharov. Senator Macklin, who I notice has just left the chamber, made one remark to which I make some reference. He suggested that he had put to the Government that those firms who were now investing a large amount in training effectively should be let be, that there should be no further approval requirements for those firms. It is easy at first glance to see some merit in that sort of suggestion if, of course, it is possible to identify these people-and I noted that Senator Macklin made some remarks as to the criteria he would think were appropriate to identify which firms should be able to get some sort of exemption.

With respect to his suggestion, I say two things. Firstly, he seems to be suggesting that we take no further interest in the type of training that companies that are now spending an adequate amount on training are doing, that whatever training they are doing will be satisfactory, and they will not have to comply with this legislation, so they can go on their merry way; but that we should take an interest in the manner in which companies that are not now spending are training. That is an inconsistent approach to take.

If this Bill is to proceed, either we care about the manner in which the training is implemented on a firm by firm basis and we require them all to satisfy certain criteria before they can get some acknowledgment that that is money being spent on training or we do not. There is no justification for saying, `Because you were in the pool a few years ago and you have been doing not too bad a job, it is okay, we will not worry, we will just leave you be'. That is the first problem I have, in a general sense, with some of Senator Macklin's remarks.

Secondly, the mere suggestion that we ought to do that highlights one of the problems of this package, and that is the difficulty of compliance. If it were so simple to comply, what benefit would there be in suggesting to these companies that they could gain some sort of exemption because they had been good in the past? If they had been really good and this legislation did not present some sort of difficulty for business to comply with, then there would be no benefit in Senator Macklin's suggestion, albeit that I see initial merit in the remarks he made.

Madam Acting Deputy President, I now turn to some remarks that you yourself made. As I noted your speech, you said that this side of the chamber was being critical of this proposal. Your assessment was that some eight years ago, when we were last in office, we had not done much vis-a-vis training and certainly had not got it right. Of course, when we were last in government people who are now able to vote were 10 years of age. I am not sure whether they were born when we last came into government. For a government to be looking back that far rather than forward is perhaps not really productive. What was happening when they were born or when they were 10 is not relevant to young people voting today.

Secondly, Madam Acting Deputy President, you said that this legislation was targeted to making those not now making a contribution or making little or no effort cough up and make some sort of contribution to the nation's training investment. As I recall, the remark was made that small business was going to be exempted from this by means of the salary cut-off point at which this little package will interrupt business, but that in any event that was okay because it was doing a good job.

Madam Acting Deputy President, you raised exactly one of the points made by Senator Durack and that no doubt other speakers will raise, and that is that small business does, in some cases, do a very good job of training. But if we were to test his remarks-were we able to test them empirically-I doubt that we would find that small business is engaging in structured, formal training programs that would qualify under this legislation. Of course, you must know that to be the case if you reflect on your remarks.

We all know that small business engages very heavily in informal one-to-one training. An employee goes to the boss and says, `Look, I've got a problem. I've mucked this up. What do I do?'. There is no structure or schedule to that sort of training. The boss gives the employee 10 minutes, half an hour or an hour, as the case may be. That is the case whether one is a plumber, a bricklayer or, as Senator Durack says, a solicitor.

In the brief time I was practising there were many occasions when I went to senior partners seeking some sort of advice not on a particular matter but on the conduct of those types of matters in general. I was seeking in-general training and guidance. With respect to what Senator Macklin said, I do not think that it is necessarily possible for solicitors, accountants, professionals and tradespeople alike to structure their one-to-one training in such a way that it will all qualify under this Bill. The very nature of one-to-one training-its immediacy, being available when someone needs some help and not according to some pre-determined bureaucratic program or schedule-precludes it from easily fitting into that category. I take issue with the remarks made about that.

Further remarks were made that the excess of the collections of this levy-the firms that do not spend the appropriate amount have to make it up and pay that amount in the form of a levy-will be allocated to community training. We have found this Holy Grail of community training-all that really matters is that we train the community; it does not matter what we train them in!

I notice by your expression that you, Madam Acting Deputy President, think that I am inferring that that is your attitude; I am not. That is my attitude. It is my assessment of the Government's general attitude rather than yours personally. What will it come to? Will we have technical and further education courses, for example, for women's surfboards. At one stage this Government thought that was an important priority for taxpayers' funds. I would like to know whether it thinks it is a priority for training. Perhaps we can have a couple of courses running up and down the Gold Coast for people to learn how to make women's surfboards. I would like to hear more about the guidelines for what those funds would be used for.

Additionally, Madam Acting Deputy President, you made some remarks about business being short-sighted. There are businesses that are short-sighted and in for the fast buck. Sure there are. But that is not what the Australian business community has prospered from. Quite the contrary; they are the sorts of businesses that fall by the wayside. I make the passing remark that for any Government member to criticise business for being in for the short term opportunity, when one looks at the short term opportunities that this Government has taken over the past seven or eight years, almost defies belief. Were there more time I would outline for honourable senators a very long list of examples of the short term opportunistic decisions taken by this Government. So for a Government member to be pointing the finger at business strikes me as being somewhat extraordinary.

Madam Acting Deputy President, you quite rightly pointed out that there would be a need to monitor this program to make sure that there was compliance. In doing so, you touched on one of our concerns about this very program, namely, that it will have a hoard of people implementing it, the costs of which may in any event outweigh the real benefits that some people believe will come from the legislation.

I note that you, Madam Acting Deputy President, also referred to the penalty clauses being deceitful in terms of how much money the Government was spending on training and the like. In doing so, you invited attention to a particular clause that might be more fully debated in the committee stage. I want to refer briefly to clause 85 of the Bill, under the heading `Part 9-Penalty Charge', which says:
If:
(a) an employer other than a government body:
(i) makes a statement that is false . . .

It then outlines the consequences of that. Just briefly, I would like to refer to the exemption for government bodies. I would like to know-perhaps a Government speaker following would be able to answer this point-whether government bodies are not going to have to comply with this legislation, in which case we wonder why there is an exemption for misleading statements, or whether some government bodies, statutory authorities, et cetera, are going to have to comply, and why they are therefore entitled to such an exemption. I do not for the life of me see why a private enterprise employer should be banned from making misleading statements and a government body should not. I see every reason why both should be prevented from making misleading statements.

I realise that that particular clause relates to misleading statements in terms of the amounts of money that have been spent on training. It relates to the collection aspect. That clause, in the sense that it relates to misleading statements, does not relate to misleading statements in general to anybody about the training capacity of a particular firm. It is quite specific-misleading statements to particular types of people about particular sorts of things. And it is a good thing that that is the case.

Were that not the case and were government bodies to be responsible for misleading statements in some sort of retrospective way, it would invite attention to the sorts of misleading statements that were issued by this Government in August 1985. I think it might even have been Minister Dawkins or perhaps Minister Willis who introduced the much publicised Priority One scheme. We all remember that-`Youth of Australia: No. 1 Priority'. We saw billboards across the nation with Bob Hawke's smiling face coming out, saying, `Youth of Australia; you're our No. 1 priority', telling people to telephone the nearest college and get in on the Priority One training scheme. I had technical and further education colleges on the telephone saying, `We do not know anything about this'. It was a classic example of someone saying, `Would it not be good if we marketed ourselves as a government that was interested in training?'. In this case it was not training across the board for the whole nation but for young people in particular.

A whole marketing exercise for this Government, based on the concept of `we are interested in training', was introduced. A fortune was spent on it when the detail of implementing the scheme had not been worked out. What did we find? We had a Prime Minister who promised with confidence, a promise conveniently forgotten now because it was made in 1985-half a decade ago-that by 1988-89 there would be 75,000 Australian traineeships per annum.

Leaflets were distributed through the community, raising the expectations of young Australians. What happened? Because the detail of the program was not properly worked out to start with, by the standards that the Prime Minister set-75,000 traineeships per annum-it was an unmitigated disaster. The Government had not worked out training courses applicable to particular industries. There was just a general notion of `let's train young people'. It had not worked out a traineeship for the banking sector, or a traineeship for the transport sector, et cetera. While all the young people who saw these advertisements telephoned trying to get in on these schemes, the Government had not sorted out the detail on a per industry basis.

The Government should have learnt something from that. It should have learnt that it is a mistake to blow the trumpet about what it is doing about training before it has worked out the details, as is the case in this particular Bill. More importantly, it should have learnt that training needs to differ industry by industry and level of industry by level of industry. The concept of `let's train in general, let's make people pay' is really very unsophisticated. It said, `Let's make everybody pay one per cent for training'. I should correct myself. The Government is not saying, `Let's make everybody pay one per cent for training'. The Government is saying, `Let's make business pay'. It is the old left wing view that businesses profit and that therefore the profits should be snatched off them; they must contribute to the profit they make. There was no acknowledgment that everybody benefits from training-not just the business community.

Some of the motivation for this Bill is misguided. It is targeted at the business community, which is seen as the rich, and the attitude is let them pay. With respect to targeting, as you pointed out, Madam Acting Deputy President, small businesses are excluded, and big businesses, as Senator Macklin pointed out, are already spending a lot of money. So we are actually imposing a levy on businesses in the middle, irrespective of their level within industry. It is a sort of make business pay and do not worry about the details approach.

I wonder why we do not ask doctors to pay some sort of additional levy on top of the Medicare levy. Doctors benefit from the Medicare system, so why do we not make them pay more? They are all getting a big slice out of Medicare. If one follows the Government's rationale that business is making money out of training and that therefore it ought to contribute to training, why do we not make specialists pay even more, because they benefit even more from the Medicare system? If it comes to that, why do we not ask lawyers to pay some sort of special levy because they are getting a benefit out of the legal aid system and the courts that we provide? The reason we do not do that is quite simple-everybody else is getting a benefit out of those systems. So why do we single out business in this respect?

It is an unhappy little scenario that has been painted by Government speakers in relation to this Bill in the first instance. I mention a further example-proof, if you like, of the Government's mentality that the object of this legislation is to make business pay and not to get good training outcomes. If a business decides that it is not appropriate for it to engage in a higher level of training than it already does-it might be a business that uses lowly skilled people and has no need of further training-it can make a donation to an appropriate tertiary institution and get a deduction for it. It is really a case of the Government saying, `It is too hard to work out who needs training and who does not so, instead of letting those who need training pay for it we are going to make everybody pay. Those who do not need training can pay by making a contribution to someone else's training'. That does not seem appropriate or fair.

There are four points I want to make. The first is that this whole package is being introduced on somewhat dubious grounds. The expectations and outcomes for particular industries have not been sorted out, so we are going into a general, `let's train' attitude without sorting out the specifics. That really is somewhat naive. We are abandoning the Government's original view that it would be appropriate for employees and employers to enter into voluntary training arrangements. The Director of the National Institute of Labour Studies at Flinders University in South Australia, Richard Blandy, says with respect to the Government's view:

. . . it is preferable for the direct beneficiaries of training, including both employers and employees in the private and public sectors, to make arrangements for funding the required increases in training expenditure.
In other words, it is preferable for them to make their own arrangements. That used to be the Government's view, but for some reason it has been disposed of.

Madam Acting Deputy President, you made some remarks with respect to the Australian Bureau of Statistics survey. I think you said that half of the people to whom this levy was going to apply were not paying anything. There has been some dispute as to the efficacy of that particular survey. Honourable senators may have seen a letter to the Australian Financial Review from Mr Spicer, the chief executive of the Confederation of Australian Industry. He said:
The overwhelming number of employers, 85 per cent of all firms, are small employers who would be totally exempt from the Government's training levy scheme anyway.
We have covered that point. This is targeted to a very small particular group of employers. But in particular he said:

The ABS survey indicated that employers with a wages bill of $200,000 or more, the figure at which the training guarantee will apply, spent an average of 2.4 per cent of their wages bill on formal training.

So there is some dispute as to the interpretation of that survey that you were referring to. As I say, the grounds are dubious. It requires a huge bureaucratic apparatus to keep this thing running, if it does get going, and on that basis it is inappropriate.

I have already made remarks about the second point that I want to focus on, and that is that while we would all want to see more training of the Australian work force in all sectors of the work force, it is not appropriate to achieve that end by simply saying, `If you do not spend more on training, you will have to pay and we will donate the money somewhere else'-`possibly to teach you how to make surfboards for women'. That is just not the appropriate way to go about it. It is not anywhere near as subtle as one would have expected from a government that has had eight years experience.
Different industries, of course, have different training requirements. As Mr Huxter, the industrial relations manager of the Chamber of Commerce and Industry is reported as saying:

There are some jobs where a week's training is sufficient and some where an hour's sufficient to skill a person to do that job. No amount of expenditure on training is going to make them do it better . . .

There are jobs like that. This particular package does not make allowances for that. The Business Council of Australia's submission to the Economic Planning Advisory Council on enterprise based training in 1989 had this to say:

There is a great variation in training investment between industries and also within industries, with investment of between 1% and 10% of payroll being the usual variation. Decisions of businesses are made in accordance with their own particular conditions. A uniform skill formation program will impliedly not cater for variety between firms. Minimum training expenditure through a levy will inevitably override the commercial judgment of people on the spot in business. There is a great potential for high administrative costs and uneven impact between firms.

I just come back to the point that through its own work place reform program the Government seems to be acknowledging the need for these sorts of things to be done on an enterprise level rather than an across-the-board level.

I conclude that point just by emphasising that this package does nothing to acknowledge the complexity and diversity in Australian industry and consequent complexity and diversity of training needs in Australian industry.

I emphasise that this Government has put out many press statements, and in Question Time in this chamber we have listened to answer after answer, about the importance of micro-economic reform and, in particular, award restructuring and the structural efficiency principle. We have read and heard again and again how part of this package of negotiations is for broadbanding, creating career paths and creating training opportunities as part of the award agreements. Yet we have a Government that, while it is doing that with one hand, seems to be saying on the other that there is a necessity to impose a levy. It seems to be expressing a total lack of faith in the award restructuring process and the benefits that the Government has been promising the community will come from that, including the consequent training packages that will be developed through that process of award restructuring.

So we have a Government putting forward two inconsistent propositions. One is, `It will be okay; we are in charge of micro-economic reform; we are moving more quickly to award restructuring; and through that you will get better career paths, broadbanding and better training opportunities built into the awards'. The same Government with the same mouth turns the other cheek and says, `But you are all so hopeless you will not spend any money on training so we had better impose this levy to make sure that you do'. Whilst the micro-economic reform of award restructuring will, quite sensibly, concentrate on training needs on an industry basis and, for that matter, in some cases on an enterprise basis, those on the other side who are oblivious to what is going on say, `We are not really interested in a per industry definition of training and its needs. We just want one per cent, full stop'. It seems to be an inconsistent approach.

Last but not least, I simply want to make a few remarks in relation to the impact of the levy, both on business and on consumer costs. There is no need to repeat some of the remarks that I have made, other than to refer honourable senators to them in the sense of the administrative cost that this program will impose on the business community-it is just another cost. The attitude is that the business community can pay and, what is more, it can pay to pay because it will have to accommodate the administrative costs incurred.

At the same time, there does not seem to be a sufficient explanation of why the imposition of a further cost on the business community will not be passed on to the consumer. After all, the business community is not the Salvation Army, and when it gets an extra cost it will, if it can, pass it on to the consumer. This point has been raised but has not yet been answered.

In conclusion, I wish to remind the Senate that I have seen this happen before: a hastily strung together package, designed to make the Government look as though it is doing something vis-a-vis training, without having worked out the details on an industry by industry basis, with great promises of what is yet to come and no expectations by the business community or this side of the chamber that it will happen. We saw that happen in 1985. We saw the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), whom we still have, promise with great confidence a training scheme for young Australians that was to involve 70,000 per annum. He even said it on television. He had a little program made of himself walking around with young people telling them what they would get. But they cottoned on pretty smartly and booed him our of a number of functions where he went to try to explain what his Priority One scheme was all about.

I have a cartoon for 1985 still on my wall which contains a caricature of the Prime Minister sitting at his desk filing his fingernails with a big rasp. He has a spiky-what I would call a hood-hairdo. Underneath the caricature are the words, `Youth of Australia, priority 2; don't call us, we'll call you'. That is exactly what is going to happen with this scheme. Something that is promised will not be delivered. It will be a total mess-up and the Government would do well to agree to refer the legislation to a Senate committee. If we must proceed with this levy the Government at least should fix up the problems that quite clearly exist and give industry some time to adapt to the demands made by the legislation. That would be the simple thing to do. If the Government is pig-headed enough to proceed with this proposal, it should at least be smart enough to get it fixed up so that it does not have egg on its face as a result of yet another failed promise to train Australians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Childs Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I enthusiastically welcome the long overdue introduction of the Training Guarantee (Administration) Bill 1990. The purpose of this Bill is to require employers to contribute a percentage equivalent to their payroll to training. Where an employer's spending on training is less than the required amount, he will be obliged to contribute the difference to a training guarantee fund. One of the most pressing problems facing Australian industry is the need for a more highly skilled work force-a work force that has been given, and has accepted, greater responsibility and authority. If Australia is going to be able to compete in the 1990s and beyond, training has to be an essential component of long term corporate strategies.

SPEECH.PARA: This Government has set out to make Australia the clever country. Although that is a slick statement, it nevertheless sums up the fact that we have to become more intelligent in the way that we do things. There must be a recognition that, to achieve this end, we must address all facets of education including schooling, tertiary and further education, universities and both on-the-job and structured off-the-job training. That is the area that has been neglected in Australia.

Developing a highly skilled work force is a complex process. Education plays a crucial role, by developing the talents and abilities of individuals and teaching some of the basic knowledge and skills used in employment. Industry training builds on this broad foundation to provide the skills required by workers and management to perform their jobs.

The need for Australia to increase its skills base is not new. In 1965-and that was in a period of conservative government-the report of the Committee of Economic Inquiry, which was known as the Vernon report, said:

Skilled labour, in our view is likely to be Australia's scarcest resource. Everything possible must be done to increase the supply of this resource . . . A cooperative attitude on the part of governments, unions, management and education authorities alike is essential.
Yet in 1990 we are still living with the legacy that reports such as the Vernon report have not been taken seriously enough, in terms of both formal education and industrial training.

When this Government came into power, the high school retention rate-the basis of education-was 36 per cent. It is now 60 per cent and it will shortly be 66 per cent. Although rising, Australia's high school retention rate is still low compared with our industrial competitors. The high school retention rate in Japan is 94 per cent; in America, 86 per cent; and in Sweden, 84 per cent. When we consider other things, such as only 7 per cent of the Australian work force having tertiary qualifications and only 26 per cent having trade or technical qualificatioins, then we can see many of the problems that we face and that are addressed by this particular measure.

It is estimated that industry-wide, firms spend the equivalent of just over 2 per cent of their annual payments on structured training. About one-third of firms spend little or nothing on such training. Whether or not that figure is exact, it is certainly a significant percentage of firms, and these are the firms that are targeted by this legislation.

There is almost universal agreement that Australian industry must become more internationally competitive as part of an overall adjustment strategy. Australian industry needs to modernise. Flexibility and speed in adapting to changing circumstances are key characteristics of successful economies. A highly skilled work force is essential to achieving this flexibility. The pace of technological advance is now so rapid and so institutionalised that those who are behind may never catch up. This is the threat, even to Australia at this moment.

Increases in job skills clearly facilitate the adoption of new technology. For many Australian enterprises, this requires a major break with the past. That is what this legislation is all about. We cannot continue with an industrial past, and I refer to industry because that is the area that I am most familiar with. We cannot continue with the Taylorist traditions that have been so much a part of our industry development in this country. Those concepts were derived and developed in the 1920s and are still with us. They have lead to mass production and a lowly skilled and tightly controlled work force becoming the dominant characteristics of our industry. They are long out of date and we cannot afford to cling to that style of business, to that style of organisation-to the giving of orders by powerful people through the layers of supervisors that are a characteristic of that inefficient method of industrial organisation, demonstrated by the resultant lack of initiative by people who are part of that system. What has been seen by management as its inalien- able right, management prerogative, is a characteristic of that system that is completely undemocratic and unsuitable for the world and the modern industry that we now need to have. Professor Ford, head of the program of organisational behaviour at the University of New South Wales, who I believe is one of the leading figures in this area and has been for 25 years, said:

The challenge for Australia is to reduce the boundaries-educational, functional, occupational, professional and trade-that are blocking the skill formation processes we need to achieve a productive culture.

If we look at overseas experience, we see that processes that we need to follow are being implemented in countries very close to us. If we look at the position in east Asia, we see that some nations have put enormous resources into skill formation-for example, Japan, Korea and Singapore. Australia is threatened far more at this moment by skill formation successes in those countries of east Asia than it is by a low wage structure. Unfortunately, that is the sort of thing that the Opposition has not faced up to yet.

Australian industry has for too long relied on external sources to meet its skills needs rather than on training or retraining its own employees and meeting the changed skill requirements that our industry has needed. They tend to shed labour with obsolete skills and hire workers with skills that are in demand. That is not good enough for the modern society and modern industry that we need in Australia at the moment. They rely on publicly funded training as a substitute for private sector investment in training. That is once again what this legislation seeks to correct.

I would like to draw upon my experience in and knowledge of the manufacturing industry to emphasise the importance of this legislation. The Senate Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology has presented two reports. In 1988 we presented one entitled Manufacturing Industry Revitalisation-Making it Together, and today I presented New Management Techniques in Manufacturing Industry-People and Technology. They are two reports that emphasise the need to revitalise the manufacturing industry in Australia. The economic imperatives for improvement in Australia's manufacturing performance are set out in those reports. It is a serious situation. Manufacturing as a percentage of gross domestic product is falling, with all the consequences to our standard of living that that implies. The level of Australia's trade deficit is subject to much attention. What is not often understood is that that deficit is really a manufacturing deficit. Seventy-two per cent of Australia's imports are composed of manufactured goods. That is part of the problem and it emphasises the need for import substitution in this country.

A further problem is the composition of Australia's manufactured exports. Only $4.5 billion of $20.5 billion of exports have a high value-added component. When one considers that about $16 billion of our exports relates to simply processed metals, sugar and other products with very little value-added manufacture, one can see the importance of Australia, as a country, making sure that we have the ability to raise workplace skills, the lack of which at the moment is a great impediment to Australian manufacturing revitalisation.

Simply put, not enough money is being invested in human capital in this country. This legislation is part of the process of investment that must occur. If Australia wishes to become industrially efficient and internationally competitive, we can no longer afford to regard organisation of the workplace and in-house and off the job training-in a sense, these are new words, unfortunately, to many people in Australia-to either not exist or exist as separate entities and not be interconnected in the way that they are approached.

Australia's goal must be to integrate work organisation and skills formation as much as possible so as to enable employees to upgrade, update and expand their abilities. This continual process of industrial development and innovation depends on the interrelationship of four factors: new technology; work organisation; industrial relations; and skill formation. It is the last point that this Bill is aiming to address, although, of course, none of the four headings that I mentioned can be looked at in isolation.

This Bill will require employers to spend a minimum amount on approved training, broadly defined. It is a targeted measure aimed at improving the efforts of firms which do not currently invest, or invest very little, in training. This particular aspect is worth highlighting. One of the most common reasons put forward for the lack of investment in training in Australia is poaching. Who are these employers who would poach staff? It is a very common development. The Australian word that describes this is bludging. A significant percentage of employers in this country bludge staff from the other sections of industry. Indeed, this Bill concentrates on a third of these people. I agree that the figures cannot be completely accurate, but it seems as though that is the best estimate of those employers who provide little or no training and rely on attracting skilled workers from firms that train their people.

Firms that will not invest in training but keep dipping into the pot of human capital that we have in this country are now going to have to face up to sharing the burden. The minimum training requirement is one per cent of annual national payroll for 1990-91. In 1991-92, it goes to 1.5 per cent of this amount for subsequent years. Employers will be exempt if their payroll for the year is less than the threshold level of $200,000, as has already been said in this debate. The training bill is a minimum spending requirement. It is not an industry average and for much of Australia's industry it is certainly not an optimum level of training and expenditure in the training area. We hope it will be a catalyst to make many employers-who are not bad people, but who have not realised that if they continue taking a selfish view as far as skill formation in this country is concerned they are going to suffer themselves-engage in training.

This is a targeted measure aimed at improving the effort of fims which do not currently invest in training or invest very little. I do not know why the Opposition is so upset about employers who until now have not faced up to their responsibilities. The Senate Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology went around many factories. We saw classic example after example of employers who were attempting to introduce new management techniques, who had trained their staff to a particular level, and then had them filched from them by employers down the street who had no commitment to improving the modern techniques that are so necessary. If we did not have the Government moving as it is on this occasion, that situation would go on for another 10 years because when the coalition parties were in power they made no effort to try to improve the general standards of training that we had in our work force.

We have now reached the point where this last facet of raising the standards of people in industry and service industries means that we have all the components in place to be able to use effectively the exciting things that are happening, such as award restructuring. Senator Vanstone disparaged award restructuring, but this measure also assists award restructuring because we will not punish the employers who are doing the right thing and who are trying to change the way that things have been done. We are now going to make it a fairly even field-perhaps even an even playing field, which appeals to a lot of people; certainly it has that characteristic.

The Opposition has criticised this proposal and it has criticised the unions. I would like to place on record the fact that trade unionists, through their trade unions, have made many sacrifices in recent years. To many of them this is an historic occasion. I well remember that at the Australian Council of Trade Unions Congress in 1987 the strategy of the trade union movement was laid down when it set the key recommendations of Australia Reconstructed in the need to increase investment in training. According to that report, Australia spends a lower proportion of gross domestic product on education and training than do the more economically successful countries. Most of the deficiency lies in privately funded-that is, firms and individuals-components of expenditure. Award restructuring, as the main focus of the trade union movement over the last few years, has created new opportunities and incentives for employers to invest in improving workplace skills.

For example, in the metal industry-perhaps the best example because it is the most advanced industry-the training strategy set in place new training and career systems for Australia's 500,000 metal industry employees. Those reforms integrate present in-house training options with those in the tertiary education sector, produce career paths based on a wide range of skills instead of individual trades, restructure the metal industry award, resulting in training and multiskilling becoming the chief criteria for metal industry wage-setting, and make it possible for employees to move from unskilled job classifications to positions requiring training and finally to the professional engineering and management posts.

That is a revolution that is taking place in the metal industry. It is absolutely appropriate that this legislation complement all these developments I have described in making sure that all industry shares the responsibility to create and develop the human capital that is this country's most precious resource. It is now time that business accepted greater responsibility for the development of that human capital. The responsibility for skills formation needs to be negotiated continually between the interested parties. There is no place for attitudes such as those expressed by the Business Council of Australia and some of the other employer organisations that have had a knee-jerk reaction to this proposal.

I am very confident that the things that are now being said-for example, that those organisations have been opposed to this legislation because it represents government interference in business-and all the usual things said by employers when facing new developments will not transpire. I am certain that if we review the situation in three, four or five years time when we have skilled our work force, when we have pressed ahead, as this Government is doing, with the general level of education in industry-I will certainly be happy to compare notes with Senator Vanstone then; I am sure we will both be here-we will find that the basis for manufacturing industry and service industries in this country is much more effective because of the passage of this legislation. We must not consider the Opposition's proposal, which is to try to shelve a project that has been in place and discussed by everyone who is interested for a long time. It is a last-minute tactic commonly used by the Opposition. It is attempting to push this off to yet another committee to prevent us having the benefit of this legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On that last point, I say to Senator Childs that it is very easy to talk on this topic. It is very easy to be lyrical about the benefit of training. We have heard much of this in the past from many sources, as he has pointed out. But tonight we are talking about the actual detail of the Training Guarantee (Administration) Bill. That is a very different matter from what the rhetoric of the past has indicated. We are talking about getting the legislation right. As with no other Bill in the past, this Bill should go to a committee so that we actually get it right, so that the rhetoric is put into effect and so that we achieve something.

SPEECH.PARA: Training would be the most popular topic anywhere one likes to go. The concept is very sound. Education and training are very dear to people's hearts. Look at the situation at present in the Australian Capital Territory where there is a threat of schools being closed. One can see the public response. It is a very emotive issue. But, at least, let us make sure that we get the legislation right.

Firstly, I hope that when the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support (Senator Collins) replies-at the end of the second reading stage or in the committee stage-he will tell us where the Commonwealth gets the power to introduce this legislation. This has been mentioned by previous speakers. Certainly, I believe that the Government needs to tell us the basis of the legislation. It is quite clear that the Government has a power to raise funds by way of taxation. If it is going to be honest, it will have to tell us that this legislation really introduces a Commonwealth payroll tax. It is yet another new tax introduced by the Commonwealth Government; it is a payroll tax.

It is worth referring to the report of the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills on the Training Guarantee (Administration) Bill. This Committee is one of the most respected committees, and it has brought down a report in which it makes a general comment in relation to clause 85, which I may refer to later and which Senator Vallentine referred to. The comment raises a very valid issue. The report states:
The Committee notes that the Bill contains a number of taxation legislation look-alike provisions.
I think the actual wording needs to be noted. It continues:
Provided that the Bill is meant to be seen in that light-
in other words, provided the Bill is meant to be a tax Bill-

most of them may be acceptable. Nevertheless, the Committee makes the following observations: (a) Clause 60 provides that on review or appeal the burden of proving that an assessment is excessive lies on the employer . . .
This is a different onus of proof from what most of us believe should be the case. It continues:
(b) Clause 70 provides that the fact that a review or appeal is pending does not affect the effect of the assessment or prevent the recovery of the charges or additional charges;
(c) Clause 77 provides for substituted service of documents in relation to recovery of charges and service. . .

It then talks about clause 83, clause 97 and clause 98. To save the time of the Senate, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the report of the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills in relation to this Bill.
Leave granted.
The report read as follows-
TRAINING GUARANTEE (ADMINISTRATION) BILL 1990
This Bill was introduced into the House of Representatives on 10 May 1990 by the Minister for Employment, Education and Training.
The Bill proposes to provide for the administration of the scheme set up by the Training Guarantee Bill 1990.
General Comment

Clause 85 provides that if an employer other than a government body makes false or misleading statements, the employer has to pay by way of penalty an additional training guarantee charge. While the Committee notes that this is not a criminal liability, it means that a government body is immune from penalty in respect of such statements. The Committee seeks the Minister's explanation as to why this apparent immunity is necessary.

The Committee notes that the Bill contains a number of taxation legislation look-alike provisions. Provided that the Bill is meant to be seen in that light, most of them may be acceptable. Nevertheless, the Committee makes the following observations:
(a) Clause 60 provides that on review or appeal the burden of proving that an assessment is excessive lies on the employer;
(b) Clause 70 provides that the fact that a review or appeal is pending does not affect the effect of the assessment or prevent the recovery of the charges or additional charges;

(c) Clause 77 provides for substituted service of documents in relation to recovery of charges and service can be effected on an absentee or someone who cannot be found by posting to the last known address, without leave of the court;

(d) Clause 83 provides for service on the public officer of a trust estate and clause 83 (2) provides that, if there is no public officer, service on a person acting or appearing to act in the business of the trust estate is sufficient;

(e) Clause 97 provides that the production of a notice of assessment or a copy thereof is conclusive evidence of its making and that the particulars are correct, except for the purposes of review or appeal. The clause also provides that the production of certain documents, certificates or training guarantee statements are prima facie evidence. Clauses 97 (2), (4) and (5) use the phrase `prima facie evidence', whereas clause 97 (3) merely uses `evidence'; and

(f) Clause 98 provides for access to premises and documents and permits an authorised officer to inspect and copy documents. The authorised officer can do so upon the production of a written authority from the Commissioner of Taxation and does not require a search warrant issued by a judicial officer.

TALK.START.PARA: —It raises important questions which the Government must answer before this goes much further. We are dealing with a payroll tax Bill which sets the level at which tax will be paid at the sum of $200,000, which is a considerably different figure from payroll taxes levied by the States at the present time. We are talking about a tax on businesses which have some eight to 10 employees. The businesses will pay one per cent this year, 1990, and 1 3/4 per cent after 1992.

SPEECH.PARA: When one looks into the Bill, one finds that it is to commence on 1 July 1990. That is pretty soon. Small business is already overburdened with paperwork imposed by this Government and State governments. One would expect to be able to look at the Bill and find out exactly what a firm has to do on 1 July 1990 to ensure that it complies with the legislation. But that is not the case. The Bill is dotted throughout with guidelines that might be brought down some time in the future. There is nothing in the second reading speech which indicates when the guidelines will be available. I do not imagine that they will be available by 1 July so that people will actually know what this Bill is about. If they are not available by 1 July of this year, then the operation of the Bill should be deferred until such time as people are able to know what they are doing, whether the schemes they are operating at present are proper training schemes which would exempt them from paying this tax, and are able to get advice from their accountants and lawyers.

Madam Acting Deputy President, I want you to tell Senator Childs that the reason why this Bill should be deferred to a committee is so that the guidelines can be seen, looked at and worked out so that we know what we are imposing on businesses. They are entitled to know. People suggest that the legislation can come into effect on 1 July this year and be operated upon by businesses when it is clear on the face of the document that the rules have not been worked out-they certainly have not been brought to this chamber, tabled or made subject to disallowance. Anybody who supports the operation of the legislation right now has never had anything whatsoever to do with the running of a business because anybody who has would know the difficulty that is being imposed on those who are attempting to do so.

We are not against training and the opportunities it will provide. Other speakers have already referred to the extent to which it is going on. It may well be that there is good reason to look at why there has been no training in some areas in the past. There is a benefit of education and benefit from training skills.

I noted that some of the speakers-Senator Childs, Senator Zakharov or Senator Macklin-talked about the Bill being designed to stop poaching. They seemed to be concerned that one employer may train people and then find that they are poached by another firm, and that that is a disincentive to train. We might look at it from the point of view that if employers are obliged or forced to train their staff beyond the level at which they are required to carry out their duties in that firm they really are inviting other people to take them. How much training can one give to a cleaner or a housemaid who makes the beds in an hotel? I will come back to them a bit later on because I think there are some questions that I want to understand in relation to the contents of the Bill about training people in these occupations.

The level of training that one might give to somebody who is totally unskilled and the level of additional training which may be appropriate for a professional person does not seem to have been thought through. A solicitor who perhaps has been in practice for 25 years would benefit from going back into some educational program on a part time basis for a time. This would increase his skills, bring him up-to-date with new legislation, and things such as that. Accountants will need to go to school to work out what we are talking about with this Bill if it goes through without the benefit of it being examined by a Senate committee. When one reads the legislation, one sees that the training program will undoubtedly be enormously costly to administer. No economic impact statement has been presented with the documents, the second reading speech, or anything else that I have seen, that really deals with the costs of it. The second reading speech refers to the costs. It states:
All revenue net of administration and monitoring costs will be disbursed to the States and Territories . . .

But we do not get precise figures as to what the costs are likely to be. I ask the Minister to tell us what the costs are expected to be. If one looks at the number of things in the legislation, one sees that the costs will undoubtedly be quite considerable. That again is a matter of interest to the Senate when trying to assess the benefits of a program such as this.
Let us look at the Bill and some of the clauses that are in it. I just want to touch on some of the things that I hope will be answered. I note in passing that clause 9 (2) states:
Nothing in this Act permits the Crown to be prosecuted for an offence.

Why is that? When I was young and studying history and other subjects at school we were told that the King was not to be above the law. Why is it now that the Crown is legislated to be above the law? I think that is a very serious matter. It is the sort of thing that keeps creeping in. It is time we knew why the Crown is above the law in this day and age.
Part 3 of the Bill is entitled `Eligible Training Expenditure and Programs'. Clause 25 defines the meaning of eligible training expenditure and states:
Eligible training expenditure of an employer is expenditure incurred by the employer that is directly attributable solely or principally to eligible training programs.

There is an example and definitions that go on and on. I wonder what this means for a legal firm that has articled clerks. Can a firm deduct the cost of the wages of its articled clerks because it is a training program?

TALK.START.PARA: —They might get paid more.

—They are not likely to be able to live on much less. What about the cost of seminars that professional people attend? What will be the criteria for those who are administering the program in determining whether the conditions for the programs have been met or not?

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable senators who have read only Senator Robert Ray's second reading speech and not read the Bill might think that the Government was inviting employers to have a say in what happens. The second reading speech states:
The Government believes that employers should spend the money themselves in ways in which they consider will maximise productivity or contribute more generally to the skills of the workforce.
It goes on:
The Training Guarantee is in fact a charge on the failure to train.
Presumably, this is the Government's way of trying to say that it is not a tax. I repeat:
The Government believes that employers should spend the money themselves in ways in which they consider will maximise productivity or contribute more generally to the skills of the workforce.

But when we read the legislation we find that it is a different thing altogether.
