Perhaps some of those who have extolled the virtues of what the Government is talking about have merely read the second reading speech and have not gone through the Bill which is now before us, which we will have a chance to go through in more detail when we get to the committee stage-if the Senate does not send the Bill to a committee for closer examination.

I again raise the question of training a housemaid who is to work in a hotel. What about all the other staff of the hotel? Is that a deduction which it would be able to make? The Bill gives examples of eligible training expenditure of an employer as including expenditure incurred by the employer by way of salary or wages paid to an employee that is directly attributable to a period during which the employee was solely or principally engaged in participating in an eligible training program. The extent to which on-the-job training is a part of it is not clear. As I say, we may come to that later, or a committee will.
Proposed section 26 (d) (i) (B) of the Bill, referring to eligible expenditure, states:
contributions payable or paid under Chapter 4 of the Higher Education Funding Act 1988 . . .

Is that telling us that if one studies as an engineer and graduates from university, as a consequence acquires a liability to pay graduate tax, and then goes to work for somebody who says, `I will pay your graduate tax; that gets me off the hook for a training program and it gets you off the hook for your graduate tax', the Government receives only one lot of money from the employer who is taking it off his training tax rather than both of them being able to pay that sum? I hope the Minister will tell us what loss there will be from the graduate tax as a consequence of that being an eligible training deduction. It is one of the other questions that I think could well be looked at. It has not been dealt with and, again, it leads me to conclude that the Bill would be better examined by a Senate committee. We are not challenging training, as Senator Childs seems to think we are doing.
It is also worth turning the page and looking at clause 27 (2) of the Bill. It says:
A training program is a structured training program if it satisfies the following conditions . . .

I remind the Senate that the Government believes that employers should spend the money themselves in ways that they consider will maximise productivity and contribute more generally to the skills of the work force, but now we find that `a training program is a structured program if it satisfies the following conditions'. It goes on:
(a) the program is designed or approved by a person-
not the employer-
who is appropriately qualified-
not defined-
or experienced to design a training program of the relevant type . . .
It has nothing to do with what the employer thinks is best for his business. It goes on:
(b) the skills to be acquired by the participants in the program are clearly identified before the program begins;
(c) the means of imparting the skills to the participants are clearly identified before the program begins;
(d) before the program begins:
(i) the expected program outcomes are clearly formulated; or
(ii) the means of identifying the extent to which the program has enhanced the participants' productivity are clearly formulated.

The paperwork involved in having all this written down so that one is able to meet an audit, if an audit is decided upon by the Commissioner of Taxation, is horrendous. All this would have to be in writing before the thing got under way at all. It goes on:
Subject to subsection (4), a training program may be an eligible training program whether or not:
(a) It is provided personally by the employer concerned; and
(b) it consists of or includes on-the-job training.
It cannot include any generally supervised practice or work experience. I am amazed why that should be the case.

It then deals with apprentices and goes on to a number of other things. Clause 30 refers to all the guidelines that have to exist before the Act can actually operate properly. Notwithstanding the fact that those guidelines are not available, we are being asked to pass this Bill now and have it come into operation on 1 July 1990. If the Government wants this Bill to come into effect on 1 July 1990, one can only conclude that it is a tax Bill and that it is the revenue from business that the Government is wanting to get and intends to have. The Government is not putting the guidelines forward and is not giving people an opportunity to find out what it is that they are embarking upon.

I wish to refer to a letter that I have received from the Real Estate Institute of the Australian Capital Territory Ltd. It is worth noting what it has had to say. The letter says, in part, that the Institute has some concerns with provisions of the Bill and the effect on small business in Canberra-and I would add, of course, small business everywhere. The letter says:

In particular, we are concerned with the administration of the system. The Bill intends to be linked to the taxation system, thus creating a negative image in those affected by it (ie employers), rather than a positive response. Is it not a pity that that should be the case? It goes on:

The administration involved with the bill will adversely affect real estate agents in the ACT; in fact all small businesses in Canberra. QUESTION.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 20 December 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many Ministerial councils, or similar forums, for the meeting of State, Federal and other Ministers exist.
(2) What are their names and general objectives.
(3) How many times per year does the council(s)/forum(s) meet.
(4) What is the membership (including officials) of each council/forum, and who chairs the meetings.
(5) Is the council(s)/forum(s) served by a Secretariat; if so, what is its composition, who is responsible for financing it, and what does it cost.
(6) What meetings of the council(s)/forum(s) were held for the last financial years and how many persons attended the meetings, including officials and private ministerial staff.
(7) What were the costs of each of these meetings to the Commonwealth including travel, entertainment or dinners/lunches, accommodation, etc.
(8) Where were the meetings held and what was the venue.
(9) Are the records of the meetings available to the public; if so, where can they be obtained; if not, why not.
